They both deliver excellent performances, and, in my opinion, even Oscar-worthy ones, Specially for Gibson. The scene where Riggs almost kills himself in his apartment is quite an impressive achievement for Gibson, being the best scene on his career. And Glover also manages to deliver a very good performance. But apart from the main duo, there isn't really a lot to add on what refers to acting. No one from the supporting cast did a above-average job, but they really didn't need to. Gibson and Glover sure can hold the bar on their own.Another point that impressed me upon watching 'Lethal Weapon' was Richard Donner's directing. I've watched most of his other flicks, and I believe this is the best job he did since 'Superman'. He managed to always keep the pace of the flick, never let the bar go or anything. And also he did a incredible job filming the action scenes. The helicopter scene, to give the best example, is quite breath-taking, so is the chase at the end of the movie. And talking about the end - both the ending and the initial scenes are shockingly well-filmed. Technically, I can't also find many flaws in 'Lethal Weapon' - Stephen Goldblatt's cinematography works very well, so does the editing by Stuart Baird. If you're wandering if the musical score is good or not, there is only one thing to be said: Eric Clapton did it (along with Michael Kamen).What can I say? 'Lethal Weapon' is the movie that started it all - it started the buddy film genre and introduced us to Roger Murtaugh and Martin Riggs, characters we all know and love. The movie's script is awesome, and it's still copied nowadays. Richard Donner's directing is also great, but what makes it almost perfect is the chemistry between Mel Gibson and Danny Glover. Donner, Gibson, and Glover would still come back for three other sequels, but nothing can come close to the magic that was the first movie. Recommended to anyone who likes action flicks or just wanna have a good time.9/10

Mel Gibson is Martin Riggs an out of control loose cannon cop who lost his wife of 11-years. As he is struggling to survive as he is suffering burn out. And that nobody in the department wants him as he is been tagged as a "Lethal Weapon!"Danny Glover is the perfect straight man to Gibson's recklessness as Roger Murtaugh on the verge of retirement and is more of the by the book and rules follower compared to Gibson's reckless cop ways.But despite the two getting on one another's nerves. As their success rate in getting closed cases. But also their friendship as both need each other to lean on. Off and on the force.Director Richard Donner does a great job in the franchise. As the movies are really show the friendship and partnership of two cops who lean on one another.

reviews.review_title: More entertaining than, but almost as dated as me
reviews.content: I'll have to be careful what I put for the first Lethal Weapon; it's one of my daughter's favourite films and when younger she used to have a crush on Mel Gibson. So, it was a marvellous, even classic film.But what of the flimsy plot? Black and white cops up against ex-army heroin smugglers, interspersed by shedloads of comedy. How about the slapstick acting caricaturing the police force of the time, to be sure an ancient time when officers went about shouting Yipikaye to the baddies as they killed them unmercifully. The schmaltzy family scenes in contrast to the vigilante attitudes? No matter how laughable this always was or how dated it's getting it was always prime entertainment and a great way to spend two hours. Like Die Hard it was a deliberate and laudable propaganda attempt to get black and white people to understand together and to work for their common good together. Like Die Hard it had Christmas violence and baddies beyond the pale, in fact albino – baddies who only deserved to be terminated.It portrayed a brilliant fantasy world where Health & Safety or police protocols played no part, along with mobile phones, the internet and without the cgi cartoonery that's taken over movies in the last 20 years. There seemed to be plenty of time to enjoy nonsensical action films such as this back then. But I loved it again tonight and am already looking forward to the next time to check how much more dated it will have become.

Mel Gibson and Danny Glover have a chemistry as a duo that is unsurpassed in the action genre, many action flicks have a cop duo, but there is nearly always a weak character (and sometimes there are 2) Riggs and Murtaugh, thrown together as partners, have to battle against Riggs's madness and a bunch of highly motivated and very professional drug dealers.Investigating the apparent suicide of a young woman (the daughter of Murtaugh's Viet-Nam buddy) The pair begin to form a very dangerous partnership of experience and expertise, based on necessity rather than trust. With Murtaugh's daughter kidnapped and his own life on the line, we will find out how Lethal Riggs is.A rare blend of good characters and some light comic relief, this movie has all you need for a couple of hours of high octane entertainment.9/10

reviews.review_title: Possibly the granddaddy of "Buddy Cop" movies.
reviews.content: Gibson and Glover are the greatest duo in what has to be the greatest "buddy cop" action movie ever made. Most of the action is saved for the third act so we can get some character development. But, the writing from Shane Black of "Predator" and the directing from the great Richard Donner, are excellent. Plus you have Gary Busey as our villian before he went full tilt crazy guy.

Continuing my plan to watch every Mel Gibson movie in order, I come to Lethal Weapon.After releasing 8 movies in 5 years, Gibson didn't release a movie in 1986, but his next movie really sent his career into orbit. Lethal Weapon is not the first buddy cop movie ever made, but it was the first one to do it this well, this is almost the definitive buddy cop movie. almost every single one since then has tried to duplicate this movie. Plot In A Paragraph: Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) has just turned 50, and only has a few years to go before he retires from the Los Angeles Police Department. Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) has just lost his wife in an accident, and doesn't care if he lives or dies. They are paired together to investigate an apparent suicide. I've said countless times, car chases and shoot outs pretty much bore me now (hence me having no interest in the Fast & Furious franchise) but the difference here is, you actually care about the characters and the situations they are in. Shame Black's script is superb and for me director Richard Donner (who is still the director of the best Superman movie) pulled off a master stroke with his casting.Both Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are superb in their roles, as is Gary Busey, Darlene Love, Steve Kahan as Captain Murphy and Mary Ellen Trainor as Dr. Stephanie Woods (the Police Psychiatrist) do well in their small roles. Glover had been superb in The Colour Purple and Places In The Heart, and Gibson was a star on the rise, who hadn't quite made it big in America. He got to be serious, funny, heartbroken, crazy and the object of someone's affection.If there is a weak link in the cast, it is Mitchell Ryan as General Peter McAllister who seems to be in full pantomime villain mode and Ed O Ross who has a small role. The editing of the final fight irritates me every time too, but that really is nit picking of the highest order. Composer Michael Kamen and Eric Claptons score is a winner too. I also like Traci Wolfe as Murtaugh's daughter who has a crush on Gibson's Riggs. Excellently directed with a great score, Lethal Weapon is almost perfect entertainment. It was Gibson's biggest hit to date, ending the year the 9th highest grossing movie of 1987 with a domestic gross of $65 million. Beating movies such as Dirty Dancing, Living Daylights, Robocop, Wall Street and Arnie movies Predator and Running Man. Interestingly though, the similar themed movie Stakeout (which I love) slightly out grossed it.

This movie is an onslaught of action; beginning with the opening scene death to the captivating end, it's a bombardment of epic scenes and high emotions. The plot is okay but what definitively stands out is Mel Gibson's performance. From start to finish, Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) makes you feel excited just watching him. Whether it's with his psychotic bouts, unique demeanour or deep moments, his presence adds an energy to this movie that makes it both fun and insane (in a good way). His quality acting in Lethal Weapon is surely some of the best in cinema. Besides the amazing casting, the overall story is mediocre. In this film, though, it's the acting that makes it special. There are so many aspects to entertainment, and Lethal Weapon hit the mark with Mel as the lead.

Lethal Weapon has been one of the most successful buddy cop franchises and for good reason. Lethal Weapon is fun filled ride and offers some laughs along the way. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are an excellent team and set the foundation for a long running series. Many other films have attempted to capture the essence of this film, without much success. Lethal Weapon is incredible and assisted by a worthy sequel.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest action films ever made
reviews.content: Not much needs to be said about Lethal Weapon....besides it being one of the greatest action films ever made.There have been a lot of great buddy cop movies, but none compare to the chemistry that Mel Gibson and Danny Glover had in the 4 movie series.The action scenes and stunts are spectacular. The comedy (through brief in the first movie) is also great and well timed.Mel Gibson was amazing as the gung ho cop who thinks he had no reason to live after his wife dies. His emotional scenes were brilliant. Danny Glover was also amazing as the by the book cop and wonderful family man. Even though both men are opposites they are perfect partners which leads to them not being friends but as a family as well.Gary Busey is also chilling as one of the main bad guys Mr Joshua. The whole main cast and supporting cast all delivered wonderful performances in the movie. This truly is an action classic not to be missed

AMCHD ran this recently edited, bringing the language down to a PG level. If you dont like bad guys getting shot in Cops & Buddy flick, you might want to pass anyway. Danny Glover, family man and straight cop, gets partnered with lunatic Mel Gibson. Both guys are ex-Vietnam, but 'Riggs' (Gibson) is the mentally-deranged by highly-skilled LETHAL WEAPON.Some of their former war colleagues have continued the drug-smuggling in the private sector and the 2 cops get wind of the operation. The bad guys are anchored by a polite, white-haired dude (Gary Busey), who is the polar opposite of those giant snarling villians in the karate films: he is handsome, well-dressed, deferential but certainly in the same league as Riggs when it comes to being a deadly oppinent. Playing a good (charismatic) villain does wonders for your acting career. Even Tom Cruise tried it.Three scenes I always found amazing:
1) Riggs climbs a building to deal with a jumper. Soon the jumper wants no part of the crazy cop.
2) Busey rises in a helicopter to take out a guy who kives in a cliff-mansion. Great photography!
3) There is a final showdown between Gibson & Busey. Had to be. It's not realistic for a lawman to engage in a fistfight with a captured felon, but--dang! it's fun to watch.Often imitated (or satirized)-never duplicated. None of the sequels quite 'get' it.At the outset, I forgot: check yer IQ at the door. Rating ****/*****

Do things like magic really exist? Well, if you've seen Lethal Weapon - not only the greatest action comedy, but perhaps also the greatest movie of all time! - you should know that the answer to that question is YES. If you don't, it's very obvious that you need to see a doctor. And in case you for some incomprehensible reason haven't seen Lethal yet, I have only one thing to say: stop reading this comment and go rent it immediately!!! There's simply no logical excuse for anyone old enough NOT to see this brilliant movie.The Lethal Weapon series started out with this film back in 1987, starring the phenomenal Mel Gibson as psychotic loose cannon Martin Riggs and Danny Glover (truly wonderful as well) as his total opposite for a partner - family man and by-the-book police officer Roger Murtaugh.Murtaugh lives a happy life with his loving family in a friendly neighborhood and is planning to retire from the force. But on his 50th birthday his life takes off in a different direction when the daughter of an old friend from Vietnam jumps out from a window and dies. This incident tosses Murtaugh into a dangerous and twisted investigation. And as if that's not enough: he is also teamed up with a new partner - a burned-out lunatic named Martin Riggs, who's been leaning on the edge of suicide ever since his wife was killed in a car crash. Roger is shocked when he meets this "lethal weapon". These two cops only have two things in common: they're both Vietnam vets and they both hate working with partners. This is my all time favorite movie, because it gives you everything you could ever ask from a great flick: action, drama, suspense, and even love (without getting all sentimental). And if you love Mel Gibson (God, he used to be so beautiful!!)- like me - this is were he makes one of his strongest and most remarkable performances. Actually, I can hardly call it acting - he IS Riggs. The emotions he's going through is so evident in his eyes and so real and cuts right through your soul: you can actually feel his pain and his anger. And Mel also contributes a great deal to the humorous element of the film with his attitude, witty comments and eagerness of doing his job: "Man, I love this job! Can we put the sirens on?" Danny Glover is outstanding as Murtaugh and serves the audience a normal, middle-aged man who is fighting with his age, a daughter who's turning into a young woman and a partner who doesn't care whether he lives or dies. Danny's hilarious making those faces and throwing back at Mel! He plays his part with great sensitivity and I think he, just like Mel, gives so much life to his character that no other actor could have done it better. And together, he and Mel undoubtedly makes the best film team there was, is or ever will be! (The concept has been copied too many times, though..."With the fantastic action, humor, performances and screenplay, Lethal Weapon and its sequels definitely top the list of all time action movies. Danny and Mel (naturally) won an award for "best duo on screen" on MTV Movie Awards once, and considering their work with these series, I believe director Richard Donner and producer Joel Silver makes the best duo OFF screen.I'm convinced this is a movie that not only action fans would enjoy watching, so I recommend it to everyone. This is a movie you can't afford to miss!

One of the best buddy cop films ever. Some of Mel Gibson and Danny Glover's best work. Sure, there are plot holes, like almost any action movie or cop movie, such as not much in the way of investigations or suspensions after police-involved shootings. But it was fast-paced, exciting, and charming in parts. Oh, yes, and this was probably Gary Busey's best work ever. Shout-out to the lovely Traci Wolfe, playing a teenager when she was much older. Unfortunately Hollywood had to make a franchise out of it. The second film was quite good, the third was OK, and I haven't bothered to see the fourth. Must see, if you're young enough to have never seen it.

Yeah, yeah, yeah, I think the PC thing is that I'm not supposed to like this one but I'm supposed to like the horrible TV series instead? Something like that?Forget about it this is Shane Black at his finest macho shoot 'em up standards. And it's fun.Two cops, two Vietnam vets, two wonderfully colorful characters come together to solve a murder that grows and grows and grows until it becomes appropriately over the top and action packed fun.And, of course, by over-the-top I mean it spirals into the land of unbelievable in the way that only the finest action movies can deliver.

Detective Danny Glover is paired with cop Mel Gibson who is a borderline psycho and has a death wish.  Together, they try to stop a drug lord. Basically this is an ultra-violent action film with tons of gun battles and car chases.  I have nothing against violent action films, but this one has a very ugly edge.  The opening scene has a nude, coked out woman falling off a ledge into a car roof! The violence is bloody, there is plenty of gratuitous female nudity (not needed), woman are portrayed as sex objects or victims and the script has incredible leaps of logic.  Never boring and Glover and Gibson are very good (they have great chemistry) but way too extreme.

It seems utterly incredible that this poor movie inspired a successful series. Badly directed, badly written and badly acted, it is more like a series of action movie clichés than a story. It borrows heavily from various previous superior films especially Dirty Harry. The 'suicidal jumper' scene in both films makes the comparison; in Dirty Harry, the scene was honest, but the inferior copy version, the scene ends with an unearned and deceptive pay-off, a cheat in other words. It is not possible to speak of the plot being contrived, but rather a series of implausible contrivances one after another. The basic idea, an unstable cop being allowed to continue working (and even being transferred to homicide!), is utterly absurd in itself but it gets worse. Basic procedures, such as handcuffing subdued criminals, are not adhered to, leading to two characters drawing weapons and having to be killed. People start shooting for no apparent reason, such as at the swimming pool. A hackneyed and unconvincing plot about a secret conspiracy emerges. An over the top shoot out in the desert, complete with helicopter. A gruesome (but laughable) torture scene. Gibson hurls a dead body across a room like a deadly weapon. A sub-machine gun fight takes place on a crowded free-way. And a final punch-up while the cops just look on.Everything about this film is clunky. It takes a long time for the story to get going and it is held together by certain convenient details. The dialogue is wooden, as is the acting (apart from the kids, who at least emerge with credit). The music is of the late 80s variety, and sounds very dated now.Nor are the action scenes very memorable, just a series of deeply contrived set pieces which neither look good nor convince. Situations are set-up just so a car can drive through a wall or hit a bus or explode. There is no artistry in any of this, and none of it lingers in the memory.A cartoon, and not a particularly good one.

In this epic action adventure movie two LA cops partner up to take on the evil CIA drug smugglers. Roger Murtaugh an aging family man, long time on the force is forced to deal with the unhinged Martin Riggs. Together they must find the murderer of a young girl in the city. What should be a conventional detectives case suddenly turns into a roller coaster ride of pain, violence and revenge.This movie is simple a classic. The heyday of action movies were the 80's. The scenes featuring Riggs and his emotional breakdowns over his lost wife are extremely effective. The contrast between him and the cruel thugs with their absence of feelings goes someway to demonstrate how the goodness of the character always shines through despite his rage.The movie is great because both of the major characters played by Mel Gibson and Danny Glover pull off the tag team so well. One would be forgiven to think this is just another stupid action movie but this is not so. The theme of Christmas is all around, while these two cops go about their business of tracking down the murderers they share the bonds of friendship which develop over the course of the movie. Riggs rescuing Murtaugh, Murtaugh inviting Riggs into his house and of course Riggs be allowed to help his partner regardless of crimes he may be about to commit.

The movie is th epitome of the buddy cop movie. The chemistry between Glover and Gibson is off the charts. If you have never seen this movie, you are definitely missing out. Very believable and relatable people in this movie. This ranks high in my list of ultimate guy movies. Fun fact - this also counts as a Christmas movie....

Lethal Weapon actually starts out as a serious film where Mel Gibson is an officer so despondent over the loss of his wife that he engages in incredibly reckless behavior. When that doesn't get him a line of duty death for a bit you see him contemplating suicide. No one will work with him and Danny Glover newly assigned to him is having second, third, and fourth thoughts. But they gradually warm up to each other as Glover and his family kind of provide a new stability for him. Also that shared Vietnam experience.That Vietnam thing comes in handy on the case these two have now. A former Army General who had a kind of stealth command of assassins Mitchell Ryan has gone heavy into the drug business via the contacts he made in Vietnam. His top assassin Gary Busey is his number two. These two think that Gibson and Glover got certain information about a big shipment coming in that their partner here told them before he was killed. That sets up all the action which is a cross between the Dirty Harry and the Indiana Jones features. The first Lethal Weapon got an Oscar nomination for Sound. Not sure if the three succeeding films got that kind of recognition. But they made money.

reviews.review_title: Lethal weapon is an absolute classic of the genre, with great script and direction. Danny Glover and Mel Gibson turns the film into something truly unforgettable
reviews.content:
The 1980s are certainly the best representation of action cinema, bringing several classic copies to the present day, which would become successful worldwide franchises. In this medium, we can include the continuations of the Rocky franchise, Die Hard, Rambo, among others. Lethal weapon is certainly one of the most successful examples of its kind. Produced by Joel Silver, scripted by Shane Black and directed by Richard Donner, the same behind the super-successful Superman (1978), the film marked the era, raising more than 120 million dollars at the box office, with a budget of 15 million dollars. In addition, it was nominated for the Oscar for Best Sound Mixing. Due to the great commercial and critical success, the film became one of the main works of Glover and Gibson, initiating a successful film franchise of three more sequences and a television series.Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) is a madman who is always on the edge. On the other hand, policeman Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) is a quiet man, waiting only for his retirement to arrive. Despite the differences, they become partners to fight a gang of drug traffickers, made up of ex-Vietnam War soldiers.Beginning screenwriter Shane Black definitely understood the buddy cop style - marked by classic series like Miami Vice, Starsky & Hutch, CHiPs, Agent 86, Hawaii Five-O and so many others - and cinema would never be the same ... Black part of the desire to do something close to an "urban western", putting us in sunny Los Angeles in the 80s. The story here is a mere pretext for us to analyze and entertain ourselves with the very amusing relationship of the characters. Glover masterfully and comfortably embodies the older policeman who believes in a safer and more traditional approach to investigation, while Gibson simply explodes on the scene in Riggs' memorable figure, a guy who, to summarize things a lot, is freaking and unstable. The death of his wife in a car accident turned him into an uncontrolled suicide, a characteristic that Black uses very well in his script and that yields brilliant moments from Gibson's performance, whose fury reaches even fun levels when facing some of the criminals here.The empathy that "Lethal weapon" provokes in the viewer is largely due to the fact that the two policemen are ordinary people, with many problems and completely vulnerable. In addition, Danny Glover and Mel Gibson's performances are obviously very collaborative. The duo's dynamics are impressive and the actors are at ease in their roles. Watch as Riggs hums during the target shooting session as he hits all the shots, causing Roger to be astonished, while his friend demonstrates firmness in confronting Riggs' trauma when needed. By teaming up with Murtaugh, Riggs ends up earning a new family and a second chance. Seeing these days, it may seem a bit shaky, since buddy cop movies have become very popular. But, at the time, there was a freshness that did not go unnoticed by the audience and the critics. True friendship appears in happy and sad moments.The excellent introduction of the characters places the viewer very well in the plot. Right away, we know that Murtaugh faces problems with his age through his reaction to family jokes on his birthday, reinforced by the phrase "I'm too old for that", repeated over and over again during the feature. We also know, in his first appearance, that Riggs is a person left in life, living in a trailer and not seeming to care much for the mess that surrounds him (in reality, this mess reflects his psychological state, revealing the good work of direction of art). It is also worth mentioning that having participated in the Vietnam War is perhaps the only point in common between the two policemen. While one seeks the calm of retirement and has a stable family, the other seeks death in every way after having his family destroyed, which makes him a constant danger to everyone who crosses his path. In the impressive scene in which Riggs puts the gun to his head and mouth, the reason for his pain is evident - and Gibson conveys this feeling very well, crying and fighting the urge to drop everything and leave this life. The script spreads evidence throughout the narrative, but never gives much explanation about Riggs' drama, which is elegant and correct. Images speak more than words.
Michael Kamen, who just completed his work on Highlander, composed the soundtrack for Lethal Weapon. The guitar part of the Riggs theme was performed by Eric Clapton. Kamen and Clapton had worked together on the music for the 1985 BBC TV series Edge of Darkness (whose theatrical adaptation would later be, coincidentally, starring Mel Gibson). The saxophone part of the Murtaugh theme was performed by David Sanborn. The Christmas song "Jingle Bell Rock", performed by Bobby Helms, is played during the opening credits of the film. The song "Lethal Weapon" by the hard rock band Honeymoon Suite is played during the final credits of the film without being credited. The peculiar relationship of the protagonists is exceptionally accompanied by the soundtrack. It's a sensual and evocative song, whose mix of a heavy saxophone worthy of a Sidney Bechet and Clapton's vibrant guitar brings a perfect harmony with the story and its characters: the meeting between the new and the old, the classic and the radical, while the notes effectively emulate the mood of a noir that falls well in this dangerous Los Angeles.Donner's direction is exquisite. Having just left the success of The Goonies (1985), Donner lends his talent for composition and action to bring Black's text to life. The wide open plans and simple choreography for the fight scenes guarantee an agile and fun rhythm, and Donner is smart to, for example, lead the sequence where Riggs deals with a suicide bomber in the city center, where we see how the framing limitation was essential to hide a very important element that guarantees one of the best surprises in the scene.Mixing elements of action and comedy is always welcome, as these two genres usually marry very well when the junction is performed correctly, even more in police films. Fortunately, Richard Donner got his hand on this first feature in the remarkable and entertaining series. The initial traveling of "Lethal Weapon" takes us to Amanda Hunsaker's (Jackie Swanson) apartment to the sound of the lively Christmas song "Jingle Bells". Upon entering the apartment, however, the reality is quite different from the joy that Christmas brings. The young blonde, drugged and apparently beside herself, walks to the balcony where her life will end. The shocking crash scene is very well done by Donner, who shows the impact in a very realistic way, ending the sequence with an impressive plan made from inside the affected car. The director also takes great care in the sensational action sequences, with emphasis on the explosion of a house, the invasion of a mansion and, mainly, the entire final sequence, which begins with the heavy torture of the police (note the painful reactions of Riggs and Murtaugh) and only ends in the fight between Riggs and Joshua (Gary Busey) in front of Roger's house. Although exaggerated, the final fight is visually beautiful, accentuated by the obscure photography, the rain and the agitated camera that alternates close-ups (highlighting the pain of the characters) and distant shots, which allow us to appreciate the elaborate strokes delivered.In another moment, right after the kidnapping of Rianne (Traci Wolfe), Donner creates a beautiful plan where Roger and Riggs talk in front of the Christmas tree. Observe how cinematographer Stephen Goldblatt uses the strong dominance of red in the scene, visually illustrating the duo's astral hell at that time. Finally, in the tense and spectacular sequence of the desert, Donner starts and ends with a traveling, setting the viewer to the place. Notice how Stuart Baird's excellent montage ensures an exciting rhythm to the scene without ever sounding confusing. Baird, by the way, keeps the narrative agile and the pace exciting at all times, which is essential in an action movie.In addition to being a lot of fun, important everyday issues are addressed: raising children, family unity, discussing values and the safety of loved ones from police, corruption of high-ranking members of government agencies, drug trafficking, prostitution, excessive urban violence, erotic video market, although some of these themes are only scratched. Even touching on these subjects, the episode is still pointed out as a diversion for "the whole family", thanks to the direction of actors, as well as the thousand jokes and absurdities so common in brucutus films.Lethal weapon is an absolute classic of the genre, with great script and direction. But it is really the explosive presence of Danny Glover and Mel Gibson that forever changed the buddy cop and that turns the film into something truly unforgettable, that mixes correct doses of action, humor and suspense, and still finds space to show, even if from superficially, the effects of a disease that attacks many people today. Well directed by Richard Donner, it also has the strength of the intertwined main duo, extremely dynamic and directly responsible for the viewer's empathy. The wonderful action sequences are the icing on the cake in this film that has its flaws, but guarantees fun without offending the audience's intelligence. Lethal weapon is a metaphor for the story of love and friendships between two men, who discover new meanings for their lives, Murtaugh learns to accept the hardships of old age while Riggs finds a new family and more reasons to live beyond work.

The 'Lethal Weapon' series is often remembered for the comedy aspects of the later episodes but even though the first instalment contains a few good laughs it is much darker in tone than the various sequels. That tone is set by the opening scene where we see a beautiful young woman jump to her death from a tall building; It looks like suicide except the drugs she had taken had been adulterated. One of the cops to attend the scene is Roger Murtaugh who just happened to have had a call from the girl's father, an old war buddy, that morning. This being Hollywood there are no coincidences and Roger and his new partner must investigate. His new partner is Martin Riggs, a cop on the edge with suicidal tendencies who is potentially a danger to those around him. As the two of them investigate the girl's death they stumble upon a trail that will lead them to confront a drug gang made up of former special-forces personnel who learnt their trade during the war in Vietnam.Made in a time before action movies were packed with CGI this film is packed with action that looks real; whether it is hand to hand combat, shootouts or exploding cars. The story is gripping and packed with great characters; leads Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are great as Riggs and Murtaugh but it is Gary Busey who plays the sinister Mr. Joshua who steals every scene he is in. As well as the great action there are some nice laughs although they don't feel forced like the gags in later films in the series. If you like action films this is a must see!

I was so incredibly naive in 1987, I had no clue, "Lethal Weapon," was a movie or even existed.My best friend had a suprise birthday present for me in 1987. She had reservations at Spago's, in Beverly Hills, the ultimate place to have any kind of food, what so ever. Wolfgang Puck was the king of restaurants.We entered Spago's and we were surrounded by a group of extremely well dressed, highly attractive people. They basically overtook Spago's. The reservation my friend had made, weeks in advance, was undone.It didn't matter to me, we had so much fun sitting at the bar, having drinks and appetizers and lamenting, "Why do accountants have such priority over us? We had reservations!" We misunderstood the manager explaining to us, a party to celebrate the premier of Lethal Weapon was under way at Spago's. We thought they said Legal Weapons, and it was some kind of accounting/attorney/legal party.Still one of the best nights of my life.

reviews.review_title: THE EPITOME OF THE BUDDY-COP FLICK!
reviews.content: This is one of those flicks where, if you go too long without a rewatch, you slowly start to forget just how much of a near-masterpiece it is. Or maybe I'm just getting old.Every scene is on point as all hell. The perfect combination of pulp, grit, action, suspense and drama. I'd long thought Martin Riggs was my favorite character, but who am I kidding? The saxophone is probably my favorite character in all of cinema. In fact, you know what? It is! Move over Dr. Loomis and Rain Man... There's a saxophone comin' through.My introduction to this film was via VHS bargain bin back in the day. I think Movie Gallery was doing one of their 3 for $15 sales, if I remember correctly. I usually used said sales to purchase two flicks I'd already rented and loved, then took a chance on something well-known but that had slipped under my radar for whatever reason. Out of all those dice rolls, this was undoubtedly the best chance I ever took. I'd go on to absolutely LOVE the concept of buddy-cop flicks, but unfortunately few would ever live up to this gem.Also, Tom Atkins, the greatest actor of all time, is somewhat present. What a gem of a movie.

reviews.review_title: One of my all-time favourite 80s action films with a two word title.
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon has some of the worst incidental music I have ever heard in a film—random widdly guitar and god-awful tuneless saxophone warbling that I found grating even back in the 80s when such things were considered cool. It also features an unnecessarily drawn out shot of Mad Mel's bare ass and some gratuitous mullet action (also courtesy of Mel).Despite this, the film remains one of my all-time favourite 80s action films with a two word title (after Die Hard, of course) thanks to its stars' wonderful chemistry, the witty script by Shane Black, top direction from Richard Donner and several supporting actors so awesome that, as legend has it, if all three were to appear on-screen at the same time, time and space would simply cease to exist.For the record, that potentially catastrophic triumvirate of top talent consists of toothy, crazy cult actor Gary Busey as albino killer Joshua, white-haired, mustachioed character actor Tom Atkins as soon-to-be-dead-guy, and everybody's favourite on-screen terrorist Al Leong as Endo the torturer. With guys like that in the film, it's worth putting up with Gibson's arse for a while.
Is it the greatest cop/buddy movie of all time?Yup

reviews.review_title: The best of the Lethal series.
reviews.content: The original Lethal Weapon is very energetic and full of suspense. It has the right amount of comedy and action, it's a great buddy picture. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are perfect together and Gary Busey, who always plays bad guys so well, is dead on as Mr. Joshua. The movie has a good plot and the action scenes are fantastic. Richard Donner can be a very good director and this is one of his best. Shane Black's screenplay is well written and the editing and cinematography are very tight. There are a lot of cop buddy movies out there, but Lethal Weapon is one of the best.

LETHAL WEAPON (1987) is perhaps the best cop buddy film made. Yes, there were several before (and many since!), but this one feels like the peak of the genre, and it's mainly due to the tremendous acting displayed by it's stars Mel Gibson and Danny Glover, but ESPECIALLY Gibson! I honestly believe that Gibson was robbed of a Best Actor nomination for his intense, deeply involving performance of L.A. Police Sergeant Martin Riggs, a suicidal 11-year police vet who mourns the loss of his wife in a tragic car accident every single day of his life. Riggs lives life on the edge. He can't keep a partner due to his affinity for danger. In comes Sergeant Roger Murtaugh (excellently played by Danny Glover), a family man who just turned 50 and is ready for early retirement, because, you know, he's "too old for this sh*t!" LOL.Riggs is paired with Murtaugh to investigate an apparent suicide of a coked-out 18-year old Amanda Hunsaker (played by Jackie Swanson of "Cheers" fame in the scene that opened the film) and things get interesting fast as the "suicide" leads the cops to a web of intrigue. The girl's father, a prominent banker Michael Hunsaker is a former Army buddy of Murtaugh who saved his life in Vietnam. The banker is played by Tom Atkins (a stalwart of John Carpenter 70s-80s flicks) and Atkins is very persuasive as a man in over his head. Turns out that Hunsaker is involved in money laundering, using his bank as a front for a local drug ring comprised of former military specialists. The head of the ring is General McAllister (played with cold detachment by Mitchell Ryan) and his right hand is Mr. Joshua (played with scary, scene-stealing brilliance by Gary Busey). There seemed to be a trend around this time of having high class villains in action movies, with McAllister and Joshua actually preceding the Die Hard villains Hans and Karl by about a year and a half (Lethal Weapon technically premiered on Christmas Day '86 while Die Hard came out the summer of '88). But the Lethal Weapon villains are just as scary and intense (if not more so) than the Die Hard ones. The real pull of Lethal Weapon to me is the authentic chemistry and budding relationship between Riggs and Murtaugh and their snappy banter throughout. There have been buddy movies ad nauseum over the years, but this one feels like the best due to the believable progression of the Riggs-Murtaugh relationship. Of course, this being the first film of the eventual series (there were 4 total), this is the only one where Riggs and Murtaugh actually disliked each other for most of the film, but by the end they were best buddies, which carried over to all the sequels. Anyone who watched any of the (inferior) sequels first will find it hard to imagine that these 2 cops actually had an active dislike for each other at one point, but you have to start somewhere!Notable performances are also delivered by Darlene Love (as Murtaugh's wife Trish) and Traci Wolfe (as Murtaugh's eldest daughter Rianne, who has a crush on Riggs). The film was directed with energy, style, and flair by Richard Donner, who notedly directed the first Superman film from 1978 (interesting dichotomy) and would go onto direct all 3 Lethal Weapon sequels. But this is the one that got it right...it's the original...usually that's the keeper!

reviews.review_title: I'm Too Old For This S***
reviews.content: Plot: One police officer with suicidal tendencies and his close-to-retirement colleague have to uncover a huge drug-smuggling operation and at the same time cope with each other.You'll love Lethal Gun if: You like these macho, cop-duo over the top action films of the 80's and don't really care about getting you intelligence insulted. Honestly I rented this movie just to help myself remember why I liked it when I was very young and I can't say I figured out why. However if you can handle the movie's cheesiness, unrealistic situations and characters and the stereotypes of US cop films, you're in for one of the best of its kind at least that's what the majority says. The saving grace of the film: the great chemistry between Danny Glover and Mel Gibson and while when I was younger I loved the psycho bad-ass Mel Gibson, I can see now that Glover not only plays a much, much better character but also a more realistic one thus easier to relate to, (unless you are 8 years old).You'll hate Lethal Gun if: You hate these unrealistic cop films and if you want a movie with an actually interesting plot. Honestly what's the big deal with this movie and its -far worse- sequels? They are one of the worst movies I've ever seen. The plot is pretty typical nothing will leave you with your mouth open or surprise you. The characters are of cardboard quality at best, with Gibson playing a cartoon who is more irritating than cool. Glover plays the conservative family man, (with a moustache of course!), and Gibson is the rebel cop who cries at night while trying to kill his self because his wife died in a traffic accident boooohoooooo! Riiiiiight The action sequences are boring and the way the main characters and especially Gibson behave is unrealistic and far from heroic more like suicidal just for the fun of it. You want a good cop movie look elsewhere. Yes, I've seen worse but the point here is that this movie is one of the most successful ones!!!FINAL VERDICT: A Series Of Action Movie Clichés (4.4/10)[+] Great main character chemistry.[-] Boring action sequences and plot. Extremely stereotypical characters.Also Check: Bad Boys (1993) - Die Hard (1988) – Lethal Weapon (1989) – Rush Hour (1998)P.S.: My purpose in all my IMDb Reviews is not to say "I like\don't like this movie" but to help you decide whether YOU will like it or not since everything is all about taste and expectations IMO...
I like the bit where he says "I'm too old for this ...."

Riggs and Murtaugh changed the game for cop movies. They set the gold standard for a cop tandem. I can't think of a duo before them. Tibbs and Gillespie teamed up in In the Heat of the Night but it wasn't the same type of movie and that pairing was more accidental and impermanent. Dirty Harry had a few partners but 1.) his partnerships were very much a solo act with extra weight in tow and 2.) all his partners were either killed or injured.I'd say that Riggs (Gibson) and Murtaugh (Glover) set the bar for a police pair and they were such a mismatch. Riggs was the younger, more athletic, very unstable partner who did things in an unorthodox manner. Murtaugh was the older, partially broken down, family man that seemed like he was just waiting for retirement. As we know by the three sequels that followed that retirement wasn't that close for him.Lethal weapon was a cool movie that gave us fighting, explosions, and shooting without it being overdone (much like in a movie I just saw called Hobbs and Shaw-or as I call it: How Many Things Can We Blow Up or Kill). The main characters were special, the story was a good one and the pacing was nice. This was a trend setter.

This is my favorite installment. It is well done, edgy, action packed, great cast, etc. Even though the partners are different they compliment each other very well. I think they should have stopped at this one. IMO it was the best.

reviews.review_title: I'm too old for this sh*t!
reviews.content: Danny Glover and Mel Gibson defined the buddy cop picture. It all started with this classic, which I tuned into when I was sure new England had the Cowbums down in the dirt.20 years afters it's release it is still relevant. The mercs that Riggs and Murtaugh disposed of in this film are the same as the ones currently operating in Iraq. We didn't need them in Vietnam, and we don't need them now.Gary Busey played my second favorite person I most wanted to see get it in the series. Traci Wolfe as Rianne was fantastic and it is good seeing her grow up.Seeing Cheryl Baker in the brief shower scene was a nice treat.

reviews.review_title: A step above the usual buddy cop movies
reviews.content: It shows my youth, but the Lethal Weapon movies were before my time. For Danny Glover's week on Hot Toasty Rag, I attended history class and rented them. Mel Gibson's mullet, once his crowning glory, just seems funny today. It flops around behind him as he runs, as wild and crazy as the rest of his personality. But once I had my good laugh, I was able to sit back and really enjoy these movies.In the genre of buddy cop movies, these are so much fun! The first of the four establishes each character's backstory and motivation: Danny Glover is a devoted family man entering his senior years on the police force, and Mel Gibson is grieving over his dead wife. In the first movie, he seriously considers suicide and takes ridiculous risks on the job because he doesn't really care what happens to him. He's extremely reckless (which I'm sure made all the women in the audience swoon), but in a pretty dangerous and scary way. He shows his guns, he shows his buns; what else is there? Now ladies, don't forget there's more to true love than just that. There's a great smile and bright eyes - Oh, he has those, too.Now, onto Danny Glover. He's funny, too, in his own way. He loves his wife and kids, and whenever Mel pushes him out of his comfort zone, he begrudgingly ends up enjoying the ride. Both leads get to show off their acting chops in these movies, which make them a step above the usual buddy cop flicks that just focus on comedy. There are some very tense action sequences, interesting characters that you want to keep watching, and a sweet blossoming friendship. The start of the movie shows Danny Glover's house decorated for Christmas (this came out the year before Die Hard). Mel is without friends or family, but if you want to take bets on whether or not he'll find both before Christmas dinner, the odds are good.Kiddy Warning: Obviously, you have control over your own children. However, due to violence, I wouldn't let my kids watch it.

reviews.review_title: The Best Buddy Cop Movie Ever Made
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon is the best buddy cop movie ever made and a quintessential piece of American commercial cinema. This movie is a perfect example of how to take a relatively common format with broad appeal and bring it to its natural peak. It is energetic, well cast, and toes the line between humor and emotional excellently.Now I have to admit some bias here as I am a huge fan of Danny Glover. I first saw him in Predator 2, which I liked him in although the movie was disappointing when compared to the original. Then I saw him much later again when I watched my favorite tv show of all time, Arrested Development, where he had me in stitches. Pairing his old, charming, and gruff cop persona with Mel Gibson's wild eyed always-say-die energy was a stroke of genius. Glover is an old cop who has amassed a good family and a nice life that he wants to protect, the exact opposite of Mel's character who is a reckless cop who has nothing to live for but the job after his wife died in a car accident. At first the situation plays out about as well as you expect, with neither particularly liking the other. It becomes clear they have very, very different methods of diffusing situations that often put them at odds with one another. Most importantly, this relationship does not feel forced and there is a minimal amount of cheese. I cannot stress how well Glover and Gibson play their characters off one another.One of the only points I can take away from the film is that the villains are no Hans Grubers. They are generic drug dealing ex military guys who like to prove how tough they are by burning themselves in front of potential clientele. That being said, they are well acted and rightfully not the focal point of the movie, only appearing to show their menace or to get into shootouts with Murtaugh and Riggs (the cops Danny and Mel play, respectively).The big reason this movie works in two fold, like almost all good action movies it does not take itself too seriously and its the fast paced and explosive action sequences works within the laws of its own universe. There is always something going on or surprising the viewer to keep them engaged. Not to mention it at time shows restraint, which movies often don't. They use feature a helicopter often but never show it exploding mid air in a ball of fire as so many other movies would do for the sheer spectacle of it despite its obvious lack of feasibility. The violence is abrupt but not overtly gruesome. It presents a convincing world and two heroes that are worthy of our attention within it. You feel the stress of the cops life as they are threatened going about their everyday work in a city full of drugs and crime and not in a cartoonish way.Action, heart, fantastic actors, this movie has all you could want from a cheesy action flick, and it does not feel nearly dated as one might think in this cgi spectacle age. A must watch for any action fan.

This movie just oozes the 80's. So if you're really into 80's cop action this will certainly do the trick. But as a standalone movie, sure its very well made but you won't really get much out of it as just an action movie. So all in all, very well made and iconic for its kind, but ultimately a but lacking.6/10: ok.

This film is truly the greatest action film of all time, with only Die Hard and the other 'Lethal' sequels coming close. In these days of XXX and Bad Boys II, and The Island, thank god that action fans still can watch the real action movies, the kind that Hollywood simply doesn't make any more. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover make the perfect on-screen partnership, in my opinion it is the best ever seen. Throughour the 4 movies, their chemistry never fails. The direction is superb from Richard Donner and the screenplay by Shane Black is remarkable as it was his first movie script. Why this film has such a low rating is beyond me, it deserves and 8.5 at the very least. Any one who likes action films but hasn't seen this should do so because every action flick that you've enjoyed is thanks to the standard set by this 1987 CLASSIC.

This is the classic deranged-but-good-cop-with-dead-wife and conservative-aged-but-also-good-cop who pair and face the bad guys who as usual are ex-CIA and stuff. Usual. Boring. But it has some good action scenes and some lines cleverer than average. And awwww this title fight scene in the end, so ridiculously ridiculous. Just fancy the situation.

reviews.review_title: One of the best examples of buddy cop cinema
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon is a fun, exciting movie that deserves its standing in the pantheon of great action films. Contrary to popular believe this film didn't make Mel Gibson a star- he already was one after Mad Max but it did make him a household name in the US. He and Danny Glover are amazing as the mismatched buddy cop duo and one can say Lethal Weapon restarted the sub-genre after 48 hours had done so a few years ago. Featuring great sequences, dialogues worth remembering, and great pace Lethal Weapon is a must watch.

reviews.review_title: The quintessential buddy cop action flick!
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon is the eighties action film that kicked off the whole buddy-cop trope in Hollywood. It's directed by Richard Donner (Superman II) and penned by Shane Black (Predator). Our cast of stars features Danny Glover and Mel Gibson in the lead roles with Gary Busey as a henchman to the main villain, The General played by Mitchell Ryan. I decided to pair the film with a nice Indica like King Louis XIII from Marley Natural. It's a relaxing strain that provides a good deal of happiness. A good combination to dive right into a badass picture like this. The earthy tastes and piny aromas pair well with a good beer too. If that's your kind of thing. The film follows the pairing of two LAPD detectives. Martin Riggs is a detective that is psychologically broken and emotionally damaged following the death of his wife. Roger Murtaugh is a veteran cop that works hard to support his family. They get paired together as partners working various crimes and bonding. Roger is constantly tested by Riggs' inherently psychotic behavior. He almost gives up. However, after things go south and the duo bands together to put an end to a very dangerous group of drug smugglers called Shadow Company. The film features cheesy action film acting and witty dialogue, mostly between Gibson and just about everyone he comes in contact with. His Martin Riggs character is iconic. He stands as one of the best cops in movie history. Danny Glover is the perfect straight man but it's kind of unfortunate that he was so tight cast. Busey is badass in this movie. He looks awesome and does a great job of projecting himself as menacing. Tom Atkins is good too, his role is minimal, but he gives it everything. That is up until his death, which is rather goofy looking. Lethal Weapon also has an amazing soundtrack provided by Michael Kamen and Eric Clapton. Yes, that Eric Clapton. The howling saxophone and blazing guitar set upon a sprawling Los Angeles cityscape provide an amazing atmosphere for the story. The soundtrack provides a great technique for building suspense that gets paid off with intense action scenes. This movie is a hell of a ride. It builds an amazing world that gets explored at break-neck speed. In some cases it's far too fast-paced to be bad. All of the faults with the film are steamrolled by the constant action. The fight scenes are brutal and unrelenting. The final showdown is a thing of pure eighties glory. I love it. It's a classic that should be enjoyed by everyone at least once! There's a reason that It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia loves it so much. The King Louis XIII paired really well with Lethal Weapon. It tasted so good, I ended up having an extra snapper or two. The cannabis had me feeling really relaxed and sunken into my couch. The uplifting effects had me alert and ready for the suspense of the action scenes, which were numerous. The effects were long lasting and are still prevalent when writing this review. Although it feels great, the taste and smell are the leading factors with this particular batch from Marley Natural. Check it out if you can!

reviews.review_title: A superb cop, buddy-buddy action film
reviews.content: Considered for me one of the greatest quadrilogies of all and film of the 80s, Lethal Weapon is the action, cop buddy-buddy movie starring Mel Gibson as Seargant Martin Rigs, a loose cannon who having lost his wife to a car accident is on the ragged edge and lives in a trashy run down trailer near the beach with his dog Sam. Danny Glover plays Seargant Roger Murtagh, a 50 year coloured man with a family who lives in a middle class house. He and Riggs are teamed up to investigate a young girl who supposedly dived out of her window who was involved in drugs and making pornographic films. Soon they are on the trail of drugs and mercenaries.Throughout Riggs remains a lose cannon and goes off on one when he gets mad. Glover and Gibson make a fantastic duo when sparring with each other and coming to trust and become buddies right at the end of the film. There is great comic chemistry between them, which will have you in fits. Gary Busey as the principal villain makes a lasting impact.This is a superb first film with excellent and exciting action, great humour and a good story that all blend in seamlessly together. And two superb performances from Gibson and Glover that dosen't just make this your average action flick. One of the funniest and most exciting action films of it's time and for me still is now.

reviews.review_title: I am surprised it took me so long to finally see this one.
reviews.content: Although I am not a huge action film fan, I am surprised that it took me 32 years to finally see "Lethal Weapon". After all, it's a rather iconic 80s film...the sort insane film buffs (like me) have likely seen. So, to correct this oversight, I'm finally seeing the picture...and fortunately just in time for the holidays since the film is set around Christmas.The film is the first of four "Lethal Weapon" films starring Mel Gibson and Danny Glover...and there's also a 2016 remake starring an all-new cast.When the story begins, Riggs (Gibson) is living a pathetic life. Following his wife's death, he spends his time drinking heavily and feeling sorry for himself. He also is suicidal--and takes all sorts of insane risks as a cop. After all, if he dies, he really wouldn't mind it at all. Because he is so unstable, he's just been assigned a new partner, Sergeant Murtaugh (Glover). While this pairing might seem like a bad thing for Murtaugh since his new partner is so unhinged, it turns out to be a blessing. After all, Riggs is an amazing cop...and Murtaugh needs all the help he can get with a new case involving an old friend's daughter who kills herself at the beginning of the film. Why does he need so much help? Because the death is somehow related to a vicious gang of heroin dealers...and they're more than willing to kill anyone who learns of their operation."Lethal Weapon" is definitely a turn off your brain and enjoy sort of movie--especially the final third of the film. Too often, the film relies on explosions, giant fight scenes and crazy stunts...and this is why I enjoyed the set up for the story but overall could only give the picture a 6. With scenes such as crashing a police car into Murtaugh's house, cars that explode and the insane (and rather stupid) fist fight at the end, the movie chose again and again to offer stunts and explosions at the expense of logic and the story. Now I am NOT saying it's a bad film...but it's an excessive one whose violence doesn't enhance the picture (unlike in "Die Hard"...where the excesses MAKE the movie). Worth seeing but far from a must-see.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic buddy cop film starring Gibson and Glover
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon is a fun, exciting movie that deserves its standing in the pantheon of great action films. Another staple of 80s action filmmaking, Lethal Weapon is solid character work mixed with a so-so mystery topped with quality action. It's interesting how there are a small bevy of screenwriters who can manage to come through as distinctly as a director. Shane Black's written films feel almost as much Shane Black as Shane Black directed films. Lethal Weapon has a distinct feel to it shared with movies like The Nice Guys and Kiss Kiss Bang Bang. It's not that Richard Donner as director doesn't come through, it's just that the types of characters, dialogue, and overall subject matter are so distinctly Black's that Black as a writer ends up a solid example against auteur theory that places authorship primarily on the director.It's one of the premiere buddy cop movies with the younger Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) paired up with the older (having just turned fifty) veteran Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover). They're put together on the case of a prostitute who jumped from a high rise balcony right around the same time that an old Vietnam acquaintance of Murtaugh's, Michael Hunsaker (Tom Atkins), reaches out to him out of the blue. It turns out that the girl who plummeted to her death was actually Hunsaker's daughter, and Hunsaker wants revenge on the men who killed her, he says, even though her death seems pretty clearly a suicide. Toxicology disagrees, though, saying that the pills she took were laced with a poison. There may be more to this.And then we get a heavy focus on the burgeoning relationship between Riggs and Murtaugh. I think Mel Gibson may be my favorite big Hollywood star of the 80s. On top of being charismatic as hell, he's actually a really good actor as well. His Riggs is a broken man on the edge of suicide because of the car crash that killed his wife. His early scene where he puts a gun in his mouth, ready to pull the trigger, is exceedingly well performed by Gibson. Murtaugh, by contrast, is the patriarch of a happy, middle-class family with a wife (who can't cook), a teenage daughter, and a couple of smaller children. He's content at home, and into his life comes this suicidal maniac of a new partner. The heart of the movie is really the burgeoning relationship between the two as Murtaugh shows Riggs that life can be happy again, maybe. It's far from heavy-handed, just a portrait of two cops getting to know each other, anchored mostly by Gibson's surprisingly complex performance going from manic to wounded to charming, all without losing that semblance of madness driven by grief. It's about an older man reaching out to a wounded younger man and offering a vision of a life after his melancholy.The two then go on a hunch that there's more to the death of the girl than just some bad pills. They go to the house of the prostitute questioned at the scene which explodes as they approach. There's definitely something else going on, and...because the film spent most of the first hour dedicated to the relationship between Riggs and Murtaugh, there isn't that much time to really give this mystery of the death of Murtaugh's friend's daughter all that much room to breathe. It's very quickly figured out, including an exposition dump from Hunsaker, and then we're into the final act where action dominates.The lack of attention to the actual mystery ends up feeling like a bit of an anchor, little more than an excuse to get our well-drawn buddy cops into the action climax. And the action climax is solid stuff. There's a showdown at a desert location with Riggs on a sniper rifle. There's a torture scene with Riggs getting electrocuted. There are shootouts to rescue Murtaugh's teenage daughter. It's solidly made stuff.And then the final confrontation feels wrong. The bad guy's chief henchman Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey) orchestrated the kidnapping of the teenaged Rianne Murtaugh (Traci Wolfe), threatening Murtaugh's family while Riggs has been dealing with how to live despite the sadness of his wife's death. So, the final physical confrontation is obviously between Mr. Joshua and...um...Riggs? There's something there about how both Mr. Joshua and Riggs were members of Special Forces in Vietnam, but it's not the emotional center of the final half hour of the film that was about rescuing Murtaugh's daughter. Sure, Murtaugh wouldn't be able to take someone like Mr. Joshua in a fight, but the way it's all filmed it feels like this is resolution of the film's entire thematic center. It's not. It feels...weird. Not to say that the actual fight doesn't work from a purely plot perspective. It resolves the danger of Mr. Joshua while, at the same time, doing it with a certain stylistic flare as Riggs and Mr. Joshua fist fight on the Murtaugh lawn with the sprinklers providing some very nice texture to the image.The movie really rides on its stars, though. Gibson does all of the heavy lifting as Riggs while Glover is appropriately wearied and exhausted by the whole situation. Everyone else around them is fine without really having enough screentime to be much else.I kind of love the first half of the film, where it's mostly a pure character drama, and I find the second half helped greatly by the work in the first half but kind of all over the place at the same time. It's never not entertaining, but it really could have been built a bit better to take advantage of the genre conventions it was dwelling in to greater effect.

With Christmas a-comin' in a couple of moths, there's no better time to rewatch the buddy cop film to end all buddy cop films. Few action movies before or since have wowed me as much as Lethal Weapon, and for good reason.Let's start with the obvious. The cast. Specifically, those two phenomenal central characters. Martin Riggs and Roger Murtaugh. Played to perfection by Mel Gibson and Danny Glover. I just love how well their respective storylines intertwined with each other. The film's central theme is family, and we get two vastly different perspectives on it. Roger the stereotypical family man, Riggs the manic-depressive-suicidal-cop-who-just-lost-his-wife.... yeah, this isn't Rush Hour. There's a lovely maturity to this film, and Martin's arc in this film was surprisingly effective, even on the rewatch. Gibson's range certainly helps sell his arc, and it helps that Glover's just as talented, playing off of Mel's manic energy amazingly well. For a movie that opens as bleak as this one does, by the end it's all smiles. The rest of the cast is fantastic too, Gary Busey especially.Behind the camera, we have Richard Donner, bringing his dependable craftsmanship to steer this project into the well-chiseled masterpiece we all know it as today.Unlike most modern films of this type, he usually holds back on the editing and more "interesting" camera angles, instead opting for a more rugged approach which really helps us be with the characters. We feel what they feel. His approach to the action sadly isn't as impressive (although he definitely gets better as the sequels go on, ending with some phenomenal set-pieces in LW4 that rank amongst the best of 90's action cinema), yet it's serviceable. This is one of the rare action films that puts character front and centre, so the action in the movie is still functional. It also helps that apart from an explosion here or there, it's mostly small and self-contained, so the geography isn't too convoluted.Michael Kamen's score is one of my favourites. I just love the soundscape he, Clapton and Sanborn created for this film (and franchise). It's funky, charming and sincere, but can also be gripping or heart-wrenching, should the need arise. Film music rarely gets better, and I wish people would bring back saxophone scores to the mainstream. I love me some good RCP action music, but listen to 'Beverly Hills Bust' and tell me you don't miss the 80s.One can't mention Lethal Weapon without, of course, mentioning Shane Black. His first produced screenplay. Unbelievable. Both Donner and Kamen said they probably wouldn't have signed on for the film had it not been for just how brilliant Black's script was. Every element of this film speaks to the core partnership between Riggs and Murtaugh, but that starts from the page. Roger only really begins to tolerate Martin around the 40 minute mark. Until then they're at each other's throats. By the end, however, it's like they're the oldest of pals, and it doesn't feel forced at all. While a lot of that credit should go to Donner, Glover, and Gibson, it's Black's phenomenal screenplay that's embedded in this relationship. His witty dialogue also helps everything feel just a tad lighter than one would expect, no matter how dark the film can sometimes go. Jeffrey Boam's contributions should also be noted, as he helped maintain that delicate tonal balance, injecting some much needed humour.I could go on and on about this film, but I won't. I've probably gone on for too long already, if I'm honest. All I can say is that Lethal Weapon is a fantastic film, one that's fit for all seasons.
