reviews.review_title: Occasionally drifts too much into pointless action territory, but overall a decent watch
reviews.content: "Lethal Weapon" is an American 110-minute film from 1987, so this one has its 20th anniversary this year. The writer is Shane Black and he was still very young back then, in his 20s, and this was his very first writing credit. Quite a way to start a career, isn't it. The director was Richard Donner and he is a bit on the opposite side. Close to the age of 90 today he was way into his 50s already when he made this one. The stars here are of course the two lead actors Gibson and Glover and the fact that Gibson is first credit says a lot already about his fame and popularity back then, even if he was still really young, but obviously very easy on the eye. Anyway, he plays a character who suffers terribly from the death of his significant other and his new partner (played by Glover) is a member of a big intact family. So things may become complicated when these two are instructed to work together as a team and they do and they get closer despite Gibson's character's suicidal tendencies. Together the two go up against a gang of drug smugglers who even kidnap Glover's character's daughter. Even if things were not always looking that way, there is a happy end eventually. This film was successful enough for 3 sequels to be made, all of these also starring the duo of lead actors we have in here.Black cop, white cop films were popular back then as for example also Nick Nolte and Eddie Murphy made a fairly famous film back then, two actually I think, even if the old cop was the white one there. By the way, Glover plays a character who is considerably older than he was back then. Anyway, the story is all a bit generic I must say, a bit too much focus on action and heartbreaking stuff without truly having the depth to pull it off. But it's the individual scenes that make this film somehow a success, like the one with the other suicidal guy early on. The second half felt relatively empty to me I must say, which is quite a shame as the initial premise and some of the plot developments did not look bad. Still in the end, I guess I will be a bit generous here and still give the film a positive rating and recommendation. Even with the villains being really boring for the most part and not half as memorable as they could have been with better writing and/or acting, Gibson is just too much of a cool cat to not enjoy this film, quite a while before his days as an Oscar-winning filmmaker himself. "Lethal Weapon" gets a thumbs-up from me, even if I must say that it did not get me curious about any of the sequels at all and I am pretty sure I will not check them out too soon.

I've seen all the 'Lethal Weapon' movies, and the original is still the best. While the others are great movies on their own, they seem to take too much of a comedic edge; I enjoyed this movie the most due to its action-packed sequences and mature theme. It definitely is a 'lethal' movie!

Mel Gibson needed a huge hit after three flops but that he found it as special forces turned LA cop Martin Riggs who lost his wife of eleven years, Victoria Lynn over a car wreck that may or may not had been an accident.Danny Glover is straight man and former Vietnam vet turned LAPD Sgt Roger Murtaugh who is near retirement and is sent to help to keep Riggs stabilize there.But with Riggs nothing is routine and that at first Murtaugh doesn't like it but then they get to know each other in stopping drug runner Gary Busey there as the fight at the end is classic.

reviews.review_title: "My luck's changing for the better every day. "
reviews.content: Let it be known that I have seen "Lethal Weapon" many, many times. I've seen it so many times that I can annoy those around me by uttering lines in unison with the characters on screen. Yet, no matter how many times I watch it, I am always baffled at how quickly the hour and forty five minutes pass as I reach the end, feeling satisfied, yet yearning for more. That's the kind of movie this is. It's got an insane amount of re-playability, which is due, I suppose, to the fact that the story works on so many levels. "Lethal Weapon" is equal parts action movie, drama, comedy and buddy flick, all wrapped up nice and neatly in a perfectly sized and perfectly portioned little action-movie burrito. The perfect action film? The best of it's kind? It just may be.One thing is for sure, and that is that Richard Donner is the unsung hero of 1980's cinema. If it weren't for the groundwork he laid in this movie, the action genre -- as it played out in it's aftermath -- wouldn't have been quite as memorable or exciting. That's because Donner -- along with screenwriter Shane Black -- raised the bar, raised expectations and quenched the thirst of audiences. To have an action movie with real characters that you really cared about was a rarity for the time. Those looking for an all-encompassing movie, something that can be both a tearjerker and a nail-biter, will find just that in "Lethal Weapon" any time they view it. And at a stunning twenty-one years of age, it has yet to be outdone and hardly feels dated.Mel Gibson stars alongside Danny Glover, and it's hard to imagine one without the other. Would this film be as good had different actors been cast? It's doubtful. While Gibson brings the psychotic, alcoholic Martin Riggs to life almost naturally, it's Glover's grounded performance of family-man Roger Murtaugh that makes up the heart of the film. More than just a buddy-cop flick, "Lethal Weapon" is also a story about redemption, as Murtaugh welcomes a troubled Riggs into his family circle. It's Murtaugh's friendship that helps Riggs patch up his wounds, as he mourns the tragic loss of his wife to a fatal car accident. Even though the movie is "too manly to admit so", at it's core, it's a touching story about the power of friendship and loyalty.There's also action. Lots and lots of action. Donner constantly bombards us with explosions, gun-play, car crashes and so on, and manages to keep it fresh throughout. Whereas in other films an abundance of action can get tiresome, such is not the case here. The action bits in this film will keep you on the edge of your seat and glued to the screen. The movie is just so well-crafted in that sense. I can safely say that I, personally, am never bored with this film, and it's a testament as to why "Lethal Weapon" is the best of it's kind. Well, unless, we're talking about "Lethal Weapon 2", but that's a different story.

This is an action-packed cop film pairing up Mel Gibson as Martin Riggs and Danny Glover as Roger Murtaugh on a mission to stop a gang of drug smugglers. From start to finish, it's a non-stop rush of humor and action, from the mismatched frustration coming from Riggs and Murtaugh to the gun-totting showdown in the desert.Gibson and Glover were a little overly-exerted in their acting at times, but they still had great chemistry together and delivered enough humor to keep the film engaging and to go along with the mad rush of all the action scenes. Riggs' suicidal tendencies and Murtaugh's too-old-for-this-s?it mantra became two intriguing focal points in the story and spell bad news for the bad guys and spell headaches for the cops' superiors - fun to watch. And, Gary Busey makes a butt-kicking villain! Overall, one of the better action films out there and one of the most iconic films of the '80s.Grade B+

reviews.review_title: Good, but not great...you had to wait until the sequel for that
reviews.content: LETHAL WEAPON is the film that kick-started the popular franchise and helped to usher in a new wave of buddy-buddy comedy cop movies. Watching it today, it does feel a little slow and dated in parts, with often laboured comedy and plotting that takes a long time to get anywhere. The reason the film still works lies in the casting of Mel Gibson and Danny Glover, two underrated actors who share an irresistible camaraderie.You know the score by now: Gibson's the crazy one (and never crazier than here), Glover the straight man, his by-the-book partner. The latter in particular is excellent, boosting the humour quotient of any given situation. The big stunt and explosion scenes are all well and good, although this doesn't really quality as an action flick until the last half hour, which has some good shoot-outs and a memorable torture-by-electrocution set-piece featuring DIE HARD's Al Leong. Gary Busey's larger-than-life baddie is the scene-stealer here, so it's a pity about all that doubling and dated choreography in the final scene.

Lethal Weapon (1987): Dir: Richard Donner / Cast: Mel Gibson, Danny Glover, Gary Busey, Mitchell Ryan, Tom Atkins: Energizing action comedy about our inner demons. Mel Gibson plays cop Martin Riggs who mourns his wife's passing at the hands of a drunk driving incident. He is depressed and goes into dangerous situations that put his life in jeopardy at the expense of himself. He is a human hand grenade set to go off even when a gun is waved in his face. Danny Glover plays his new partner. He is married and has a couple children and is completely safe until Riggs heightens his nerves. The two have great comedic chemistry and are involved in a plot that began with a hooker dropping to her death from way high up in an effective opening. Gary Busey plays a psychotic villain with crazed eyes and a knack for making hits, including one that sent Riggs through a window. Other characters are not so broad. Mitchell Ryan plays another villain and has nowhere near the scene stealing ability that Busey possesses. Tom Atkins is another waste as the father of one of the female victims. He is in trouble for doing a botch job and will become a target. Unfortunately we feel nothing here. Otherwise the screenplay is written with skill and detail with Richard Donner adding another gem to Superman: The Movie and The Omen. Here he delivers something lethal with a few chuckles added in. Score: 8 ½ / 10

reviews.review_title: This is an elite addition to the action genre that is an absolute must see
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon (1987) is a movie in my DVD collection that I recently rewatched on HBOMAX. The storyline follows an aging police officer preparing for retirement who gets a new partner, an ex-special operations military man with a screw loose. The two have to work to track down a drug king pin after his actions lead to a woman committing suicide. When the chase becomes personal the two new partners will have to rely on each other more than they'd like to...This movie is directed by Richard Donner (Superman) and stars Mel Gibson (Braveheart), Danny Glover (The Color Purple), Gary Busey (Gingerbread Man), Tom Atkins (The Fog) and Mitchell Ryan (Liar Liar).The storyline for this picture is very smart and does a great job of establishing the main characters, their backstories, their perspectives, mind sets and approach to life. The dialogue and circumstances are very smart and the primary storyline unfolds well around the fantastic characters. The comedic content is consistently well sprinkled in throughout the film. The casting is perfect and the chemistry between Glover and Gibson couldn't have been better. The action scenes and shootouts are brilliant and the final fight scene between Busey and Gibson is epic.Overall this is an elite addition to the action genre that is an absolute must see. I would score this a 9/10 and strongly recommend it.

In Los Angeles shortly before the Christmas holidays, a woman, stoned out of her mind, plummets from an apartment building and lands on a car. Two detectives get assigned to the case. One of them is a suicidal loner with a death wish; his name is Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson), still grieving over the death of his wife. The other is a family man who just turned 50; his name is Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover). They don't like each other and that's made clear since Murtaugh knows being partnered with a psycho cop is likely to get him killed. This is the world of "Lethal Weapon," the brain-child of a trifecta of competent filmmakers: director Richard Donner, producer Joel Silver, and screenwriter Shane Black. One thing is made clear that "Lethal Weapon" takes no prisoners and is all about action, and the relationship between two guys who don't like each other but if they're to survive what they are up against, they'll need one another's help. The dead woman happens to be the daughter of an old friend of Murtaugh's (Tom Atkins), who was himself involved with mercenaries from the Vietnam War that specialized in heroin smuggling. Riggs, Murtaugh, and the man are all products of that war. Their investigation eventually leads back to these mercenaries and their shadowy leader General McAllister (Mitch Ryan) and his peroxide-blonde chief henchman Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey). What it all leads up to is a no-holds-barred showdown in one of the most action-packed finales I've ever seen. "Lethal Weapon" was of course followed by three sequels, each one less dark in tone but with more emphasis on blockbuster action, and are indeed an essential for any true action fan's library. The first "Lethal Weapon" is as tense as they come. It's fast, it's thrilling, and it's lethal.10/10

It's a film that delivers exactly what you are looking for and that can never be a bad thing. The investigation to the crime is a bit basic and by the book, but the characters development is what makes this so special. We really like these two guys. They are not perfect but they are relatable as ****. This was super influential and there are reasons for that.I'm too old for this s***

My parents seen these films long ago back when they were on VHS & they mentioned how good these films were so I got the boxset for Christmas & watched this one first! I'd have say after many watches, it's a pretty damn good film!The film follows 2 newly paired Police Officer who are complete opposites of one another. Riggs is a Crazy, Mad Police Officer who lost his wife & has suicidal tendencies so he doesn't care whether he lives or dies, & Murtaugh, is a soon-to-be-retired Police Officer who is more sensible & careful when it comes to his Police work. But despite their differences & barriers, the 2 must work together to catch a gang of ruthless drug smugglers.I found the film to be pretty good! It mixes action, comedy & sadness well! There's plenty of funny one liners, action packed & has a decent enough story-line! The characters of Riggs & Murtaugh are great! The banter between them is pretty good & adds to the films crazyness! Much like with Hobbs & Shaw from the Fast & Furious films, their differences & banter work well & are a staple in the 4 films! The villain Joshua, was also pretty good as well & had a good level of menace & ruthlessness about him!Overall, it's a really good action buddy-cop film of the 80's!8/10.

reviews.review_title: One of the best action-thrillers of the 80's.
reviews.content: When a young woman, who committed suicide. Which she jumped from her high-rise building. When a police detective by the name of Roger Mirtaugh (Danny Glover) finds out that the victim has a father (Tom Atkins), he knew from his Vietnam days. But Roger finds out that the victim was drugged and poisoned, which she's was going to die anyway. Since Roger's is on the cast but he's forced to team with an suicidal cop (Oscar-Winner:Mel Gibson) on the edge. Which the partners begins an unlikely friendship. When sadistic bad guys (Gary Busey and Mitchell Ryan), who are involved with the victim's death doesn't want the lead detective in their way.Directed by Richard Donner (The Goonies, Ladyhawke, Radio Flyer) made an outstanding action-thriller with sharp performances by Gibson and Glover makes this familiar if somewhat original film works.The original DVD has an fine anamorphic Widescreen (1.75:1) transfer (also in Pan & Scan) with an good digitally remastered-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. Fans of the action genre will have a great time with this one. Director's Cut runs 117 minutes. Written by Shane Black (Kiss Kiss Bang Bang, The Last Boy Scout, The Long Kiss Goodnight). (****/*****).

reviews.review_title: One action movie that lives up to its title.
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon may be another one of those buddy-cop action pictures. This is one of them. You want action? You got action. And Lethal Weapon has the action. Lethal Weapon stars Danny Glover and Mel Gibson as Los Angeles detectives who are partner up to solve the case. They may hate, but that doesn't make the movie bad because this was just the beginning. The chemistry between Glover and Gibson are outstanding. The action sequences are thrilling and compelling. Writer Shane Black introduce some new characters that we seen before, but not in a steady action picture between there are lines of dialog that present humor, even between Glover and Gibson. The movie was directed by Richard Donner, who also made the 1976 horror classic, The Omen and the superhero 1978 picture, Superman. This time, his direction works. Here, a steady action picture like Lethal Weapon are why action movies back in the 1980's were exciting and thrilling like Die Hard. These action movies never have the computer special effects or CGI. If haven't seen Lethal Weapon, I will recommend the movie to those who never seen it before. ★★★★ 4 stars.

'Lethal Weapon' is a movie that knows what it is to be a buddy movie and a hard police movie at the same time. Comedy and action come together in the perfect way. In a way it is your typical buddy movie. An older and wiser black cop and a younger white cop, living on the edge, team up. The black cop is personally involved in the case they handle, the white cop is a little suicidal.Where most movies like this work to hard on the relationship between the two and therefore force most of the jokes, 'Lethal Weapon' starts by being a good action movie and from there it thinks further. The movie is funny because the characters simply do what you would expect them to do and because personalities collide it gets funny. Not that it is very different in other movies like this, but in those movies the characters have some strange habits to make it funny. Here the characters feel more real.The black cop is Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover), the white cop Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson). Together they have to solve a case that involves drugs, an old Vietnam friend of Murtaugh and a villain played by Gary Busey. The screenplay is not very complicated, more like a simple police story, but it has some nice touches. We know Gibson can not die in the first couple of minutes of the movie, but when he holds that gun to his own head we really feel the fear he must have. This movie is one of the reasons he is the star he is today, and you understand why. Glover is nice as well, and that he and Gibson, together with director Richard Donner, made three other Lethal Weapon' movies together is no surprise. They are one of the best teams I have seen, for the action and for the comedy.

reviews.review_title: 'Lethal Weapon' is a classic buddy cop flick
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon begins with a woman jumping to her death from a roof. We then are introduced to Officer Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and family. His wife informs him that a buddy of his that he fought alongside in Vietnam is trying to reach him. When the audience is introduced to Officer Riggs (Mel Gibson) he is contemplating suicide. What ensues after is a rollercoaster ride of comedy and action and a great story. Lethal Weapon is the kind of movie that keeps you on the edge of your seat and you are always rooting for these two cops who are thrown together and forced to be partners but then help each other in the end. The film may have some cliches but it is well worth the view, and let's be honest, anything with Gary Busey as the villain is worth seeing.

Written by Shane Black who was only 25 years old when the movie was made. Veteran director Richard Donner hit the right notes when it came to hard edged action balanced by some comedy.Donner very much hit the wave laid out in 48 Hours and redefined the mismatched buddy cop action movies for the 1980s. He even added some subtle political messages. Check out those anti apartheid stickers in the Murtaugh household.Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) is an ex special forces veteran who now looks like a crazy burnt out cop. Since the death of his wife, Riggs has had suicidal thoughts.Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) is a veteran cop who has just celebrated his 50th birthday. Murtagh is a family man who just knows he's too old for this sugar when he is partnered up with Riggs.When the daughter of Murtaugh's Vietnam war buddy takes some tainted drugs and throws herself off her high rise apartment.Both Riggs and Murtaugh find themselves in a drugs conspiracy that began during the Vietnam war. Their investigations quickly gets personal as Murtaugh needs to save his daughter.Lethal Weapon is very much a stripped down action picture. Donner adds layers with characterisation. Murtaugh with is close knit family, his growing children, his wife's bad cooking and looking forward to retirement.Riggs with his loneliness and nothing much to look forward to apart from just being a cop. Both Gibson and Glover establish a warm rapport rather quickly.The film is enhanced by Gary Busey's bad guy. A Vietnam vet who is the flip side of Riggs. Lethal Weapon was a bit of a comeback for Busey who had been academy award nominated a decade earlier but his film career quickly hit the doldrums.

reviews.review_title: "You ever met anybody that you didn't kill?"
reviews.content: Every once in a while I don't mind kicking back, suspending disbelief, and enjoying a mindless action film like "Lethal Weapon". You have to realize of course, that no human being can withstand the kind of punishment a guy like Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) endures and then get up the next day feeling good as new. For the sake of these action flicks you just have to go with it, and as long as the story is OK, you'll be fine.I liked the camaraderie that developed between the suicidal Riggs and his newly assigned partner Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover). It evolved over the course of the story with each man earning the respect and gratitude of the other after several life defying situations. If you're paying attention though, a few questions will pop up. Like when Riggs tells Roger that the guy who shot at him on the street was the same guy who tried to kill him from the helicopter. Considering the distance involved, there's no way Riggs could have seen Joshua (Gary Busey) well enough to be able to identify him on the chopper.Then there's the scene in the desert when Riggs takes up a position to watch Roger's back as he makes contact with The General's (Mitchell Ryan) men. Except for some scrub ground cover, what would have prevented Riggs from seeing The General sneak up on him? If you think about it too much, some of the movie's tension just falls away in the clear light of day.I'll say this for Mel Gibson though, that scene when he was contemplating suicide showed a remarkable range in the man's talent as an actor. Glover's character wasn't called on to get that emotional, but he managed to deliver his role with some finesse as well. As a team, they're an effective pair once all the trouble goes down, with an attitude well reflected by that tattoo on Riggs' arm that says 'Never Quit'.

reviews.review_title: First installment of the Lethal Weapon series is also the best.
reviews.content:
I saw Lethal Weapon 4 almost 3 years ago, a free DVD when I bought my player. Now, I've gotten around to seeing the initial one, which brought together Danny Glover playing a cop just turning 50, getting a new partner, played by Mel Gibson, who had recently lost his wife in a car accident and was considered "crazy" by the other cops who knew him. I haven't seen all of Mel Gibson's roles, but I have seen quite a few of them and I believe his role as Martin in this film might be his best ever. The DVD picture is only average as DVDs go, but it has a 5.1 surround sound which is quite good for a film that was not originally released in surround sound.
some SPOILERS FOLLOW, please don't read further unless you have seen the movie.The film opens with a girl apparently high on drugs, half-naked, dreamily dives off the high balcony onto the roof of a car below. Her death becomes the mystery to be solved, intertwined with a large drug operation her father is involved in and run my ex-military covert operatives. Gibson's character is introduced at a sniper shooting, he was going to walk off until he saw a wounded child, then went into the open, yelled at the sniper, then pumped about 30 rounds into him from his automatic pistol. He had been a top marksman in the military.Glover's character is introduced as part of his family, he is opposite Gibson's, a by-the-book type of guy. Often making the reference, "I'm too old for this $hit." The unlikely pair make a good team, get the bad guys. In a great last scene fight, reportedly choreographed and filmed over four dusk to dawn days, Gibson's character takes out Busey's, both of them former special forces combat experts.Other highlights - Gibson talks to a jumper, offers a cig, handcuffs them togther, "If you jump now, you will kill me, and that's murder, and murder of a cop, at that."  Then they jump, into an inflated mat.  The meeting bad guys in the dry lake bed, Gibson picking off several of them with his sniper rifle. Walking up to the prostitute's house, it explodes.  Good action film, good "buddy" movie.

A solid action movie staring the insanely handsome 80s Mel Gibson and old faithful Danny Glover. The acting was good from the whole cast, the characters well developed and the action on point. Glover and Gibson had good banter playing opposite style police officers. The storyline was a bit sketchy on the actual detective work, but at least it doesn't try to get too complicated. Overall a solid cop action movie.

"Lethal Weapon" is just plain bad -- a dismal movie. Don't waste your time watching this one. Pass, you aren't missing anything. If you want to see a good movie of this sort, I would recommend "Above the Law" with Steven Seagal. "Lethal Weapon" just doesn't work on so many levels. I'm sorry I bought the set of 4, now I have to decide if I should risk any more time watching the sequels. I saw the sequels years ago and I thought they were average, but I never saw the first one until now, and it was bad. I had a feeling I would not like it.So many problems: it is too dark, too unrealistic, bad action scenes, hardly any normal women in the entire film (just one wife and several prostitutes which are treated poorly), the hero is a degenerate (not because of his fragile mental state which is nothing to mock, but because he is portrayed as interested in underage girls instead of ones near his own age), the plot is nonsensical (cops are invited over without a warrant then the suspect starts shooting at them; no backup cops ever around; that ending fight - so stupid), the Christmas motif and blasphemy is unwarranted -- the entire film is like some psychological trick to associate Christmas and Christ with the awful trash encompassed in this film. I'm not sure how this film got the great reputation it has or had. In summary, skip this one, 3/10 stars (and that may be generous).

reviews.review_title: An Police Action movie at its finest
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon is an all time classic action film and a pioneer in the buddy cop genre. A movie that can't age and will never age. It kept me very entertained and I enjoyed it.

Close to retirement, Detective Sergeant Roger Murtaugh is a bit disturbed to find he's breaking in a new partner. Even more so when it turns out to be fellow Detective Martin Riggs, who since the death of his wife has scant regard for life, his own or those around him.Light on plot and character development, Lethal Weapon none the less shines bright as a beacon of how a buddy buddy action film should be done. Roughly an hour and forty five minutes of quips, action, villainy, heroics and cross generational/cultural divides. All what else is needed is a star duo with buoyant chemistry - thankfully Richard Donner's movie has it by the clip load.Mel Gibson is Riggs, a trigger happy suspected loony on the ragged edge, wonderfully playing off of Danny Glover's (superb) "too old for this nonsense" sage old copper. Riggs is a hard dude who quickly became a cinematic hero to many, an unstoppable force with a quip on the tongue and a glint in his eye, to which Gibson is terrific and perfectly cast.Gary Busey's "psycho's are us" henchman flits in and out the picture with gleeful nastiness and Shane Black's script crackles as the super stunt work starts to take a hold. Chief villain Mitchell Ryan as The General is almost a bystander though, and there's the odd piece of careless editing, but really Lethal Weapon has a winning formula that the box office punters promptly lapped up.Three sequels, all of which are of differing quality, would follow it, but this is a template movie for the genre and worthy of nostalgic revisits any time of day. 8/10

reviews.review_title: Overdone 80's cop thriller redeemed by Gibson and Glover
reviews.content: Released in 1987, "Lethal Weapon" stars Mel Gibson as the suicidal new partner of a detective played by Danny Glover. When a beautiful young woman is found murdered it leads to a radical heroin-smuggling ring whose head honchos are played by Mitchell Ryan and Gary Busey.Everything about this movie screams mid-80s, like the music and the haircuts; it's also annoyingly comic booky, melodramatic and over-the-top. Once you catch a grip, though, it wins you over with the blossoming buddy-relationship of the two stars, not to mention the consistent thrills and scenic S. Cal. locations.In case you didn't know, the half-nude girl at the beginning is none other than Jackie Swanson, Kelly from Cheers. The film runs 117 minutes and was shot in the Los Angeles area, e.g. Palos Verdes, and the Mojave Desert. GRADE: B-
I heard it was great, but all I noticed was the generic storyline and not much or interesing action. I could notice the great characters, but that's about it.

My Take: While somewhat dated in spots, this is an enjoyable caper comedy with some thrilling action and well-developed characters. LETHAL WEAPON still remains one of the classic 80's action pictures. But it ain't a classic for non-stop action ala DIE HARD and RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK. The film is memorable heavily for the partnership between the two leads, Mel Gibson as Martin Riggs and Danny Glover as Roger Murtaugh. Gibson is the suicidal type, Glover is the nice family guy type. For just the bond between and the sparing of these two characters, LETHAL WEAPON had me and never lost me.The main plot concerns the odd couple cop partners battle against drug lords. But the real plot mainly concerns how these two characters go together. The action scenes, including two car chase with one against a helicopter, come later during the film. But director Richard Donner doesn't keep us waiting. He makes his actors fun to watch to make sure the audiences stuck to them till the end. The trick works, and these two leads are very fun to watch.Gibson is very lively as Riggs, a crazy guy ready to explode. He's wacky and witty, yet darn serious and just plain nuts at the same time. Glover is his counterpart, and he's just as good to watch. It's nice to see a cop movie where the cop's family plays some essence in the story. What Glover's character cares about (his family), we care about. Then there are the bad guys, which like all great villains are real meanies. The villain played by Gary Busey (the nearly unstoppable Mr. Joshua) is probably the best of the other villains in the film played by Mitch Ryan and others.Overall, it's not as relentlessly busy as DIE HARD or the INDIANA JONES movies. But it's the closest one where we'll get to an action movie with well-developed characters.Rating: **** out of 5.

Mel Gibson(Riggs) & Danny Glover(Murtaugh) made a memorable team in director Richard Donner's fun, action packed adventure as two mismatched cops(one straight-laced family man, the other rogue & suicidal) try to bring down brutal drug dealers after a friend of theirs is murdered.Lots of memorable action, especially an extended fight climax at night, really make this film stand out, though the tone and violence get serious at times, which balances things out nicely. Effective character development, as both Gibson & Glover shine; though film does stretch credibility at times, it never goes off the rails.Big hit that spawned multiple sequels and imitators.

Given that police detectives often work in pairs, it is surprising how long it took the film industry to come up with the "buddy cop" movie. "In the Heat of the Night" is a rare example from the sixties, but most of the "tough cop" dramas from that decade and from the seventies were about loners who preferred to work alone. Even when the likes of Clint Eastwood's Dirty Harry were paired with another detective, the focus was very much on the title character with his partner playing a minor role. "48 Hours" is sometimes classed as a "buddy cop" film, but in fact Nick Nolte's detective was teamed not with another police officer but with a convict temporarily released from jail.The "buddy cop" genre probably came of age with the "Lethal Weapon" series, of which this is the first. Two LAPD detectives, Roger Murtaugh and Martin Riggs, are assigned to investigate the apparent suicide of a young woman named Amanda Hunsaker, who turns out to be the daughter of one of Murtaugh's old buddies from the Vietnam War. Upon investigation it becomes clear that her death was in fact murder and that those responsible are a ruthless gang of drug dealers, all themselves Vietnam veterans. Amanda was killed because her banker father Michael, who acted as the gang's money-launderer, was threatening to alert the police to the scheme.What lifts "Lethal Weapon" above the average is not its plot or its action sequences, which are all very much standard shoot-e-mail-up stuff, but the characterisation of the two main roles. A common feature of "buddy cop" films is that the two partners are normally very different in character. They initially start off disliking one another, but this dislike eventually turns to mutual respect, even friendship. As in "In the Heat of the Night" one of the two is black, the other white. In the earlier film, which used the conventions of the police thriller to explore the problem of racism in American society, this racial difference is the most important element in the film; here it does not really matter, something which shows how America had changed in the twenty years between 1967 and 1987. The film would still be much the same if Riggs were black and Murtaugh white, or if both were of the same race. The important differences are not of race but of temperament.Murtaugh, as played by Danny Glover, is the older of the two, having recently celebrated his 50th birthday. He is also the more stable, a happily married family man. Mel Gibson's Riggs, by contrast, is depressed and suicidal following the death of his wife in a car crash. Murtaugh wants to play everything by the book, whereas Riggs prefers more uncompromising methods of law enforcement. He was originally attached to the drugs squad, but was transferred to homicide by his superiors who are weary of his violent behaviour. Riggs has some similarities with Harry Callahan, another widower who lost his wife to a car accident; the main difference is that the unpredictable Riggs lacks Harry's icy self-control.Along with "Die Hard", made the following year, "Lethal Weapon" launched a "second generation" of tough cop movies. (Bruce Willis, who plays John McClane in the "Die Hard" series, was originally considered for the role of Riggs). Like most tough cop films (the original "Dirty Harry" perhaps being an exception), it does not ask any very deep questions, but does at least provide some good entertainment with some exciting action sequences. 6/10

'Lethal Weapon (1987)' is the definitive 'buddy cop' movie. The film is a sort of extended set-up for its follow-ups, bringing its iconic duo together in preparation for the continuing adventures of Riggs and Murtaugh, but it still works as a stand-alone experience. It's a little bit unfocused, with most of its main plot being squished into its final act in favour of sequential set-pieces intended on deepening the dynamic between its leads. Indeed, that's what the narrative is really about: the protagonists' relationship. It's a good thing, then, that it's one of the best realised relationships ever put to film, evolving in a natural and empathetic way until it reaches its inevitable plateau just before the credits roll. Both Gibson and Glover are great, delivering performances much more nuanced than you might expect. Gibson's wild-eyed fury is hard to beat, while Glover's under-the-surface stress practically seeps out of him. Much of the affair is dedicated to Riggs' severe depression, which is dealt with more sensitively than you'd anticipate from an 80s action movie (even if its resolution is rather rushed). The picture is pretty good in terms of representation, too; it has a diverse cast and practically no out-dated, race-related humour. It's all just good fun, to be honest. Of course, it has some dark moments and is, generally, more serious than any of its follow-ups. It balances its comedy with its drama well, though, and delivers exactly what you want. Ultimately, that's what matters. It may be messy, with a fairly weak main plot, but it's very entertaining. Its action, which I haven't even mentioned yet, is fantastic. Richard Donner and his second unit team do an excellent job. From its delightfully practical car wrecks to its blank-firing, squib-triggering shoot-outs, it's all edge-of-your-seat, smile-inducing stuff. Its weakest moment is probably an odd, protracted fight scene that may just be the origin of unintelligible shaky cam. Still, even this soon becomes enjoyable and it doesn't prevent the piece from going out on a good note. In the end, this really is essential viewing for fans of action cinema. 8/10

reviews.review_title: A buddy cop movie that enjoys a cast so perfect that its alchemy literally explodes on the screen
reviews.content: This is the excellent idea of denouncing the crimes of the mafia and narco-traffickers of "Air America", through the evil actions of its Los Angeles unit, more than a decade after the end of the Anglo-American imperialist holocaust in Southeast Asia. In a subtle way, under the disguise of a buddy cop movie that enjoys a cast so perfect that its alchemy literally explodes on the screen! In this first episode in 1987, and then in three other installments, respectively in 1989, 1992 and 1998, to form the Lethal Weapon quadrilogy. Maybe a pentalogy, since both Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are not only interested but also seem more and more motivated by the idea of teaming up again as Martin Riggs and Roger Murtaugh on the big screen, more than 20 years after their last "lethal" encounter. They have been publicly teasing it since 2017. Screenplay (Shane Black), directing (Richard Donner), soundtrack (Michael Kamen) and editing are just as smart and effective and complete this classic movie of its generation.

reviews.review_title: Even in 2037, the film will not be too old for Cinema ...
reviews.content: It's hard to believe that Roger Murtaugh and Martin Riggs started driving up together 25 years ago, and I'm not expressing nostalgia here, only complimenting the timeless appeal of a film that stood the test of time. Because, as much as it carries the visible mark of the 80's, there's a level of freshness and modernity that elevates "Lethal Weapon" above any of todays productions. And not just as a classic cop/thriller, "Lethal Weapon" will forever be regarded as the film to that epitomizes the 'buddy-movie'.Generally, this sub-genre's main premise relies on the coexistence of two polar opposite personalities within a unity of space, time and plot, and whatever happens, the friendship or growing complicity between the two leads remains the plot's center of gravity. While not a golden rule, it's assumed that the more different they are, the funnier get the interactions, and the closer they are, the more serious it gets. I guess that a good buddy-movie should find the correct balance between "The Odd Couple" and "The Defiant Ones". And "Lethal Weapon" works like a school case, the relationship between Danny Glover and Mel Gibson could serve as the best reference for any buddy movie, regardless of the genre, the tone or the style.Richard Donner, who directed"Superman" and "The Goonies" already proved to be capable of making action films where characters were more than tools to build a story. In "Lethal Weapon", he surpasses himself by providing two remarkable examples of great characterizations. Indeed, instead of taking for granted the necessity of having two different cops and throwing it at our faces –for instance, after a stereotypical set-up where one of them loses his partner- he takes time to present the two leads. And when they meet, they're familiar enough to us, to make us care for them equally, and that's a key element: no one serves as a foil to the other, no lead and sidekick, Glover and Gibson are complementary to the core. And that's because they have more in common than they think and each one has a potential to fill the other's life-gap."Lethal Weapon" opens with Danny Glover as a man who just turned 50, the father or three kids, one beautiful daughter, and like every man his age, he's concerned by his gray facial hair, can't find the car keys or can't tell his wife what he thinks of her cooking. His motto: "I'm to old for this ----"summarizes the attitude that govern 95% of his life. And Mel Gibson plays a relatively young, long-haired, sharpshooter who became suicidal after his wife's death. Three key scenes sum up his 'pathos', he confronts a nervous sniper without taking any protection, he challenges a thug who took him as a hostage, and in one of the most emotionally engaging scenes, he tries to kill himself by pointing a gun in many spots in his face before giving up, his face covered of tears. By the way, the level of emotion Mel Gibson manages to pull in these 3 minutes is Oscar-worthy.Basically, Roger Murtaugh is in a routinely logic while Martin Riggs is in a dead-end, one is exceptionally ordinary; another is so tormented no one wants to work with him. It's astonishing how never, and I mean, never in the film, they seem stereotypical. As I described, when they start working together, we identify to each one of them, and try to figure how they can complete each other. Yet they do, because on their own, they're two lonely men, one absorbed by his family life, and another stuck to the only thing that keeps him for blowing his brain off: his job. Riggs is good and he knows it, is Murtaugh as good? Well, he lasted long enough without getting a bullet, or a scratch, and he contemplates retirement like Riggs suicide. Both are in a sort of transitional time of their life, in a tunnel where the most needful element to enlighten their lives is a buddy.And that's what makes the film so great, while we enjoy the countless action scenes and the investigation, we also have a good time watching them having some beer, commenting on the wife's food or the crush the cute daughter has on Riggs. Riggs' wisecracking comments and Murtaugh's excitability are the spices that provide the film (and the sequels) its entire savor. Of course, I'm not making "Lethal Weapon" sound like a character study but granted it's a great action/cop thriller with some heart-pounding sequences, there's more to it definitely, something in the same vein, than "Die Hard" that renewed the action genre. I guess the audience needed less superheroes or modern lone rider's type and needed to identify with the characters before getting immersed in their universe and caring for them not just because they're labeled as heroes.It's not surprising that "Lehtal Weapon" and "Die Hard" take place in L.A. during Christmas, the context doesn't play as a pivotal role in "Lethal Weapon but it does provide this natural ordinary setting that, by contrast, make the action scenes more challenging. Naturally, the impact and entertaining value of an action film also relies on the presence of a great villain. "Lethal Weapon" manages to do so with the unforgettable third pillar of the film, Gary Busey as 'Mr. Joshua', although he doesn't have the same sophistication than Hans Gruber, he's genuinely scary and impressive enough to be a perfect match for Riggs and Murtaugh.What else to say about "Lethal Weapon"? Well, it created the most endearing cinematic duo of the recent years, and although the film slides sometimes into some stereotypes, it still remains one of the greatest of its genre, with a genuine human quality. And I'm sure that even in 2037, the film will never be too old for Cinema.

reviews.review_title: Bizzaro World Tubbs and Middle-age Crockett
reviews.content:
Shane Black wrote a very tight screenplay, that was surprisingly solid for an 80's action vehicle, and that, for the most part, was well written, wonderfully pulpy. Unfortunately that was not enough to elevate it above its lot. It's literally 'Miami Vice' in L.A., or more because of Richard Donner's standard direction, a high-end "To Live and Die in L.A.". Hell, there's even a helicopter above the ocean scene that heavily reminded me of the opening credits to Magnum P.I. Black has since proven himself to be a more visually competent and exciting director than Donner, who is and has always been a mediocrity. One can only wonder what Black would've done with it...
Shane Black would revisit a similar theme nearly 30 years later with the much better looking, visually engaging, better acted, more cleverly written and arrestingly directed The Nice Guys, which was a terrific ride from start to finish. The much more droll 'Kiss Kiss Bang Bang', with Robert Downey, Jr. and Val Kilmer, was also more enjoyable than this dry-rub precursor, where the script was more interesting than the movie - kinda like watching a lackluster Hollywood adaptation of a mildly enjoyable pulp novel. What had potential on page ended up just another plaything to throw to the boys to play with.

The cinematography was pretty good, and so were the gunfire and explosions. I'm sure there are some people who consider Mel Gibson's acting a little over the top when Martin is behaving in an unhinged manner, and Danny Glover's acting when Roger is angry, which is understandable. Personally, I don't have a problem with it. There were other moments and things that were a little over the top as well, which I don't have a problem with, either. And I really liked the development and progression of what started out as an annoyance on Roger's part towards Martin to what ended up being a unity of camaraderie between both of them by the end of the movie. Good movie.

Considered by many to be the most influential of all buddy cop actioners, Lethal Weapon is a fast, energetic & unrelenting example of its genre that gets the formula just right, and is driven by the near-perfect chemistry between its two leads to deliver a powder keg of an entertainer. One of the most enjoyable & satisfying delights to come out during the 1980s, it still retains its potency & old-school charm.Written by Shane Black & directed by Richard Donner (The Omen), the premise is established right away & character introductions are real quick and once the two conflicting personalities are together on screen, the film never decelerates from thereon. Donner balances elements of drama & action with finesse but it is the conflict, contrast & banter between the two cops that makes the journey so fun & compelling.Adding more fuel to fire is the gripping narrative with hardly any fat on it, sudden outbursts of gunfire & explosions keeping the momentum alive, action set pieces exuding an unabashedly raw appeal, and grungy camerawork & jazzy soundtrack adding flavours of their own. But it is Danny Glover & Mel Gibson who stand out with their individual inputs and shine even brighter as a duo, each helping the other to put their best foot forward.Overall, Lethal Weapon is expertly directed, smartly scripted & brilliantly acted, and continues to be one of the finest offerings of its genre. Its flow & pacing is smooth throughout. There is as much heart as there is humour. And the way our diametrically opposite protagonists help each other fill the void in their lives, plus Glover & Gibson rendering of all that with precision on screen, makes the ride all the more fulfilling. In short, Lethal Weapon still packs a wallop.

reviews.review_title: Truly one of the best Action Films!
reviews.content: Nothing satisfies a movie watcher like a great Buddy Cop Movie.  Lethal Weapon is the pinnacle of Cop movies.  It's the be all and end all.  It truly is an outstanding action/suspense/thriller movie.  The thing about this movie that really blows me away is how many different things it covers. It's NOT just a blow things up action movie, the characters are very deep, and their stories are interesting, the plot is excellent.  On top of the action you have incredible comedy.  One liners, and catch phrases that are just brilliantly written.  Of course there are always things that can be critisized about every movie.  I don't suppose that two cops could truly run around a city shooting and killing every bad guy they come across...or a cop could dive off a building with a suicidal man and not get fired, or arrested himself.  But who cares...it's fun.  It's not meant to be reality or a cop training video (unless you're the LAPD...gratuitous low blow)  Gary Busey is of course great as the killer mercenary, and the big bad boss drug dealer (that guy from Dharma and Greg) played the perfect bad guy.  This movie doesn't leave much for improvement but it does leave you begging for more Riggs and Murtaugh.  Mel Gibson is perfect.  Martin Riggs had to be one of the greatest movie characters of all times.  It's astonishing how much feeling they put into Riggs who is a man who has lost his wife in a car accident and is just begging for death to take him.  He's suicidal and on the edge and it makes him look psycotic.  He is partnered with Lt. Murtaugh, played by Danny Glover.  A cop who is nearing retirement, who plays by the rules and has a perfect family life.  Together they make the perfect team. Gibson and Glover have the ideal chemistry and their characters, completely different, help each other in every way.  Murtaugh learns a lesson in letting loose and not being quite so uptight and Riggs learns to love life and finds himself with a surrogate family in the form of the Murtaughs.  The movie spends so much time introducing us into the lives of these two men...how different they are, and how much they needed each other.  Together they find themselves the perfect team to taking out a ruthless drug operation.  The action comes in the ending scenes, the last 45 minutes has to be one of the perfectly filmed action sequences in movie history.  Mel Gibson battling it out with Gary Busey, hand to hand, under the spouting water of a decapitated Fire Hydrant is brilliant and heart stopping.  The fight scenes were flawless.  I give this movie a perfect score making it one of my favorite movies.  Perhaps it's not the perfect movie but for me and anyone else who sees it...it will do the job for entertainment. 10/10 **********!!!!!

reviews.review_title: Gibson and Glover chemistry the best since Sundance
reviews.content: One of the most compelling and entertaining movies to come out of Eighties Hollywood was Lethal Weapon. It cemented the superstar status of Mel Gibson - already essential casting following the success of Mad Max, and also turned Danny Glover into a household name. But crucially, the script - despite being a typical 80s action thriller that stretches credibility to its most unlikely point - actually works because of the mesmerising chemistry between Gibson and Glover. The two bounce off each other and the dialogue sizzles in between the breathtaking action sequences. It's the best on screen partnership since Newman and Redford in Butch Cassidy, and rarely can two characters have been so neon-lit as being 'the good guys'. The set pieces are tremendous - from Gibson's attempts to bring down a suicidal man from the top of a tower block to his hilarious yet unmissable brush with a gang of drug dealers early on, this top the buddy-movie genre onto another level. Of course the movie spawned another 3 sequels and became one of the most recognisable franchises in modern Hollywood. But this is entertainment at its very best, and Gibson has rarely been better. His psychotic, crazed cop blessed with martial art and sharpshooting skills most of his colleagues don't have made him the perfect rampaging crusader and his star status was assured after this.

It's quite simply one of the greatest buddy cop films of all time. Gibson and Glover give great performances and show terrific chemistry on screen together. The movie starts out slow, but once the two of them finally pair up, its gold until the end.It's a high octane thrill ride throughout, and the fun part is the back and forth between the leads. I really like that they give a solid back story for both rather than just have them be together in the first few scenes. It's nice when you become invested in the characters when you know why they feel emotionally a certain way. Gibson's character is suicidal and borderline crazy, and Glover is a good family man who just past the mid-century mark. I really like the action scenes, and even in 2014 they pretty much hold up. Now it obviously does have the typical 80's cheesy feel at some parts. But it doesn't diminish the fact that the movie has some depth to it, and isn't just a mindless action thriller.With that said I would have like to see more of the story to the villain side of things. 2 hours is a good length for the film but possibly remove the first few scenes of Gibson just in his trailer and instead give us scenes with Busey. I know the bad guys are involved with drugs but I wanted to get to know those characters more. There are also some parts that seemed a little bit too coincidental, but it is a Hollywood movie. And some parts weren't realistic, I mean the final fight with Gibson and Busey? Would have never been allowed in real life.Still a good film with one of the best cop duos ever captured on screen. Now to watch the sequels...8.4/10

Some 80s action movies lose their charm with time but some only get better. Lethal Weapon is one that really wasn't my favorite when I was younger but now it gets better every time I see it.I don't know if this is the first "buddy cop" movie but it might be the most well known, the first that comes to mind (when thinking of action films with two cops who have different personalities and that causes comedic moments.) The thing with this movie is that even though it has action and comedy, it also has some darker and emotional aspects which is probably why it has grown on me.The cast is great with Danny Glover as an older family man cop, and Mel Gibson as the crazy cop who lives dangerously and is about to lose his mind. The highlight is Gibson who gives some of his best ever performance, he's on fire here. Also the story and directing work well so that there is no dull moment.

There are two great action movies series that begins in the 1980's. They are Die Hard and of course, Lethal Weapon. It's hard to tell which series is better. I like them both a lot. This movie starts the tone for three more movies.Martin Riggs and Roger Murtaugh are two different people. Riggs is a suicidal freak who likes to kill everyone and Murtaugh is a middle-aged cop who just wants peace and happiness. They are to be partners. Together, they must bust a big time drug industry.The acting is great. Along with the action, the actors added plenty of comedy especially with Mel Gibson who was brilliant. Danny Glover also did a great job.For action movie freaks, there are tons of action scenes. Things get blown up, there are fights, etc. They will not be disappointed.Overall, this is a great, great movie. I rate this film 10/10.

It's OK for a film of this genre...have not seen any of the sequels or prequels ( if any), but I hope they are better than this. Two lunatic cops are paired together. One, Glover, who appears sane ( but loses it frequently) has a house, kids, and a wife who needs to meet Betty Crocker or Chef Boy-Yar-Dee. The other makes no pretense at sanity (Gibson)...declared dangerous by a department shrink...other cops refuse to work with him out of fear. Sounds like a typical strike force cop if you grew up in the ghetto. Not exactly a match made in heaven, and not quite as satisfying as Laurel and Hardy, they bumble their way through a series of events where there is a lot of action, a lot of gunfire, and a lot of blood. But when the daughter of an old friend of Glover's winds up dead and the death is ruled as a homicide instead of a suicide, the two bumblers find themselves on the trail of a vicious drug and crime ring. For those who thrive on action in films and violence, this one is right up your alley. But it is not without its flaws. There is one scene where a man is threatening suicide by jumping from a tall building. Gibson apprehends him and they both jump into free-fall...but what the director holds out on is...they jump into an air-bag cushion that is already in place, not mentioned, and not visible to viewers until they fall into it. A 'cheap shot' scene like this one took away any credibility this film might have had for me...and holding out on that was an insult to the intelligence of the viewer. I grudgingly watched the rest after that, but that made me lose respect for the integrity of the film...or the lack of it. Watch it if you want, but be prepared for the ridiculous.

These films are staples of my generation, it seems hardly a Sunday night would go by without one of them showing up on TV. But upon revisiting them over the past few days, I was surprised to discover that my impression of them was for the most part colored by the sequels and this first one is quite a bit different. It truly is a classic of its time and as good as most comments say, but let's delve a bit deeper.The strength of most films can be broken down to reasons of their individuality and generality, active gestures and underlying environment. The first are always easier to pick out and measure at a glance, in fact most reviews of any film center on these. This is easy to see here in the quirky characters of Riggs and Murtaugh, how Gibson and Glover actively flesh out the chemistry. Around them we have a perfectly competent action vessel for them to act out in.That's fine, this chemistry is what they relied on to create the franchise, building it up to a family. But I believe the film works - and is significantly different to the sequels - as much for their active presence as due to a presence of another sort.The first thing to note is that here we have the transition from film noir more clearly than any other film I can recall right now. The story begins with detectives on a case, cops. We are in a noir LA, Chandler's evocation of it: suburban money, prostitution, sleepless nights of drifting. The crime is a murder that would have been murder had the girl not leaped first from a balcony to her death, wonderfully worthy of the jazz causality of film noir. The transition from noir is that our detectives do the same suburban snooping around that Marlowe would do, but at every stop it erupts into gunfire and fireballs. The world no longer fiddles its noir machinations of mystery and self, but explodes, disappearing. You'll notice that by the end we don't get as much as a vague suggestion about her suicide, but we have the whole plan explained about the murder and drug trafficking plot. The causality is flattened. But the investigation itself still charms because it carries that sultry jazz echo of noir.Which brings me to the main thing I bring up in many other comments, the experience of immersion. The transition is from noir into action, from that generality which in pure noir appears as an ambiguous fabric of fate where the ordinary schmuck finds himself enmeshed, where space throbs with a mystery, to the straighforward individuality of the action film where space is a material backdrop for acting out. The transition means we get to see both.When Murtaugh first arrives at the murder scene by morning, we have a marvelous shot of him on the street looking up at that fateful balcony, our eye engulfed in bright light from above. Moments later, he's in the apartment ruminating as curtains flutter around him in the wind. The shot introducing us to Riggs' place covers first a vast stretch of beach. The first shot that introduces the villains, that whole lighter in the arm scene, is shot beneath a wonderful constellation of light bulbs.None of these shots are held for longer than the story has use for them, it's not that kind of film. But it's truly evocative, truly reflective about staring into the night ahead, because it is always anchored in an underlying space with presence. We have Murtaugh contemplating a life without all these things, on a boat, and that boat is stationed on his front lawn. You have some evidence of all this at work by looking at the much thinner sequels. The villains and plot are as ridiculous, but they bring Riggs and Murtaugh much more to the front, ignoring the noir and spatiality.Noir disappeared in TV shows and cop films like this, which fooled around with the plots or appearances, but these were never the main shaping forces of noir. Its essence is preserved and taken further by someone like Lynch, entirely about that prelogical point in the story when it is still both a murder and a suicide.

Lethal WeaponThe best thing about being a cop at Christmas is that you don't need the fake belly to play Santa.Surprising, the flatfoots in this action movie are quite fit, albeit not mentally.During the holiday season a prostitute is murdered, and her death is made to look like a suicide.Assigned to the case are cranky L.A.P.D. Sergeant Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and his loose cannon colleague Riggs (Mel Gibson).Together, the unorthodox pair expose a heroin trafficking ring run by ex-special forces (Mitchell Ryan, Gary Busey).But with Murtaugh's family in jeopardy, the duo may not be able to prevent the former flattops smuggling in the largest shipments of smack into L.A.From the combustible chemistry of the two leads, to the shadowy seasonal storyline, this initial installment of the successful series is still the quintessential buddy picture.Incidentally, Valium remains the number one drug choice of the holidays.
