All I can say is that this film is nothing short of awesome. I had actually been watching the series, and all through the series I just felt that, despite it being good, and that the actors did play their parts well, that it simply did not equate anywhere near the originals, and that was certainly the case with this particular film, which some have suggested is the bar upon which all subsequent buddy cop films are measured. Honestly, there is so much about this film that makes it good that it is impossible to list them all, one of them being that it is just so tight - nothing happens that doesn't need to happen, and pretty much everything is explained.Mind you, I probably don't need to give a rundown, but then again it is a rather old movie, though despite that it still works, and still works pretty well. It is about two cops - Roger Murtaugh and Martin Riggs, who are basically chalk and cheese. Sure, both were originally in the military and served in Vietnam, but Murtaugh is a family man while Riggs is suffering severe depression, namely because his wife was killed in a motor vehicle accident. Murtaugh lives in a nice family home while Riggs lives in a trailer on the beach.Anyway, the film opens with a woman throwing herself out of the top floor of a hotel, but it turns out that she had so many drugs in her system that she was dead anyway, so what appears to be a suicide turns out to be a murder investigation. I won't say that there are necessarily a lot of twists and turns in the film, because it is basically a straight out action film, but I have to admit that some of the scenes are pretty well done, especially the closing scenes where Riggs is running down the middle of Hollywood Blvd (I believe) in the rain. Actually, that whole scene at the end (not the punch up outside the house, but the scene where they are captured and tortured) works really well, and the way it unfolds is something that I rarely see in many of the films that I have watch.Honestly, I have to admit that this film is an absolute classic, and while it is definitely going to be really hard to beat, I am looking forward to watching the next films in the series.

There are two movies here: the first is a brilliant, groundbreaking "incompatible cop team" action movie with plenty of laughs. LAPD Sergeant Murtaugh (Danny Glover) is a "middle-aged" (altough Glover was actually only sweet 40 at the time of filming) cop with a large family and the world's worst cook for a wife. He has to team up with Sergeant Riggs, a young buck from a Special Forces background, who has gone mental following the death of his young wife.Just the opening scene, where a young hooker jumps to her death, is outstanding. At the beginning of this scene you might still be chatting with your friends about where to go afterwards, but at the end of this scene you will be firmly sitting in your seat and staring at the screen. And I may not be the hugest Mel Gibson fan, but his acting here is very impressive. There is a scene where he attempts to muster the courage to shoot himself in the head; this scene is crucial to the credibility of the entire movie, and there is one way of doing it right and a thousand of doing it wrong, but Gibson gets it spot-on. Glover is equally outstanding as the good-hearted, amiable guy who feels he's getting "too old for this sh*t". A difficult role to play next to Riggs' atom bomb of a character without going under or seeming like a douchebag.Anyroads, this film has it all: great acting, great plot, great cinematography, great atmosphere, it's all just so damn right and fine. You'd think that this movie was safely on its way to cinematic greatness when suddenly, inexplicably, it starts to suck harder than Monica Lewinsky trying to beat an octopus to it. It kind of starts in the scene where Hunsacker reveals his role as a drug trafficker and then is murdered by being shot from a helicopter. While drinking eggnog. But the story really jumps the shark in the desert lake scene, where oldtimer Murtaugh keeps a whole squad of heavily-armed mercenaries who are equipped with a freakin' helicopter AND holding his darling daughter hostage in check by threatening "to blow us all up" with a single hand-grenade.It's as if the studio had decided that this movie has been great enough so far, let's just roller-coaster it home. I don't know what happened here behind the scenes, but in a nutshell: a great movie for about one hour, then terribly sucky in its denouement. Still, for the cop-action-fan, it's recommended viewing.
34 years and its still as enjoyable as it was back then the ultimate Good Cop Bad Cop partnership.

reviews.review_title: Lethal Weapon! A great action film!
reviews.content: The Lethal Weapon series is an explosive and exciting one that is always exciting with a lot of action and great acting from the stars. There's Lethal Weapon 1, Lethal Weapon 2, Lethal Weapon 3, and Lethal Weapon 4 all starring great actors Mel Gibson and Danny Glover! Also Joe Pesci and Rene Russo are in the later editions! Steve Kahan and Paul Tuerpe are in all four as well. Shane Black did a great job with the writing! I also like how the series has the same composers Michael Clapton, and director Richard Donner has directed all four! Lethal Weapon is the one that started it all! It stars Mel Gibson, Danny Glover, and Gary Busey! Also in the movie is Mitch Ryan, Tom Atkins, Ed O'Ross, and Grand L. Bush. Look for Joan Severance, Sven-Ole Thorsen, Mic Rodgers, Peter DuPont, and Al Leong! There are some really neat action scenes and Gibson puts on an excellent performance! Good music by Michael Kamen and Eric Clapton! Looking for action and love Mel Gibson, Danny Glover, and Gary Busey? Watch Lethal Weapon today! I strongly recommend it!Movie Nuttball's NOTE:I noticed that Danny Glover, Gary Busey, and Steve Kahan were all in two movies together and they are Lethal Weapon and Predator 2! Interesting!

reviews.review_title: Mel Gibson likes action but with some social depth
reviews.content: We are reaching here the roots of Mel Gibson. He is a cop without any equal and pairs with another cop who is only second but learns fast. The action is highly packed and intense and that is exactly what we want, what we like. But is action enough to make a good film? Of course not. The film is good first of all because of the small touches of humanity that are scattered all around, a dog as a best friend, a cat as a best buddy, and you can imagine the meeting of the two on Christmas day. A boat that has a front and a back and no water all around. Several kids who are as nice as kids know how to be when they are in a good mood, and we are surprised by the high level of resistance and resilience they demonstrate in the midst of that frantic action. A few black street boys who are deliciously anti-cop and just like ice cream so much that they start forgetting they are not supposed to speak to cops. A grenade that is a smoke bomb. A birthday that turns hectic with too many candles, definitely too many, on the cake. A shooting gallery that turns funny with bullets carving nice smiles into the faces of all the culprits in the world. And that and many more details make that film a real pleasure, nearly emotional. But the film is a lot better than that. When a country starts something dirty in the world against another country or another people, sooner or later the criminals that country has trained to do the bad job will come back to haunt everyone in their tombs or a little before they put them in their tombs. Killing machines are killing machines and you cannot stop them because you decide the war is over. That's why you should never start a war anywhere in the world, and those professional trained criminals can only be put to death because they will never accept any other trial or judgment, nor any period of peace and quiet at the bottom of a jail seen as an aquarium for gold fishes. They can only end fighting with real weapons and killed by real bullets, two rather than one, from two different guns rather than only one. That's what makes this film a lasting pleasure because in the world there is always the temptation to start a new war, and after starting a first one you cannot resist starting a second to spread the feast and the fun and make hundreds of thousands of people, in uniform or not, take part in the "danse macabre" that leads right to the cemetery, what's more an anonymous tomb of course, or just a collective grave, a big hole with some lye on top of the dismembered bodies. But we can end with the beginning then and imagine what the best friend dog and the best buddy cat do together when they meet. They do what human beings always do when they meet: they fight over their differences.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne, University Paris 8 Saint Denis, University Paris 12 Créteil, CEGID

Lethal Weapon (1987)Well this takes me back a long time, back to a time when Mel had it all going on (except for the hair). I actually didn't remember this one that well and so I assume that it must be number 2 that I think of mostly when I think of the Lethal Weapon films.In general I did enjoy it again. Mel's bottom was a particularly nice way to start the film off, but Gary Busey terrifies me. I don't know if he will ever get a job as a nice guy, I mean can you imagine him as a romantic lead? Who would want to kiss him? I'd be afraid that he would stab me or something (I'm sure he's lovely really).It's a film full of action and some good comedic moments throughout and while it doesn't compare with 'Die Hard' (1988) as the best Action, Christmas film (Why aren't people making more of that?), it does entertain.I wonder if it might have been even better if they had taken it slightly more seriously and really focussed on the psychological issues the pair had. Although to be honest, there are probably too many of those films out there already, especially in these later years where no one seems to be able to make a comedy anymore, because they think the audience all wants to be depressed by realism. I suppose taking the sting out of it a bit in this film might have helped to deliver the message more easily for viewers less used to such misery all the time in the 80's. What a grim world we live in now.The fight scene at the end was a bit unbelievable, but Mr Gibson did look good all wet and covered in mud.I'm actually looking forward to watching the next three.639.91/1000.

Don't read this review. It's bias in every which way! Singularly my favourite film ever. Maybe the main reason for me getting to geek status with the wonderful world of movies. 
Shane Black (wow) Richard Donner (wow) Mel Gibson (wow)! All my Christmas's at once. Many people will disagree with me but I love it! 
The ultimate in buddie movies which spawned 3 more fantastic films. The original crazed Mad max becomes the even crazier Martin Riggs. Gibson portrays the agony and heartache of a cop on the edge of losing wife. His face could tell a thousand stories of his pain. Richard Donner knows that Mel Gibson has this edge and frames it perfectly. He lets the actors generate an energy and rolls with it. This is seen even more on LW2. 80's action with amazing energy that doesn't stop. Danny (Murtagh) Glover could be the voice of reason but for Riggs but realised he is too much of a lose cannon to control. Perfect cop buddie, good cop, worst cop! "I'll never be to old for this shxx!"

reviews.review_title: A buddy action movie the way it's properly done, but in 2021 little bit dated
reviews.content: Before the buddy-cop formula became overused "Lethal Weapon" was viewed to have much freshness compare to most of the late 1980s action movies. In the 33+ years since film was first released, a good bit of it may seem dated but will still be fun for those that appreciate the era. The chemistry between D. Glover and M. Gibson is readily apparent and stays that way. The plot is little bit over the top, but it's easy to forgive, because "Lethal Weapon" is one of those rare action films that has a little for everyone, even when it makes spiraling out of control.Rating: 6+/7-

With the time, this movie started a lot of trends that are nowadays in all action movie. The funny thing is that those ideas come by pair of opposites:First, the buddy movie: the old timer teams up with a crazy hotshot and the mix is explosive. The former calm and dull pavilion life will be changed forever. The magic comes here from its formidable casting because Glover and Gibson fit the part like glove. Next, the big violent criminals and sexual arousal: it's evident here that the shootings and fights are more brutal that those we have previously seen in similar movies. The kills rise high as well as the nudity scenes (it's not a erotic movie but you see that the prude veil is starting to come down at the release). However, the pill passes up as this content is blended with very familial content as well and comedy.Now, the complicated and very unbelievable plots: as they laugh themselves of it ("it's thin", "anorexic"), the crime story isn't original or inventive but the movie is speedy, nervous and dynamic (maybe it's even a bit too fast because the edit is sometimes clumsy: look for the handcuffs just before the big jump or count the shots and compare them with the card!). Like the casting, Donner has been a good choice because he knows how to tell a story.At last, in this first movie, the more unexpected opposition comes to shoot the movie in LA at Christmas time. It's very unusual to see that and the movie has a good atmosphere coming from the Californian sun and the Christmas decorations!Quickly, a good mention goes to the daughter that I have unfortunately never saw in other big movies and to the late Nick Kamen who scored a very bluesy score that helps define the mood of the movie.As you have understood, it's a really good movie, full of juice and laughs and that calls for more!

reviews.review_title: High calibre action, that's lethally addictive
reviews.content: If you ever saw the movie trailer, rip roaring with action, that will appease the hardcore viewer, you won't be disappointed by what unfolds before your your very eyes in this 110 minute high level actioner, that pits probably the best two partner cops, ever seen on film, even though the two, strangers at first, take an instant disapproval to one another. Gibson, as Riggs, gives one of his best acting performances ever. He's everything the part calls for. He's a border line psycho cop/ex Vietnam vet, who needs a stable cop, like Murtaugh (Danny Glover) to take him under his wing. Riggs is a very lonely guy, who just can't get over his wife's (Victoria Lynn) death, so basically he hates the world. This latest case which becomes personal for both cops, sees a young girl suiciding by free falling several stories, plummeting to her death, where later, it's discovered she was murdered, due to cooking up, where this pretty lass, was also used in pornographic films. But there's much more to this exciting story, where the bad guys are bad, and beautifully played by two heavyweights, but I won't disclose names. Action comes thick and fast in this, with no time to really stop. What makes Lethal Weapon, better than many of it's competitor action films, is beside the explosive action, is the family angle, where in between fighting baddies, Riggs and Murtaugh, spend some time out scenes like at Murtaugh's house, when he's invited for dinner. This is a great scene, and after on Murtaughs boat, where the last scene when all the dust has settled, just upon Christmas, and Murtaughs invites Riggs in, it couldn't be penned more better. This I will say, now, is the best buddy cop partnership in history, where we are thankful for the three sequels that followed. Lethal Weapon has a great young breakthrough writer as in Shane Black who was only 23 when he wrote this. The opening of the Jingle Bell Rock song, is unexpected, and too the title song is explosive. It's so much fun here, watching mad Mel, displaying so many emotions, some moments, really scaring us, as this is one unstable dude. The woman psychiatrist, played by a late actress, is really taking the p..s out of psychiatrists generally, by her un layman terms of evaluation. One special non stop actioner, I demand you all see, which will always live with me, as the actioner of 87 that stood out when first viewing it, but too, we could do with a few more action films, not involving drug.

It's a good movie. I watched alot as a kid and liked it very much. Now is just ok. Girl doing drugs and jumping to her death(Judge Jredd). Alot like Die Hard, but Die Hard is better. Also not as funny.

Mel Gibson, Danny Glover, Tom Atkins, Gary Busey, Mitch Ryan, Darlene Love, Jackie Swanson and Traci Wolfe star in Richard Donner's 1987 action film. This takes place in L.A. where we meet veteran cop, Roger Murtaugh (Glover) who has a wife, Trish (Love) and 3 kids. Roger celebrates his 50th birthday and soon gets paired up with new partner, Martin Riggs (Gibson) who has a death wish due to the loss of his late wife. Together, they investigate a murder-suicide of a young girl, Amanda Hunsaker (Swanson). Along the way, Murtaugh and Riggs get to know each other and eventually become friends. Atkins (The Fog, Halloween III) plays Amanda's wealthy father, Michael who is also Murtaugh's old friend, Busey plays drug-dealer, Joshua who works for General, Peter McCallister (Ryan) and Wolfe plays Roger's daughter, Rhianne. Gibson and Glover are great in this and together and who can forget Michael Kamen's excellent score. I recommend this great 80's action film that's definitely the best in the series.

reviews.review_title: Infamous cop duo of Riggs and Murtaugh get it done
reviews.content: Nothing says 1980s cop thriller like a story of two cops that don't want to work with each other being forced to work with each other, especially when one of them is black and the other is Mel Gibson with flowing hair.There's not much to say about "Lethal Weapon" other than it got it right. Riggs and Murtaugh (Gibson and Glover) are undeniably one of the top duos of all time. After all, their chemistry was spectacular enough to bring about three more sequels. But why does the aging, skeptical black man work well with the younger, reckless, suicidal white guy? It's this huge contrast that reaches a wide audience.Because of how different they are, both heroes connect to everyone, but it's really more about how they are one person split in two. We all have a more grounded perception of our lives and our jobs like Murtaugh, but there is a part of us that wants to live on the edge and do things the bold way. That's the whole idea behind Shane Black's script and he sums it up well at the end. Of course it didn't hurt that he had one of the greatest directors of that decade bringing his work to life. Richard Donner is about as solid as you can get when it comes to action. While some of the scenes are definitely "please keep this locked up in the 80s" material, Donner does a lot to show you just how similar Riggs and Murtaugh are with camera angles and shots that compare them similarly.The plot is really only a vehicle for these characters to interact. It seems like every time the two go somewhere they are launched directly into an action sequence. There is no set up, no tension building; something merely explodes or suddenly there's a helicopter and a guy shooting at them. It's kind of ridiculous and the bad guys as a result seem way out in left- field, but the point is just how Murtaugh and Riggs respond to all these events and how they're changed. We just get to enjoy some great 80s gunfights along the way.

Best Christmas movie next to Die Hard. One of my favorite buddy cop movies, action movie, 80s movies, Christmas movie. It took many years to detach myself from the shenanigans of Mel Gibson. Now that I have I can enjoy these movies again. I wish today's action movies would look back on movies like Lethal Weapon so they could learn how to be good... but maybe I am just too old for this $@#t.
The best four-piece of all time. All the others were destroyed by Reboots & Co.

reviews.review_title: The model of the cop buddy genre
reviews.content: With it's mix of serious thriller plot, action-comedy and chemistry between it stars Lethal Weapon has an iconic film from the 80s and as one of archetype buddy-comedy films.Danny Glover and Mel Gibson play Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson), two LAPD detectives who could not be more different. Murtaugh is a Sergeant who just celebrated his 50th birthday and a happy family man, whilst Riggs had just lost his wife in a car accident and has become suicidal. Both are good officers but have very different styles: Murtaugh is much more safer in his approach to Riggs as a maverick. The two are forced together after Riggs was transferred and the two are assigned to investigate the death of a prostitute. But it quickly turns out that the death was linked to a drugs ring, run by the General (Mitchell Ryan) and his loyal henchman Mr. Joseph (Gary Busey).Lethal Weapon was a film that was able to mixed a serious plot that could have worked in a thriller or police film, with strong, light-hearted relationship between Glover and Gibson. The plot is played straight and has moments of darkness, whilst the characters themselves were a bit more comic because of Murtaugh's domestic situation and Riggs' crazy personality. But this film was played to be pretty serious for the most part.Shane Black writes a very good script and with Richard Donner's direction the action is constant. Donner knew when to slow the film down to allow the characters to shine. With a good score and traditional action techniques Donner makes an exciting and fun film: but the final fight scene was a bit disappointing. Donner kept a fast pacing so it was hard to get bored with a film like this. But Lethal Weapon is Donner's best film since The Omen (I am including Superman). Black avoided clichés that plagued the genre later on, like the dressing down by the police captain or the main two characters hating each other and then becoming friends. Murtaugh and Riggs do have a chalk and cheese relationship, but they never hate each other. They learn from each other and the relationship was natural in the film's internal reality. The plot itself was as mentioned, dark and in the right level between believable but just enough to keep a level of fantasy which was needed for this type of film.The key to the film was the interaction between Glover and Gibson who worked well together. Glover was more natural and deadpan in his approach whilst Gibson was more over the time. The acting is decent for the most part.An enjoyable film.

reviews.review_title: The beginning of a beautiful friendship
reviews.content: This is one of the buddy cops films I liked very much. "Lethal Weapon" is a name in the making, and I think this movie will stick in the minds of movie goers for all ages. Here you have Riggs(Mel Gibson), a neurotic cop who teams with Murtaugh(Danny Glover) a veteran family man cop. Pairs like these, you'll need someone from I.A.(Internal Affairs) to keep tabs to. I liked the Christmas tree crackdown where Riggs showed his crazy side to the crooks using the Curly maneuver, N'YUK! N'YUK!N'YUK! That's homage to the Three Stooges. When it comes to villains, Gary Busey played it well. Targeting both men, this soldier doesn't deserve an honorable mention of any sorts. The martial arts scenes were great, despite Riggs mental state, he's sane enough to protect his partner and his family, who would know that he would have eyes on Murtaugh's daughter. Hmmmmm! Other than that, this is great all the way, and these guys will be friends for life, in the films and in real life! 4 out of 5 stars.

reviews.review_title: One Of Best Cop Movies, Better than Bad Boys
reviews.content: Two newly paired cops who are complete opposites must put aside their differences in order to catch a gang of drug smugglers. These old cop movies make me happy. Die Hard, Bad Boys and now this. Lethal Weapon became one of the best cop movies on my list. Really great story, not some lame story genuine story. Oh, acting those two made me insane Mel Gibson and Danny Glover those two make a perfect team. I should mention sound balancing in this movie they did a perfect job in that section. Highly recommend this movie.

reviews.review_title: The honest truth about one of the most beloved action/comedy series in the movie industry.
reviews.content: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS FOR ALL FOUR MOVIES!!1 - was fresh, innovative, edgy and hard. It had everything a good action movie needs to make it successful; excellent character development, imaginative direction, professional performances by the cast and crew, a clever and witty screenplay with intelligent dialog, and action...lots of good fast-paced, well-delivered action. It had a fresh comedic element without ever turning to camp or juvenile antics to solicit a chuckle from us. The comedy was educated, intelligent and expertly-delivered. The characters were lovable, and we got the feeling that we "knew" them, cared about them, wanted them to succeed. Riggs's character felt less like a character and more like a person, due to the high-level of development his character received. True, the "gun handling" left a lot to be desired, but the vast majority of audiences would not realize that you can not get 20 shots from a 16 shot clip. Nor would they realize that you can't just leave those empty clips on the ground; they cost MONEY and no CoP would do that because law enforcement officers are typically not highly paid. That aside, this was an excellent movie with wonderful entertainment value. One of the best of its kind.2 - gave us Joe Pesci's character, Leo Getz. Because of Getz, I honestly found this film to be rather endearing. Getz is one of the best characters to have been introduced to this series. Unfortunately, the edge and freshness is toned down way too much, and the action is really rather predictable. I thoroughly enjoyed bearing witness to the further development of the relationship between Riggs and Murtaugh, and was not in the least bored with that aspect. It is still a good movie, even though its edge is shelved for a more "marketable" product.3 - is just as good as 2. Riggs now has a new love interest and it seems as though all will be well and all manner of things will be well. It is still a few months away from the press release concerning the Glover/Gibson signing for 4 & 5, so it seems the series has wound down, rather than up. The action is still quality, though there are fewer and fewer unpredictable moments. The comedic aspect which was enlightened and intelligent is now a bit puerile and tired. And while the performances are still professional, it seems as though Riggs and Murtaugh both are well on their way out.4 - is the perfect ending to this series. Honestly. The characters have developed as far as I can bear to witness; Murtaugh misfires his gun in the locker room of the precinct, Riggs gets his butt kicked by a rookie cop in the boxing ring, and Riggs and Murtaugh are both just too old for this action thing anymore. (Gods help us with 60-something-year-old Harrison Ford in the upcoming "Indiana Jones 4.") Their CHARACTERS speak constantly of being too old, and I'm not talking about Murtaugh's well used line, "I'm getting too old for this sh*t." It is far beyond that. And now, with Riggs's marriage to Lorna, Murtaugh's daughter's marriage to Butters, the new babies and all the smarmy crap at the ending...enough is just enough.5 - should never happen. I don't think I can bear to see anymore smarm from these two. The characters we all loved are already gone. Like in "Invasion of the Bodysnatchers," they've been stolen from us. The edge from Riggs's character is gone. He's a bit hapless now, and sad rather than the lunatic mayhem we want and NEED from his character.The only way to pull off a 5th installment would be to kill off Lorna's character, the baby AND Butters. Either put Riggs back where his character was in 1 & 2, or don't bring him out of the moth balls. PLEASE. I loved these movies, but for the love of Mike! NO MORE!If you liked any of these movies, I highly recommend "Tango & Cash," an excellent, much-overlooked, highly under-rated "Buddy-Cop" movie.1. 9.2/102. 8.8/103. 7.6/104. 6.8/10 from...the Fiend :.

reviews.review_title: Hard As Nails 80s Action Headed By Unorthodox Gibson
reviews.content: (Flash Review)Family man and wild man are two cops at the opposite ends of the personality spectrum. Murtaugh has a family and kids and Riggs's wife has just died so isn't thinking straight on top of it all. They are thrust into breaking up a drug smuggling operation. During that, things get personal for Murtaugh as he ups the stakes. Watch the two partners battle through the dangerous case. There are some crazy action scenes, amusing banter and Gary Busey plays a strange bad guy as one would hope. I can sort of see how this sparked a movies series but at the same time, this was not as good as I remembered back in the late 80's.

reviews.review_title: Lethal Weapon Series: Part one (and the best of the bunch).
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon (1987) was the first big stateside release for Mel Gibson. After living in Australia for many moons, he returns back to his homeland with this surprise hit. Mel Gibson stars as Riggs, a loose cannon cop who lives life on the edge. He takes many chances whilst he's on duty because he doesn't care about life anymore (since the death of his wife). He's partnered with Murtaugh (Danny Glover), a nearly retired cop who's counting the days until his retirement (aren't they always going to retire in these films). Can Murtaugh keep Riggs in line? What drives Riggs to live just another day? Why is this movie filled with homo-erotic tendencies? To find out you'll just have to watch LETHAL WEAPON.This movie was the best of the bunch. I was fascinated by who cool and crazy Riggs character was. Instead of leaving it at one movie, they had to ruin the memory of the film and make three more lame action films. The longer the films went the more homo-erotic they became. I'm serious, watch these films again with this in mind.Recommended.

reviews.review_title: plain and simple: lots of fun
reviews.content: Violent, energetic action-comedy from director Richard Donner centering around two mismatched LA cops, one a reckless hothead on the verge of suicide (Gibson), the other a skilled veteran and stable family man (Glover), who are reluctantly paired together after the alleged suicide of a young prostitute, but there's more to the story and they're soon in over their heads after they stumble onto what appears to be a drug smuggling ring. The two leads are both in peak form and provide many laugh-out loud moments, aided by intense, raw, adrenaline-pumping action scenes. A simple buddy cop movie that's elevated thanks to a good cast and lively direction. Bottom line: A real good time. ***

reviews.review_title: Gibson and Glover's First Rodeo is More Than Just a Brainless Action Flick
reviews.content: Mel Gibson and Danny Glover ignite a franchise with this dense, multi-faceted action flick from the mid-'80s. Although in later installments the duo grew too chummy and formulaic for my taste, Gibson and Glover's relationship in this introductory adventure is icy, complex and quite interesting, especially with the enhanced benefits of retrospect. Gibson, in his mainstream American breakthrough, is particularly good as unhinged, suicidal cop Martin Riggs, who always seems to have a pit of emotion raging behind his wide, unsettling gaze. Of course, it's an action movie from right in the heart of the genre's heyday, so there's no shortage of fireballs, gunshots, abandoned warehouses or furiously flying fists, but its big heart, strong core relationship and generally-grounded approach to the big fight scenes keep it from feeling overly indulgent. Surprisingly gripping and diverse, it's a feather in the cap for both the headline duo and their veteran director, Richard Donner.

Lethal Weapon is the typical Hollywood popcorn action film: it wasn't the first and certainly not the last either. But it's kinda special. I dare to say that it is...superior to the other films of the genre? I mean, it is extremely dull, the characters motivations are certainly not convincing or cleverly explained, and the story arc is painfully cliché...but the hell, who cares? The targeted audience is perhaps very satisfied with the result. It is a dull action popcorn flick with lots of crude jokes on it. I really don't get the appeal of this kind of film, it offends my intellectual capacities, but i can understand why some people do like this one so much. The fans of the 'popcorn' sub-genre do _and the future ones will_ absolutely love it. Mel Gibson actually overacts a lot, and so Danny Glover does. But that aspect do actually made some sense, since the film is plain over the top. And the soundtrack is actually very good. I really like it. It brings to the film a entire new type of atmosphere, a more neo- romantic thriller one. So...it's worth of one watch, i guess. More than one, it's asking too much. 6.5/10

Plot; A calm, rational veteran detective is paired with an unorthodox and mentally unstable younger partner.Perhaps the definitive film in the buddy cop genre, this first of four Lethal Weapon films is much darker than its sequels. Where they amped up the comedy and softened the harder edges of Mel Gibson's Martin Riggs character, the original is an occasionally brooding and jarringly violent action/dramedy.Stars Mel Gibson and Danny Glover share an incredible and effortless chemistry, and though it boasts a tight script (by Shane Black) and steady direction (by Richard Donner), it's Gibson and Glover who really make it work.

I'm not sure that I'd place Lethal Weapon as the best buddy cop flick  that honour would probably have to go to 48 Hours, mainly by virtue of the fact that Nolte and Murphy spend most of the film randomly punching each other in the face  but Donner's film is near the top of the pile. It certainly delivers in terms of action and barely concealed man love.One of the most telling things about Lethal Weapon is that Gibson is introduced in the nude and that the first shot of Glover shows him in the bath. We're not talking action here. We're talking lurve, a love that transcends age, race and supposed heterosexuality. Don't believe me? Well, how does Riggs (Gibson) come to terms with the death of his wife? Over time? By finding another woman? No, Riggs only overcomes his suicidal urges after a big manly hug (while soaking wet) on his partner's lawn and after being welcomed into his partner's home. He doesn't need his wife anymore. He has a new beau.And going to the start of the film, what's the first thing that Riggs and Murtaugh (Glover) talk about when they're teamed up? They talk about their 'guns'  size, age etc. And they even go to a firing range together. Here we get to see their guns in action and how potent they are with their weapon. Of course, Murtaugh thinks he's hot stuff, but he's an old codger and the young buck can hit the target from a much greater distance. Needless to say, Murtaugh is impressed. The date went well.But the lengths that Gibson goes to in order to protect his dear one are rather extreme. He even endures electrocution  topless, of course, with his ripped torso showing and with water cascading over his fine mullet and impressive abs. But he never betrays his partner and he kills the bad guy with his thighs. Impressive. And after that he fights the dastardly Mr Joshua on his partner's muddy lawn  again while soaking wet and again choking a man with his thighs. I guess Riggs likes having a man's head between his legs. But the two detectives kill Joshua together. They're officially a couple.But the film's not entirely about man love. There's action too. And it's to the film's credit that none of the action is too preposterous (by 80s standards, at least). Yes you get helicopters that can sneak up on cliff-side mansions without making a noise and yes people can take severe beatings and still get up for more, but there are no Die Hard-style flights of fancy (as fun as they are, though). In fact, the best bit of action is the famous jumper scene. Riggs handcuffs himself to a suicidal man and leaps off a side of a building with him. It's just damn funny. However, I do have to point out that I prefer Dirty Harry's style of negotiation. He doesn't bother with handcuffs or theatrics. He just taunts the jumper, makes him jump onto the cherry picker and then punches him out. Splendid. But I heartily endorse either style of policing.I also endorse the rather sadistic aspects of the film. There's one bit when you see the bad guys rubbing salt into Murtaugh's wounds. I like that. I like that a lot. And I like it because it makes you root for the good guys even more. You want them to blow these guys away. And that's what you need for a good action film. You don't want to be passive. You want to revel in the bloody death of bleach blonde drug runners and their Charlton Heston look-a-like bosses.Earlier I mentioned Die Hard. The two films actually have quite a bit in common. Not only are they both set during Christmas, not only are they both set in Los Angeles, not only do they have the main henchman make a surprise resurrection at the end, but they also have pretty much the same score. I guess Michael Kamen, when Die Hard came around a year after Lethal Weapon, was so lacking in inspiration when called to make a second Christmas action score that he recycled it. But I guess it's not too much of a problem. It's a good score. And at least Lethal Weapon, unlike Die Hard, has the benefit of Eric Clapton's twangy guitar and some weeping saxophones. (What is it with cops and saxophones? The two are inextricably linked. I guess its because the saxophone is the instrument of depression and sleaze.) But to go with the action and the saxophones, you also have some enjoyably awful lines. Murtaugh says to a hooker, "All dressed up and no one to blow." And when freeing his partner, Riggs says, "Let's do what one shepherd said to the other shepherd. 'Let's get the flock out of here.'" Groansome, yes, but enjoyably so.However, the script isn't as convincing when it tries for emotion. Riggs' yearning for his wife is certainly rather by the numbers. You know that he's going to get over it and you know its there just to try and give the film an added edge. Or more accurately, it's the film's justification for Riggs' craziness  the film has little interest in exploring Riggs' emotions, it just wants a crazy cop. Better, though, is the bonding between the two cops. Gibson and Glover certainly have chemistry and the family scenes have a warmth that you rarely see in these sorts of films. Which I guess is the reason why their man love is still so enjoyable to watch.

reviews.review_title: Worth a re-watch...except maybe for Mel's hair
reviews.content: I caught this on TV the other night and had a blast watching it again. I had forgotten what a great movie this is and really enjoyed myself. It's aged pretty well too except maybe for the annoying score of saxophone music and possibly Mel's cool hair. Well there is that scene with the giant portable phone.Anyways, this is how buddy-cop movies are meant to be; great chemistry between our leads, humorous, without feeling forced, yet also dark and gritty with action scenes that didn't feel like they were just there for the sake of a cool stunt. This also managed to stay away from clichés and the prevalent 80's cheese factor and felt original all the way through. Just a great ride.I was also impressed with how tortured Mel's character 'Martin' is. You genuinely feel his loneliness and pain especially the scene at Christmas with his wife's photo and the hollow point bullet. On a lighter note his original hairstyle gets billing as "created by Ramsey" in the credits which made me laugh. 07.13 (3)

This Thrill-packed action-drama is second only to Die Hard In the best action movies of all time. Mel Gibson's charecter is however the best in the long magnificent history of action movie  charecters. 10/10  See it as soon as you can, Even if you've seen it before. Yes It's just that good.

reviews.review_title: Looking back, this was a DUMB movie
reviews.content: OK, I'll admit that when I saw this movie upon its release, I thought it was the most awesome cop movie I had ever seen. It's only upon looking back with the benefit of 21 years of experience that I can say it truly is a dumb movie, one that doesn't hold up to scrutiny. A total departure from "real life".I don't know why they bother to make these brainless movies. Are they made just to placate the dumb crowd, who wouldn't know real police activity if it jumped up and arrested them? This series got stupider and stupider as it went along -- more insulting to the viewer's intelligence in each installment. Eventually they became a political vehicle for a gun control message. Showing the public the evils of "cop-killer bullets" -- you know, the handgun-caliber ammunition that can punch right through the blade of a front-end loader. *groan* Yeah, right.I'll never watch one of these movies again. They're for idiots.

One of the best action movies of the 80's. One of the best cop buddy movies ever,, you got Glover, Gibson, Murtaugh,, Riggs,, one just had a birthday,, the other psycho, maybe suicidal, perfect match,, then you got one of the greatest bad guys of the past say 20 years,, Gary Busey,, he plays the part of Joshua. basically the cops have to try and stop a shipment of Heroin before it get's to the docks. Riggs just lost his wife,, but they don't go into any kind of detail how it really happened and all,, he lives alone,, with his dog,, kinda looks like Lassie,, on a trailer on the beach.. Murtaugh is married big family,, even has a boat.. There is lots of action in this one,, but the best thing is that it is so darn funny, the one - liners they give these boys is just unrealistic,, i think this is def. in my top 250 i don't know how IMDb will look at it,, but definitely a winner in my book

Richard Donner's fast-paced action film was one of the best from the 1980's. Detectives Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and "Lethal Weapon" Riggs (Mel Gibson) are on the trail of drug lords who will stop at nothing to keep their operation functional. The story from Shane Black makes for an over the top movie, yet it is restrained enough to be enjoyable. And Donner makes sure the two leads are portrayed as real people that we can relate to.The end does take proceedings a little too far, but does not spoil the roller coaster ride which Gibson and Glover seem to have enjoyed as much as the audience will. Also starred Gary Busey and Mitch Ryan.Thursday, August 13, 1992 - Video

.The opening scene starts with an airborne view of Los Angeles where a gorgeous blonde chick, clad in a white nightgown,lying on a red sofa. Next to her on a table with drugs situated on top. The young lady gets up to sniff the drugs, then walks outside to the balcony, leans toward the railing and take her fatal plunge to her death.Mel Gibson was flat-out excellent as mentally unbalanced cop Det. Martin Riggs. As he combines his versatility as both a strong action hero and a lovable clown. Using both his charm and charisma, Riggs is probably one of the most endearing characters in film history. As a man who's perpetually grief-stricken after the death of his wife in a fatal automobile accident, Riggs has been living an unsettling life. Hell go far as to dare someone dangerous to kill him, even if its just for kicks. Many times Riggs tries to kill himself. With the assistance of his .9 mm. Beretta, he places the gun into his mouth and attempts to pull the trigger. Other attempts of suicidal tendencies is when another hes on top of a building and another jumper is nearby. He places one part of a handcuff on the jumpers wrist and another on his wrist as he gracefully throws the key in the air. As a unstable gunman, he fires shots without blinking claiming that "killing was the only thing he could do well".Riggs joins forcing with a reluctant ageing African-American police detective Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) to explore further investigation to the suicide of the young lady who fell to her death, which puts the dynamic duo in the centre of a major drug bust. Glover is equally effective and is known for stealing every scene he's in. Murtaugh is from the old-school of investigating as he is fixated on retirement but prefers to play by the rules rather than take risks like his partner Riggs. Pushing towards 50, Murtaugh wants to just forget about his achievements he's accomplished as an investigator and wants to spend time with his family.When news gets around that his daughter has been kidnapped, Murtaugh bites his tongue and goes along with Riggs risky ways in order to get his daughter back. Gary Busey is Mr. Joshua,a cold-blooded evil drug-lord who's also has had experience as a Vietnam vet. Joshua will go to any lengths necessary into how much the cops know about his drug rings. His boss General Peter MacAllister (Mitchell Ryan) who looks even more menacing than Joshua like as though he has icicles running through his veins. The evil general turns up the crank in the investigation by ordering Murtaugh to be annihilated and in the process kidnaps his adorable daughter Rianne (Traci Wolfe) in order for Murtaugh to speak. Director Richard Donner this movie combines plenty of bone-chilling action, great humour and brilliant acting by the cast. This goes beyond all expectancies from a cop-drama. The final action scenes pit Riggs and Murtaugh against the General and his goons features some of the best choreographed fight scenes ever put on film.

reviews.review_title: An entertaining buddy cop action film
reviews.content: Buddy Cop films were not uncommon in the 80s for several reasons. A big reason was that they permitted heavy violence with comical one liners. Another reason though was to pair up two odd ball actors together in one movie. It was a big grab because it allowed for audiences to see interactions between stars that were not normally seen in other genres. Among all the productions that were made, the most popular and critically praised was Richard Donner's Lethal Weapon (1987), the director best known for Superman (1978) and The Goonies (1985) up to that point. Then, attach writer Shane Black to the production and it became an instant hit. Shane Black is the more successful brother of Terry Black, the writer behind Dead Heat (1988).Black's set up to the main story is for the most part like any other buddy cop film. Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) is an older police officer on the force getting close to retirement. Officer Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) is widower who can't be handled by his coworkers. Ever since he lost his wife, Riggs has been on the edge and no one wants to be partnered up with him. That is until he gets assigned to be with Murtaugh. Once Riggs meets Murtaugh, there is initial friction but they soon grow on each other with emotional backstories that are developed enough for the audience to care and understand. Aside from that, both Glover and Gibson give their characters a decent dose of charm. Glover is great at being the tired elderly cop and Gibson is great at being all over the place and bouncing off the walls. These contrasts are fun especially when they share the screen together.There's also a number of supporting actors cast in this movie. Gary Busey and Tom Atkins also have significant roles to play. Tom Atkins plays key a part in a homicide that Riggs and Murtaugh have to figure out. Gary Busey doesn't play a unique individual but makes his performance interesting because he's not all out crazy. He's a bit disturbing but not loony. That's Gibson's role anyway. Sadly there isn't much to say about cinematography or editing. It is competently done though. The cinematographer was Stephen Goldblatt (who might be editor Mark Goldblatt's brother?). The editor was Stuart Baird, who also worked with Donner on Superman (1978). Other than that, there's nothing to say that really stood out. The action was handled well especially when it came to fight sequences. Mel Gibson sure knew how to throw a punch. As for shootings and car chases, nothing there felt special either, I actually expected more. Musically related, Michael Kamen produced the score while collaborating with Eric Clapton. Was it memorable? Ehh,...no not really. However, the sound was different than most scores. This particular score highlighted the most saxophone in it than any other score I've listened too. This made it unique, sadly not enough to remember though. I don't even recall a main theme. However, there were some scenes that were effective - like Mel Gibson's emotional trauma. That worked, but it worked on occasion. It is still a well-made action film no doubt.It has a good cast of actors, fun action and a well-written story. Music and camera-work are good too but nothing to be amazed over. Fun fun.

Often overshadowed by the archetypal Die Hard, this is a fun Christmas actioner that deserves it's slot in your holiday rotation. If Die Hard defined action movies, this defines buddy cop movies. Shane Black had to fight to keep Riggs suicidal, making it all the more remarkable.

reviews.review_title: The best buddy cop movie of the 80s
reviews.content: I love this movie !! Mel Gibson as a psycho pinching suicidal cop and Danny Glover as a family man cop and they are both a great chemistry with each other and that spawned 3 more sequels and they were all great. You can't have a better buddy cop movie than this . Gary Busey playing Joshua was awesome in this playing very vicious in this and Mitchell Ryan did a great job as General Mccalister. If you new millennials didn't see it yet , then check it out and the three other sequels after it and you will love it!!

It's all about the partnership! Both are great characters and some iconic scenes here, it does turn into very typical action shoot em up from about half way through and for me loses a little of what it starts out to be, but easy watching all the same!

Lethal Weapon is the only film I have seen in the series.It is a cop/buddy movie starring Mel Gibson and Danny Glover.I thought it was pretty good, it had some entertaining moments(some humor as well) and it was just like any other cop/buddy movie of the 1980's.I personally think the Beverly Hills Cop movies were better(but I have only seen this one in the series).The film is about a cop who must solve one more case, he is also close to retirement.He is paired with a crazy, suicidal cop(played by Gibson in a good role) and together they must stop a gang of drug smugglers.Lethal Weapon is a fun cop/buddy movie but it's not excellent by any means.

reviews.review_title: Standard action film- gets credit for being one of the first of the summer blockbusters
reviews.content: I wasn't altogether impressed by 'Lethal Weapon', the scenes were often formulaic, and I was especially disappointed by the lack of much comedy. Still, the film had energy and was worthwhile, redeemed slightly by good chemistry between the leads and a few outstanding action sequences.	The film takes a while to establish itself, and is slightly tedious during the first half hour or hour, but much of it is well done and quite entertaining. Richard Donner's direction is fast paced and helps the film move through the slower parts almost effortlessly.	The acting is absolutely first rate. Glover is excellent in the lead, and Gibson is good, but many of the scenes belong to villain Gary Busey, appearing in one of his (very) few 'real' roles, those being ones not of the B variety. He's a good actor who can't seem to choose roles well. Gibson is the lesser of the two leads, but still better than many other actors could do. He starts to fit in more with his character in the next three films, but is still more than respectable. 	If you are a fan of any of the three stars, or of director Donner, I recommend seeing it, or else you may be disappointed. More comedic moments certainly would've helped.6.5/10

reviews.review_title: Not very interesting in my opinion
reviews.content: I saw this movie when I was visiting my aunt in Chicago.  She likes it quite a bit, but I don't really care too much for it.  I didn't think it was stupid or anything like that.  I just wasn't too interested in it.  But for those of you who do enjoy the series, you can go watch it yourselves.

I've always thought the Lethal Weapon movies were pretty good, but the first isn't the best, like everyone says. Its really good, but it sometimes gets boring on re-watches, so it doesn't rate as high as parts 2 and 4 for me.

Martin Riggs is an unstable man. He lost his wife a long time ago, and is always on the edge no matter who he encounters.Roger Murtaugh is a family father who has been in the force for many years. He has a relatively tidy life, but feels a bit anguished over turning 50. When a woman jumps out of a window in what looks like a suicide but might be something else, Riggs and Murtaugh have to work with each other. To their dismay.This is an iconic staple in the buddy cop genre. The chemistry between Mel Gibson and Danny Glover is said to have rarely been replicated as well, and it's easy to see why. Gibson is impressive as the unstable cop and approaches his character with both a darkly humorous and tragic quality that makes him so engaging to watch. The scene where he's so close to really pulling the trigger on himself is both intense and heartwrenching. He doesn't do it, but you can tell he thinks he might as well. Unsurprisingly, he's not the greatest choice trying to talk a suicidal person out of jumping off a building. They both land happily, but could very well have been fatal. Gibson teasing the guy and telling him to jump if he really wants to is disturbingly hilarious, and such is Murtaugh telling Riggs to kill himself if he really wants to die that badly. Murtaugh anger/fear over his unstable partner is very realistically portrayed, yet you can't help but smile when Glover yells in at the opponent, who is equally compelling as the down-to-earth cop who loves his wife and kids, but doesn't like feeling like a dinosaur.There's not much mystery around who murdered Michael Hunsaker's daughter even if the movie does a good job hiding it, but the journey there is what grabs you. The two cops slowly learning to trust each other chasing down people who are connected to the murder is very fun watch, and even more so the scene where Murtaugh shows Riggs his home and family. I like how Riggs starts to grow on Murtaugh, but is immediately disturbed again when he talks about how killing has been a part of him since he was a child.The last third is when the action takes a faster tempo, and Gary Busey gets a time to shine as Joshua, the man who had Hunsaker's daughter murdered. With his cold intimidating stare and playful delivery as he tries to keep control of the situation makes him a memorable villain. The final fight scene where he faces Riggs is gritty and intense, where you can feel the two of them trying to bite each other's ears off.I predicted he would stand back up and getting killed for real after Riggie lets him go with the police to arrest him, but the fact that he was shot by *both* partners is what makes it so cool. In trying to overcome each other's differences, they became one and the same. It's pretty odd though how the other cops just stood there and let the fight play out not knowing who will win. Did they think it was so cool they don't care if it went one way or another?The final part is Riggs coming to his now friend's home with a present getting ready to leave right away, but Murtaugh insisting he stays and endures his wife's bad cooking with him. It's apparently so bad they used the joke thrice.As a fan of the genre, this is one of the best in its kind. The action, drama and comedy mix together perfectly and makes it a highly satisfying experience. You can never get too old for this shìt.

reviews.review_title: Typical and now aged 1980s action film
reviews.content:
1987 US cop buddy action movie starring Mel Gibson and Danny Glover.What the film lacks for in artistic merit it makes up for with some quite explosive action sequences.
Produced by Joel Silver such action films became the norm in the late 1980s.Gibson and Glover play homicide detectives Martin Riggs and Roger Murtaugh. Recently made a cop partnership they fight a gang of heroin smugglers.Riggs is suicidal (haunted by the death of his wife ala Mel Gibson in Mad Max) and Murtaugh is the sane family man who has just celebrated his fiftieth birthday.The soundtrack by the late composer Michael Kamen is a lazy copy of some of his other work before and after (Rita, Sue and Bob Too! and Licence To Kill spring to mind) although some guitar chords from Eric Clapton can be heard.The director Richard Donner was more famous for 1978 film Superman.Gary Busey plays the menacing bad guy long before he was relegated to Z list celebrity status on reality TV shows. Busey was quite good in the role.References of US involvement in the Vietnam War are made as we learn that Riggs was a Special Forces operative in the conflict.A good early evening actioner. I am to old for this!

reviews.review_title: A high-water mark in mismatched buddy cop action comedies.
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon is perhaps the easiest Gibson vehicle to like and one of the best "mismatched buddy cop" films in history.Jaded vet Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) has just hit the big 5-ohhhh, with three kids and a mortgage, when he is partnered with Martin Riggs (Gibson), a younger, psychotic - and very likely suicidal - drunk struggling to move on from his wife's death. Riggs lives in a trailer on the beach with a dog as his only companion, and he has a myriad of techniques and skills in the art of killing, a crack shot with pistol or rifle and a martial artist, let's just say.The new pair are investigating the death of a young blonde woman who leapt to her death from a tall building, landing on a car below, which I only bring up to ask if anyone who ever jumped from a tall building DIDN'T land on a car? Regardless the young girl was a prostitute who more than dabbled in drugs and porn, and she was the daughter of one of Roger's buddies from Vietnam. It is discovered that her drugs were laced with poison and if she didn't jump from the building she would have died very soon in any case.Roger relays this new information to the father, who makes it very clear that regardless of Roger's badge and job description he wants the people responsible D.E.D.D.Pausing only to "jump a jumper" and to ponder the worth of his life, Riggs and Murtaugh are on the case...Being an 80s movie the plot is complex but not unnecessarily convoluted, the duo rapidly learn that they are up against a team of extremely dangerous mercenaries who intend to make a large shipment of heroin in only a few days, the team are led by the General and his loyal 2IC "Mr Joshua" (Gary Busey), who as well as being a crack soldier is perhaps the equal of Riggs in the insanity stakes.The mercenaries are vicious and brutal, and they target anyone in their way or anyone who might pose a threat, they quickly decide that Riggs and Murtaugh are both. Thankfully Riggs and Murtaugh are equally determined to deal with them and have no intention of running away. Each of them even get their own personal nemesis to "off" in the finale.After the initial wariness and friction Riggs and Murtaugh gradually develop a bond, which by the end of the film is already an easy chemistry. There are many setpieces that are extremely effective and some cool 80s stuntwork and driving sequences.This film wasn't as worried about the comedy elements as the sequels so it doesn't try so hard, but as a result the jokes work a little better, and of course they are often thrown around in the middle of crisis situations.Lethal Weapon is one of the better preserved classics of the 80s, it has aged very well and aside from being a little slow at times in comparison to today's action flicks it stands up against any film of the last decade and features a cast full of bit actors from half of the films made in the decade. The reasonably straightforward plot is a plus - the good guys are good and the bad guys need plugging full of holes - and the action to comedy ratio is just in favour of the action.As it should be.I said to my wife that Riggs is Gibson's Rambo or Rocky, and if you think he hasn't strongly considered dragging him out of retirement to attempt to rebuild his image you're nuts. I then joked (repeat: JOKED) that given his tirades in the last few years Riggs would take on a group of Jewish criminals... then turn the gun on Roger.If that sounds off-colour it is more a reflection of Gibson than anything else.I wouldn't watch Lethal Weapon 5; but I must (begrudgingly) admit that the original Lethal Weapon is a great flick.Final Rating - 8.5 / 10. One of the best buddy cop action flicks. Well paced with big explosions, car chases, snappy quips and a high body count. Immensely entertaining.

reviews.review_title: It's aged. It's fun. It worth a watch.
reviews.content: This is a fun good cop, bad cop movie that hasn't aged too well. The characters are pretty fun and likable, and you can clearly see their motivations well. I really like Riggs' depression and suicide motif, and how that affects him in the first part of the movie. The villain was pretty fun too, although their history is a little weird and shaky with the Vietnam connection. The reason it's a little dated is just because of the situations they get themselves into. The dry lake action scenes feels very one-sides: it was two dudes against 20 and a helicopter, and the two dudes held their own. The torture scene was pretty okay as far as Riggs goes (with the electrical shock) but Murtagh was literally just have salt rubbed into wounds. Don't get me wrong, that's hurts, but compared to modern day torture scenes in movies it just seems comical. Finally, the last scene where a Riggs (a cop) bare knuckle fights the villain while 40 cops watch and Murtagh yells at them to stay back just feels... wrong? Silly? Completely out of character for a police department? It's good to show that Riggs has changed (because he didn't kill the dude, at first at least) but it just feels like that isn't at all what any sort of law enforcement would do. The suspension of disbelief in this wasn't needed in any enough in any other scenes, but was really needed in these. I will day though, the camera work is 👌🏻. It feels alive. The camera always seems to be moving, which is really cool. Furthermore, the focus on the DOF on some shots was sooo shallow, and even the ones in motion was crystal sharp. Really good shot selection. It was still fun, but it just felt a little dated.

Cartooney and naive as funk, but why not? I have to admit I had a few drinks before watching though. Gibson and Glover's chemistry is the greatest strength of the film. Hilariously dated action aside, the only thing that really bothered me is the inconsistency with the tone. I have nothing against black comedy and brainless action, but the first bunch of scenes with a girl jumping off a balcony and suicidal Martin Riggs mourning his wife felt a bit out of place.

reviews.review_title: You should watch the quadrilogy in a row
reviews.content:
Yep, you should watch all 4 movies in a row, and you will discover:
ConsistencyEvolution of the personae, but they are still themselvesNo plot hole in their own story/history (because it's the same producer)Over al it's Action packed, very funny, good acting and dialogues over all 4 movies!

reviews.review_title: One of my favorite films ever.
reviews.content: Danny Glover and Mel Gibson give the best performances of their careers in the instant classic Lethal weapon. Though I love this movie so much because Mel Gibson is bad ass and they are both very funny and the action is great, this is going to be a short review for this film. Just know that it's great.Do I like this film as much as Die Hard? No, but I thought that both were great films series'. Mel Gibson plays Riggs, a cop with a death wish. Danny Glover plays Martaugh, a cop with a family. The two of them are assigned to each other. But they both have one thing in common. They hate being assigned partners. The two of them have to take down drug dealers. Though not too much to the plot, but the film is fantastic.Lethal weapon:****/****

reviews.review_title: Lethal Weapon is the ultimate buddy-cop film.
reviews.content: Murtaugh (Glover), is a hard working family man. Riggs (Gibson) is a suicidal maniac. They both hate working with others. Their differences cause major rifts. Their bickering, squabbling and conflicting ideals make their current objective a thrilling experience. The story is simple, but strong, the leads cops driving it until the end credits. Murtaugh's anger towards Riggs is funny. On the flip side Riggs's troubled past is touching. It dips a little in to dark comedy, but not so much that it takes away what emotion it carries. Murtaugh might be too old for this ..., but we're not. Riggs and his partner are characters that stick around, more so than John McClane or Axel Foley.

Who would have though gibson and glover would be a pairing that would work. Clearly those that made the film knew they were onto something and the result is something very great. They both bounce off one another's personalities very well and the way the movie is structured is cleaver. Showing riggs as a bit of a mess and murtof as someone with his stuff together but in the end both have something in common, they are bad ass as cops. I also enjoyed gary buseys role here and he worked as a villiab well. Overall a very enjoyble buddy cop movie with some great one liners. A great cast and crew and a great start to the series.

reviews.review_title: A steady buddy cop movie, featuring suspense, humour, and two likable leads
reviews.content: This 80's action movie, starring Mel Gibson and Danny Glover, both famous actors I'm familiar with, was released about half a year after I was born, and since it's an R-rated movie, it obviously would have been quite a while before I would ever get to see it. 22 years later, after being aware of the existence of this movie and its sequels for only a short while (I guess that's because I came across copies of them in the video store more than once), I've finally seen it. "Lethal Weapon" was obviously a success, since it spawned three sequels, and knowing how popular it was, I was expecting a decent action thriller. I could have found the film absolutely stunning, which I didn't, but for the most part, it is an impressive buddy cop movie.Roger Murtaugh (Glover) has been working for the L.A.P.D. for quite a long time, and has just reached his 50th birthday. He is informed of the death of Amanda Hunsaker, who fell from her apartment. She was the daughter of Michael Hunsaker, a man who was friends with Roger when they fought in Vietnam, but they haven't seen each other in twelve years. So, the L.A.P.D. detective is assigned to investigate, and is assigned a partner for this investigation, a younger L.A.P.D. detective named Martin Riggs (Gibson). Riggs has been mentally unstable and suicidal since the death of his wife in an accident, and he takes unusually high risks while on the job! It turns out that Amanda was poisoned, so the two cops are to find out who is responsible. Their mission, which won't be made any easier by their conflicting personalities, leads them to a group of drug-smuggling mercenaries! Not everything about this movie thoroughly impressed me. The intro is a bit bland, showing a moving overhead view through the city put to "Jingle Bell Rock". It then goes to Amanda Hunsaker, showing the character on her fateful night, and this sequence also could have been done better. Jackie Swanson didn't do the best job in this very brief role, even though she apparently performed her own stunt, which was obviously an accomplishment. So, there may be some dull moments, but to make up for that, there is a lot of action and suspense, and while the dialogue may be flawed at times, I've heard worse. So many people have praised this film for the two leads, and I'm going to have to join them. Danny Glover and Mel Gibson do make a good team, both playing memorable characters with depth. (Yes, I know I'm not the first to point that out.) Putting a lot of action in a movie isn't necessarily going to make it good, but with the two leads, along with some humour, "Lethal Weapon" doesn't rely entirely on action for entertainment value. For that reason, I can see why this 1987 blockbuster was such a big hit.

reviews.review_title: Not just good action in the film; there is some good characterization
reviews.content: The movie had a wide variety of action and that is why I love it....from explosions (especially when Murtaugh and Riggs almost walk right into a house that blows up) and car chase scenes to shoot-outs and martial arts fights.Well, Riggs' character is very, very crazy. Especially when Murtaugh says to him that Riggs came from the special forces in the war in Vietnam. The reason for the craziness is clear--the Vietnam War caused the whole United States to protest Americans who fought in it. And especially when he faces off with something ripped-out of the headlines from the Columbine high school shooting in the director's cut version....a crazed man at a school firing randomly with an automatic weapon, and Riggs, in a very high-risk move, moves towards the line of fire at the shooter, plays a game of "you missed the target" to confuse the shooter, and finally knocks him dead with his 9mm at close range. Or even more, when Riggs hammers his head himself with his fists--as if his head was some type of drum------in front of his first perpetrator and then without warning points his 9mm at him--and surprise is Riggs' way of arresting perpetrators (because he uses unusual diversions).The scene involving Riggs and a suicidal man on a roof who wants to jump to their death tells more about Riggs' character....Riggs loves to talk fast, and, as mentioned before, he loves surprises, especially when he handcuffs the suicidal man without even telling him......and their famous jump off the roof into an awaiting safety mat is almost like the movie "Hooper", which gives you a gist of how a Hollywood stunt person lives with one's work.During the torture scene, where Endo shocks Riggs with about 600 volts of electricity over a shower raining on Riggs, I had seen why there was water. They say water and electricity don't mix. Doubly exciting was the part where Joshua tortures Murtaugh by attempting to break his left arm....and the intercutting camera work on both of the tortured characters.The final climax shows why police officers use handcuffs on their arrestees...here, you think Joshua is down for the count after the final fight with Riggs as he is dragged side-by-side by police officers without handcuffs. There was very good editing work on Joshua's sudden act of wrestling away one of the officer's guns and Riggs's 9mm and Murtaugh's .38 finally finishing him off...probably the only time in all four of the "Lethal Weapon" movies where the two main characters shoot their guns at the same time. The film speed at that point was about 1/4 speed as if you are fast-forwarding on 1/4 speed on your DVD remote.

reviews.review_title: Makers of Die Hard watched this
reviews.content: Predating Die Hard by a year!This is pretty heavy on the profanities and violence.A bit cliched now, veteran cop gets a new wild partner.Not really much in the way of a story. Just good guys and bad guys.

Mel Gibson stars as a cop on the edge who teams up with a straight-arrow, down-to-earth cop(Danny Glover) to take on Mr.Joshua (Gary Busey) who leads a pack of drug smugglers in this over the top yet enjoyable movie. I must admit i've always been a bigger fan of 48 HRS and Lethal Weapon 2 over this movie, mainly due to the fact that the plot is far duller and the action sequences not quite as spectacular as the fore-mentioned titles. Still there is plenty to like here, as Gary Busey makes a great villain, Gibson and Glover share excellent chemistry and basically the movie is directed with an excellent eye for detail. It just lacks that extra something that made 48 HRS and its sequel better. Still I say it's worth a look, and by far one of the best in the genre, especially when compared to the extremely dull Red Heat and Tango and Cash. Also the movie has a great hostage negotiation sequence, although as far as Mel Gibson movies go, I'll always be more partial to the Mad Max movies. But that's just me.* * * out of 4-(Good)

Richard Donner's film did great.  I don't remember it from when it came out, because I was only 1.  But, it is a great cop movie, unlike some of todays cop movies.  The part at the end was hilarious  when Busey reads the note on the Christmas tree, and a car crashes through the front room window.  It is great, that's why I gave it 9 out of 10.

classic case, of two cops who are forced to work together and hate each other but tend to make a good match. Lots of action, a very good plot with some good twists but the interaction between the main characters was the best thing and turned out to be very funny. Even though it doesn't lose its seriousness that way, it reminds of the classic buddy cop series/movies of that era. For example starsky and hutch, tango and cash and so on. Generally a very good and enjoyable movie which keeps you interested and haves some cheesiness from the 80s. Mel Gibson is awesome as well, at first he did gave the impression of the main star but, Danny Glover, a new face to me, proved to be an interesting character and of almost equal importance to Mel Gibson, though the story is mainly built around his environment at start. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes cop movies filled with some good amount of high quality action.

The buddy cop movie formula seems to have been around for a while, but one could argue that Lethal Weapon is the film that devised this formula. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover star as two cops who reluctantly work together to stop a group of drug smugglers. They have wildly different personalities that are constantly clashing, as are their methods of doing the same job. Gibson plays Martin Riggs, an unhinged officer with suicidal tendencies, while Glover plays Roger Murtagh, a family man and a veteran cop. The two make a charming pair that make for a fun and explosively entertaining film.Lethal Weapon is very simple and very straightforward. It is, after all, just a formula film. There's nothing astounding or jaw dropping about the film, but it is a lot of fun. It's the quintessential buddy cop film, no matter how standard and ordinary the buddy cop genre is. The story about drug smugglers brings nothing new to the table. It's very simple, but thankfully not dull.All that a good buddy cop movie can really depend on is the chemistry in its two leads, as there's not much more going for this genre most of the time. Lethal Weapon succeeds on this front. Gibson and Glover are great together. Their characters are believable and seeing them work together is a lot of fun. It's clear they had a fun time working on the film together as they give their respective performances their all. I have zero respect for Mel Gibson these days for obvious reasons, but I was even able to find him enjoyable in this film. He and Glover are excellent, and are essentially the only thing that makes Lethal Weapon a worthwhile watch.If you love buddy cop movies then this is a must see. If you're indifferent towards the genre, like me, then you may or may not want to invest two hours of your life towards Lethal Weapon. I have no regrets, but I couldn't see myself watching this film again.

reviews.review_title: I ain't too old for this sh.. yet and I won't be for quite a while!
reviews.content:
This is a classic action flick and together with Die Hard from 1988 and Indiana Jones from 1981 and 1984, these 4 films have invented action as we know it today, great action scenes, great direction and comic scenes mixed with a bit of true feelings (like Mr. Action (producer), Jerry Bruckheimer tends to do often). This ain't the best one thou, the best one is part 3, then 1, 2, and at last 4 (that one's not too bad either, but just a tag too corny sometimes), but this really is a good movie + it is a classic, so go and see it. 
8 out of 10

reviews.review_title: One of my all time favs
reviews.content: Staring Mel Gibson, Danny glover how can it be bad! There's never a moment that I'm bored rewatching this film. I'm either entranced in the great action or smiling at the heartwarming moments of the two cops. It's got to be near my top 3 favorite movies ever.

This movie is one of the best action-comedy movies of all-time. It was incredible. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are a perfect team in this movie. A young man who wants to commit suicide because his wife dies and a older man who has a family for a long time is not a good mix. Put these two together and destruction is bound to happen. My favorite scene in this movie is when Mel Gibson was on top of the building with a guy who is about to jump off and Mel Gibson handcuffs himself to the other man and jumps off together. He thought it was fun but the other guy was going insane. I think that particular scene shows how crazy and determined the character Martin Riggs really is. The non-stop action was incredible. The ending was full of high quality action that will keep you at the edge of your seat the whole time. Mel Gibson was incredible at the ending. Danny Glover was also full of surprises as well. I give Lethal Weapon **** out of ****. It was a classic movie and I recommend this movie to all viewers who like non-stop action and comedy and are Mel Gibson fans because this was by far Mel Gibson's most classical movie he made besides the movie Braveheart which he won an oscar for Best Director. Lethal Weapon gets TWO THUMBS WAY UP!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: Sets the standard for the many "buddy cop" flicks that followed
reviews.content: Although there had been others before,this "buddy cop" film is the one people probably most refect back on,when they see one like it today.This teaming of a middle aged veteran cop(Danny Glover),and the mentally troubled recently widowed Martin Riggs(Mel Gibson),is the one that sets the standard for the many that have followed since,including it's three sequels.The chemistry between Glover and Gibson is terrific,and the story is indeed compelling,with Murtaugh(Glover),finding himself at odds with a former Vietnam war buddy whose daughter has just been murdered.A great villanous performance here by Gary Busey as Mr. Joshua. It has just enough appeal to be an entertaining film,though it has it's violent moments which of course children should be shielded from.Thumbs up!

Lethal Weapon is an unfortunate act on Donner's part to return to his television roots.
