Everything from the camera set-up to his visualization of action comes straight from a range of ideas whether they are The Three Stooges, Miami Vice, CHiPs, or Looney Tunes.Danny Glover and Mel Gibson are unique in this line of thought.  Glover plays it serious, Gibson plays for laughs.  Part of this is Shane Black's fault for concocting such an absurd concept, but this is marginally better than more recent trash like Lethal Weapon 4 and Bad Boys.Thankfully, Donner sees the satire in the script and proceeds to have some fun, cathartic moments such as Gibson and Busey destroying TVs at either end of the movie.  I found the latter to be more enjoyable, I've always wanted to do that.Overall, not as good as you'd think.  The soundtrack is awful and the cinematography is not a versed as The Omen or Die Hard.  Donner has done better.  2.5 out of 5 stars.

"Lethal Weapon" is another buddy cop movie but with a rare pairing of substance and quality. The plot is very straightforward and surprisingly makes sense. The action hardly ever stops, and the cross-culture jokes and one-liners add humour to the film. While that may be all well and good, It's Gibson and Glover's performances as two like-minded cops with an unlikely friendship who win us over with trigger-happy enthusiasm.It's about a young girl who dives out a window in an apparent suicide. When it's investigated closer, it turns out to be a homicide. Ageing cop, Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) is partnered with a volatile cop, Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) who is transferred from Naraciotis to homicide. Together they discover something bigger than a suicide that will test with limits as partners and friends.It opens to the wintery tune of Jingle Bell Rock before a woman decides to swan dive out of her hotel window on a dark night. Murtaugh is assigned to the case and he discovers the girl who jumped is only the tip of the iceberg but also has a connection that puts Murtaugh in touch with an old companion from the Vietnam war, the girl's father, Michael Hunsacker (Tom Atkins). That's basically the setup, a murder investigation with a few unexpected twists. Riggs comes into the movie when he ends up transferred because nobody wants to work with him. After he meets Murtaugh, they initially hate each other but develop mutual respect when Riggs saves Murtaugh's life and they bond over the violence in their pasts and he gives Riggs someone to talk to.Riggs is a suicidal hot dog whose developed a tendency since his wife was killed in a car crash and he blames himself for it. He carries a hollow point bullet that he tends to use on himself the moment the job doesn't do it for him anymore. He's considered a burnout on the ragged edge and a psycho but he is more of a criminal's worst nightmare than anything. There is a scene early on in the film that has Riggs load the special bullet into a 9mm Baretta and in a flurry of tears, he puts the barrel in his mouth and begs himself to pull the trigger. It gives you a reason to care about him and understand him. He's a martial arts expert, a sharpshooter and a "lethal weapon" hence the title of the film with a shot at black humour. Murtaugh on the other hand has just celebrated his 50th birthday. He is the middle-class good cop family man who begins to lose faith in himself due to his age and he's close to retirement. When we first see him, he is in a bathtub and ribbed by his wife and kids for his age. Just like Riggs, it shows the vulnerability of the characters.Richard Donner as the director and Shane Black as the screenwriter together make a fierce pair. They keep the movie wound tight and the tone is frenetic with surrealistic violence but it's balanced between the action sequences. When Riggs saves Murtaugh, he invites him to his home for dinner and you can see the sadness in Riggs's eyes as he admires Murtaugh's family and his new friend. You can also see that while Riggs is broken on the inside, after meeting Murtaugh, he becomes more lively when around him and the prominent scene of Riggs starting to find a new meaning is when he brings Murtaugh coffee and says "Come on. You gotta get up so we can catch bad guys." Murtaugh gets grumpy as he is comically forced out of bed.It all comes down to the two cops discovering what is going on and the villains appear because the cops are hot on their trail. One of them is a bright eye hateful killer, Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey) and the other is the stereotypical bad guy who is the leader and barks orders, Peter Macallister (Mitchell Ryan). Rather than just explain everything, Riggs and Murtaugh have to piece it all together which makes it exciting. When a house explodes and Riggs finds something he hasn't seen since the war, it makes them wonder what they are up against and these are the suspenseful moments that build up the film. An unexpected kidnapping sets up the third act where Murtaugh must turn to Riggs for help and it gets quite intense. You may be able to figure out the ending because it's an action film with a few surprises in an otherwise redundant story but there's a little more to it than you might expect and that's what makes the film chug along with a full chamber with buses crashing, cars exploding and non-stop gunfire. The most appealing are two characters that will be admired for many years to come.

reviews.review_title: I prefer Lethal Weapon to Die Hard!
reviews.content: The first time I watched Lethal Weapon, I liked it without thinking to much of it but after watching the sequels, I really wanted to see the first again. It is now possibly my favorite action movie. Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) is a suicidal recluse and loose canon after the death of his wife while Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) is a family man who just celebrated his 50th birthday and is a character most can relate to. They eventually get partnered up, neither of them wanting to work with the other as Riggs (Gibson) makes it clear that no one wants to work with him as some think he's faking the suicidal thing to draw a psycho pension and others believe he really is suicidal. They get sent to work on a case involving the suicidal of a prostitute who's father just so happens to be an old Vietnam war buddy of Murtaugh (Glover) and is involved in a heroin-smuggling operation which leads to some top-notch action. As I said, I am one of a few people who prefer this movie to Die Hard as an action Christmas movie.

The biggest American film in the Hollywood action would have to be Die Hard, and honestly, I can't disagree. But it was about a year before that this film came out and it packs serious action. The cast gives good performances and Donner's direction is tight and effective. The script from Shane Black set a big standard for Hollywood action movies. I guess Die Hard is more popular because of it's spectacular scenes, Lethal Weapon is more gritty; the opening scene shows a naked cokehead prostitute jumping off of a balcony on to a car roof, later Riggs' thinks about suicide, and there are notions of drugs and torture. However the grimness works for the movie and makes it rough and tough like a classic thriller should be. 8/10

The first and best of the Lethal Weapon series sees Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) meet his new partner Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson. Murtaugh's just celebrated his 50th birthday so to get a new dangerous partner is the last thing he needs. To start with Murtaugh doesn't trust Riggs but soon starts to mellow to his new partner, especially on their new case about heroin shipments. The main baddie is of course Gary Busey as the mad Joshua. When Murtaugh's daughter Rianne (Traci Wolfe) is kidnapped by Busey and the General (Mitchell Ryan) our buddy cops come to the rescue, a great fight at the end between Riggs and Joshua is well choreographed.This is one of the best buddy cop films ever made and even the sequels weren't too bad.

I remember when I was growing up and I loved pointless action flicks and the Lethal Weapon franchise was by far my favorite series. It beats die hard by a long shot which is the movie this was competing against a lot in the 80s.Mel Gibson and Danny Glover do a great job as very believable partners they have great chemistry.This movie is about a older cop named murtaugh(Glover) who is given a new suicidal off the wall partner named Riggs(Gibson). They both hate working with a partner but they must put their differences aside so they can stop a group of drug smugglers.I know the story is really nothing new actually back in those days it was quite original and groundbreaking. But even for today this movie still holds up because for its day it had some great production values.

Veteran cop Glover and young suicidal cop Gibson are paired together (and mismatched) to stop mastermind heroin-smuggler Ryan and his fearless goon Busey, with the former two using their dislike in partnerships and hatred for drugs as a bond to take down the latter two. Intense and edgy for its time; but with very little substance, it s now just another buddy-cop action-comedy that came from the 1980s. First movie to feature a cellular phone; however, its Gibson's mullet that seems more ancient than anything. A classic to many for being fun, witty and thriller; but it is ultimately a ride comprised of two-dimensional characters with a one-dimensional backstory, only to be thrown in a cliché conflict.**½ (out of four)

Lethal Weapon is a fantastic movie. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are great actors, they are the best in this movie, i think they are great working together. I give this movie 10 out of 10 because i think it is such a fantastic movie.

reviews.review_title: Too much action, not enough laughs - uneven mediocre effort
reviews.content:
All the clichés meet here: this film is undeniably an 80's action flick. It's got the cop one-two punch, that light crime atmosphere and intrigue revolving around a death (suicide...or not ?), cheap campy laughs and lengthy action scenes, soundtrack full of saxophone or bluesy reverb guitars, the "I'm too old for this s*it !" line and a very (too) obvious divide between the good guys fighting the good fight versus the definite bad guys.They really could've used lots more of the comedic potential between a completely insane (like, more than usual) and unleashed Mel Gibson and his black older counterpart Danny Glover whose characters are both likable in their own different ways, naturally. There are at least two full action scenes that seem endless and feel pointless after a certain point where if you're not a fanatic of explosions and electric-paced successive bursts of motion you're probably going to feel every second of them pretty quickly. Too much action - not enough laughs. That's for sure. It's too uneven barring that anyways. The film settles itself nicely at the beginning, develops decently as we get to know more about the plot and the lead characters (how great a shot Mel Gibson really is, etc) but then those monolithic chunks of action... it's too disparate in how much humor is supplied, how much action was needed, and the plot wears thin way too soon.
Finally the film is also quite politicized: the 'black and white partners make nice' rationale, the apartheid sign on the fridge that's well emphasized... it's not just an innocent little comedy-action flick, there's real underlying social commentary here.Not good enough, it doesn't matter how slightly more semi-original it was when it came out in 1987: 5/10.

reviews.review_title: Has Aged Well, Still A Great Action/Buddy Flik
reviews.content: 30+ years have passed since its release and it still stands out as a great action / buddy movie. Good acting, good chemistry, good production values, and a plausible story ( well, for a cop/buddy picture), and the start, really, of Gary Busey's career as a bad guy all add up to a really enjoyable movie that is still very watchable & enjoyable today.

reviews.review_title: An excellent action movie that is still enjoyable today.
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon makes a dynamic impact on the action buddy cop genre. Take two mismatched cops and make them reluctant partners, and as their relationship forms they go up against the bad guys and take them down. It's an 80's movie through and through, but it's still an enjoyable movie today. The best thing about Lethal Weapon is that it's not a "leave your brain at the door" action movie with gunplay, fights and explosions that ignores the story. It's not a movie with action for the sake of action, and it certainly not a movie that relies on an endless body count. The action and violence fits in perfectly with the story to make it believable as the movie flows very smoothly. Lethal Weapon makes its name as a great action movie that never stops, interesting well rounded characters, crackling and witty dialogue with occasional moments of humour, excellent cinematography, and a fully fleshed out story with excellent attention to detail.The movie starts with Jingle Bell Rock playing over the opening credits as the camera pans over the blue tinted Los Angeles skyline at night. The mood quickly changes when Amanda Hunsaker (Jackie Swanson) leaps to her death from her apartment balcony which forms the basis of the story. Sergeant Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) investigates the apparent suicide and he later finds out that Amanda Hunsaker is the daughter of Michael Hunsaker (Tom Atkins), a former Vietnam Veteran that Roger served with during the war. At the same time, we are introduced to Sergeant Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson), a crazy, wild eyed rebel with a death wish following the death of his wife in a car accident in 1984. Martin Riggs has lost the will to live and often takes wild risks, hoping he will die in the line of duty. Riggs and Murtaugh are polar opposites. Roger Murtaugh has just celebrated his 50th birthday and he is a proud family man at heart. He is also a conservative by-the-book police detective who is also considering retirement after 20 years with the Los Angeles Police Department. Martin Riggs is a police detective with a wild suicidal streak who is not afraid to put himself in harms way. He has attempted suicide but decides against it as he hopes to end his misery in the line of duty. Riggs has also served in the Vietnam War and was a former US Army Special Forces soldier specialising as a trained killer. These skills have served him well as well as his psychotic behaviour which gives him a dangerous edge against his enemies. Following serious concerns about Riggs' wild behaviour, he is transferred from Narcotics to Homicide and partnered with Murtaugh. Though they resent each other at first, their partnership grows solid throughout the movie, and also giving Martin Riggs a new lease on life. Amanda Hunsaker's suicide turns out not to be the case as the trail leads Riggs and Murtaugh to a heroin smuggling syndicate operated by a former Special Forces group named Shadow Company which operated during the Vietnam War. Shadow Company is made up of a gang of mercenaries led by ex-military General Peter McAllister (Mitchell Ryan) and his chief enforcer and right hand man Mr Joshua (Gary Busey). Riggs and Murtaugh take on McAllister and Mr Joshua when they declare war through the streets of Los Angeles.Besides Braveheart and Mad Max, Lethal Weapon is one of Mel Gibson's best movies. Mel Gibson's role as Martin Riggs is certainly one to remember. His character is psychotic and unstable like a powder keg waiting to explode, but he also brings a comedic side to Riggs with a love of The Three Stooges. Danny Glover is tailor made to the role of Roger Murtaugh, a sensible police detective and a proud family man at heart. Gary Busey's role as the intimidating enforcer Mr Joshua made him a great villain. Believe it or not, this was Gary Busey's first role as a villain which has seen him cast as the villain such as Under Siege (1992) and Drop Zone (1994) or a crazed character such as Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (1998), and also lends his voice in Grand Theft Auto: Vice City (2002).Richard Donner previously directed The Omen (1976) and Superman (1978) and had cemented his reputation as a reliable director. Richard Donner created an unbeatable chemistry with Lethal Weapon and there has not been a movie that has been able to beat it. He has also since carried on with the chemistry with a further three sequels. Writer Shane Black found himself in high demand for action movies following the success of Lethal Weapon and since then, he has written The Last Boy Scout (1991) and The Long Kiss Goodnight (1996) and received a record setting sum of money for his work. He has proved he is not just a pretty face as an actor appearing as Hawkins in Predator (1987) and small roles here and there, as well as striking success as a director with Kiss Kiss Bang Bang (2005) and Iron Man 3 (2013). Producer Joel Silver also can add Lethal Weapon to his long list of box office blockbusters along with 48 Hrs (1982), Predator (1987), Die Hard (1988), The Matrix (1999), and Sherlock Holmes (2009).There have been numerous "buddy cop" movies that have been released since Lethal Weapon, and numerous movies such as but not limited to Tango & Cash (1989), The Rookie (1990), Bad Boys (1995) and its sequel Bad Boys II (2003), The Glimmer Man (1996), The Other Guys (2010), and The Heat (2013) do not hold a candle to Lethal Weapon or any of its sequels.Lethal Weapon is still an enjoyable action movie years later, and the magic continues with Riggs and Murtaugh returning in Lethal Weapon 2 (1989), Lethal Weapon 3 (1992), and Lethal Weapon 4 (1998). Definitely a must see for all fans of action movies.9/10.

reviews.review_title: One of the best Hollywood action movies ever
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon became a very popular movie and spawned three sequels and a thousand copycats.  The movie is about the two cops Riggs and Murtaugh, and their battles against a huge crime syndicate.  The movie is a great mix of well-balanced action and comedy.  The action scenes are elegantly directed by Richard Donner, who`s also responsible for the three sequels. This is one of the best and most innovative action-movies around today. 9/10

Mel Gibson + Danny Glover=Brilliant ChemistryBrilliant Chemistry times Richard Donner=Brilliant TeamBrilliant Team divided by Shane Black's script=A brilliant action film with great performances, characters, direction, and a great cast.3 1/2(***1/2)out of 4(****)stars

Two cops are assigned to investigate a drug dealer. One of them, Roger Murtaugh (Dany Glover) is a gentle, middle-aged family man who goes by the rule-book. The other, Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) is young, unorthodox and somewhat suicidal. They don't like working together initially but become the best of friend by the end of the movie. Yes, it is a formula seen on screen many times and this movie knows it. Thus, it does not try to convince us that it is something new. Instead it concentrates on entertaining us. Both the lead characters are well- written and have interesting backgrounds. Glover and Gibson do a good job of bringing them to life. They share a very good chemistry throughout the movie. The supporting characters, especially Murtaugh's family, are a lot of fun. The dialog is witty and there are many clever and funny moments. It has a bit of pointless nudity. I guess they were trying to make it look edgy. Apart from that, the knows its scope and sticks to it.

reviews.review_title: Lethal Weapon — A mold for modern law enforcement action flick
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon is now a classic of law enforcement action, and at its release, it put Mel Gibson on the map.The good. Plenty of action. Great main characters. Nice intrigue. Interesting story. Very well paced scenario.The actors. Mel Gibson is definitively the best of the bunch as the crazy suicidal Martin Riggs. Danny Glover is pretty good too as his more conservative partner Roger Murtaugh who has a heart of gold and hidden depths of ruthlessness.The bad. The age of the movie is showing in a number of places, but not too much. Still pretty acceptable. The bad guys have no depth at all.The ugly. The actor playing the jumper is just terrible.The result. Excellent action geared entertainment if you can get past the age.

reviews.review_title: The Golden Age of Action Film's
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon, an undisputed classic of the action genre featuring amazing performances, sharp script and some great action. But the real success comes off with the amazing chemistry between Gibson and Glover. The eighties was a great time for the action genre, just to name a few classics, Batman, Predator, Aliens, Die Hard, Terminator, all of which where phenomenally successful and have shaped the action genre right up until this day. I was able to watch all these films from about age six, which means i basically grew up watching these films, they contain probably some of the greatest memories from my childhood, Lethal Weapon was one of those movies i could relate to, due to my life circumstances. Regardless of my own opinion of the film, It really is a classic of the Action genre, anyone who was captivated by the eighties golden age will have surely watched this film, pure magic. Highly Recommended!

reviews.review_title: Best buddy cop movie there is
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon to me is one of the best buddy cop movie that I have seen, the combination of Sgt Martin Riggs and Sgt Roger Murtaugh is one of the best character pairing when it comes to this genre and we were given the honor to see this paring done by first class actors in Mel Gibson and Danny Glover. This movie combines high tense action with humor that makes you want to see more of these guys, as it ends you just find yourself desiring that it didn't. From the very beginning this casting was set from someone high in heaven, because according to Wikipedia Casting director Marion Dougherty first casting suggestion was Mel Gibson and Danny Glover, which ended up being what we saw on screen.They were both like a diamond in a rock, one an all-round good guy with a family man consisting of 3 children and the other a widower with suicidal intentions and nothing to live for until he met the first. These were Murtaugh and Riggs respectively and if you think you can cross any of these guys and just walk away you got another thing coming.The first of the four series is this one which was released in 1987; it stands as the introduction piece of how Murtaugh and Riggs met, and how they bonded. Murtaugh (Danny Glover) at that time was 50 years of age enjoying the life of being a straight shooter cop until he got partnered with a younger suicidal cop Riggs (38 at that time) (Mel Gibson) who no one wants to work with. Now both guys who are like a mix of crazy and normal must learn to work with one another to stop a gang of drug smugglers.As easy as this may sound on paper it wasn't on screen, as we get to go through scenes after scenes of both parties ready to do what it takes to get the job done. The music score in this movie is one that you will love as it was done by Michael Kamen and Eric Clapton. The Jazz feel is just exquisite, moving ahead my favorite scene in the movie; "Spoiler Alert" is where Riggs convinced a man that was going to jump to appreciate living. He did this by making the man live up to his word when he was threatening to jump, Riggs made him jump.After this the duo went ahead to make 3 other films similar to this and they from my point of view were just as beautiful as this one was.www.lagsreviews.com

reviews.review_title: You're never too old for this!
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon is the ultimate buddy cop action movie. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover's chemistry delights as the crazed young gun and the old experienced cop grow to respect and trust each other. Mel Gibson gives another iconic performance in his catalog of outstanding characters as the quirky and lovable but traumatizing Martin Riggs struggling to find a reason to hope. Danny Glover's grouchy but endearing Roger Murtaugh is a perfect balance to Riggs. The two develop a loyalty throughout the film that makes the audience invest and care. At its core, Lethal Weapon is an epic action movie where the good guys kick some serious butt! For the 80s, this movie raised the bar for the action genre. My only complaint would be the first few minutes have some nudity that, if left out, would have made this a contender for the ultimate holiday action movie.

reviews.review_title: As good as LW4 was bad
reviews.content: "Lethal Weapon" was as good a movie as "Lethal Weapon 4" was bad a movie -- and this is saying a lot!This movie introduced many popular (endlessly copied) story themes and film elements to Hollywood.  Much credit must go to the original Lethal Weapon. It scores a Hollywood 10.

reviews.review_title: watch this movie over and over and over
reviews.content: This is a really cool movie. I've seen it 20 million times already. this is one of the best action movies ever. Mel, and Danny were really cool in this movie. The acting was good. I recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good crime action, comedy, movie.

reviews.review_title: Funny, action packed, excellent cop movie
reviews.content: Take a cop who's lost everything and is not afraid of death, pair him with a 50 year old cop, who has a family and a promising job position and has led a nice life, and you get Lethal Weapon.The pair go up against a gang of drug dealers, led by corrupt former army General Peter MacAllister (Mitch Ryan). MacAllister has a creepy second hand man, Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey), who is hell bent on his task.Luckily, Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) aren't going to let them get away so easily.There are plenty of great scenes and a lot of fun action. You can not watch this without smiling.9/10

Mel Gibson and Danny Glover star in this crackerjack policeflick that made them international stars! Gibson is in top formas Riggs, a suicidal cop who is paired with a methodicaldetective named Murtagh, played by the ever-watchable DannyGlover, to solve the murder of a drug-addicted girl. The two mixlike ice cream and ketchup at first, but they become fastfriends and desperate allies when they discover a sinister drugring is behind the girl's untimely death.Gibson is convincly great as the nutcase Riggs, whose maniclifestyle nearly drives his new partner crazy. Glover is alsoterrific playing Murtagh, trying hard to be patient with hisscrewball of a partner. Gary Busey also stars as Joshua, theevil hitman who is argueably Busey's greatest role he's everplayed. Though the action and violence might tend to be quite gruesome,(especially the torture scenes) I think the violence is a bitprimitive now compared with the stuff shown today. Even still,"Lethal Weapon" is a great, enjoyable action movie, thanks tothe t

Directed by SUPERMAN director, Richard Donner, Lethal Weapon is more than just mindless violence, the characters played by the 2 leads are excellent. Mel Gibson really does shine and his Martin Riggs is quite haunting and disturbing at times. Danny Glover is also good, and he and Mel play off each other really well. Gary Busey shows potential, and probably this is his best role.
The screenplay is surprisingly very well written, the characters are well rounded and their is some depth to some of them but the villains could've deserved more attention. Their motives are too cliche.The finale was a little too long but very well choreographed.Richard Donner certainly showed an eye for direction and the characters, he keeps the film going at a decent pace. I can see why he shot this film in 1:85.1The version I saw was the new director's cut, the extra scenes don't help the film, but worth watching.

***Starring: Mel Gibson, Danny Glover, and Gary Busey.A detective whose been on many excellent jobs before is suddenly teamed up with a cop with a great little death wish.  The movie is lethal from head to toe and is accompanied with flawless performances.  See this and the sequels.

reviews.review_title: Gibson and Glover as a dynamic duo
reviews.content: Mel Gibson stars in this influential (For better or worse) buddy film as a stressed out suicidal cop who is paired up with a set to retire Danny Glover to chase down some bad guys. While paired up the two discover a drug running scheme by some ex special forces men.With plenty of action, violence, explosions, and just the right touch of humor. Lethal Weapon entertains. Gibson and Glover are great together and the presence of Eric Clapton on the soundtrack adds to it. Two sequels followed but as in most cases the first is the best. On a scale of one to ten..8

Despite having one of the lamest titles and tag lines of any successful action movie (and most bad ones) this movie goes far beyond the action genre.The plot is fairly basic. 2 mismatched cops are thrown together. Riggs is young, his wife is dead and is happily breaking every rule in the police man. Murtaugh is an older family man who is just doing the job till his retirement.They get involved in the death of a prostitute, who turns out to be Murtaugh's old army buddy's daughter.What makes this movie different is many fold. Firstly there are a lot of sub plots and issues that tie into the overall story. Such as Riggs suicidal tendencies and his special forces military training. It is not just an ad-on, but forms part of a character arc for Riggs.There is also the police investigation. It is like real police work. Based on guess work, in exact, but no incredible plot twists. Most police work involves arresting the person standing over the dead body with a bloody knife shouting "I did it". This story shows how police try and work through something tricky but solvable by simple good police work.Then there is the action. Other than Mel Gibson pretending he knows Jujitsu the action is both realistic and exciting (no situations where 2 people shoot at each other, only the good guy hits, rather it is about the strategy, the chase and so on).Finally there is the humour. Jokes are understated and perfect for Mel.Oh wait...girls, you get to see Mel's naked bottom.....when he was young and sexy.This movie works at so many different levels (from naked bottoms up to great character development) that it will be enjoyed by many people. Also, do a search online for the movie script and you will see the script writer Shane Black needs to cut down on the coffee.The worst part of this movie is the terrible sequels and carbon copy movies that came later.

reviews.review_title: One Of The Best Action Films Ever Made. An Unforgettable,Landmark Classic.
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon is one of the best Action films ever made that is filled with great direction,intense Action,a great screenplay,excellent acting and a wonderful score making Lethal Weapon one of the all-time great Action movie classics,one of my favorite Action and one of my favorite films period.Set in Los Angeles,CA,Lethal Weapon tells the story of veteran L.A.P.D cop Roger Murtaugh(Danny Glover)who now has to team with suicidal cop Martin Riggs(Mel Gibson)to investigate a homicide while going after a drug cartel. Riggs and Murtaugh now must figure out how to work together and solve the case while at the same time try to get to know one another and figure each other out and Murtaugh get used to Riggs as a Lethal Weapon.Lethal Weapon is one of those Action movie classics that made me fall in love with the Action genre and gave viewers an introduction to one of the greatest film screen duos of all time Riggs and Murtaugh and a masterful introduction to the amazing Lethal Weapon series. Right from the opening credits to the end you are glued to the screen because of the Action,thrills,suspense and memorable characters in the film. I think that one of the reasons Lethal Weapon is such a brilliant film is because the film took the Buddy cop concept of the Action-Comedy Walter Hill classic 48 Hrs and flipped it and instead of being the cop and criminal this time both are cops. It's no coincidence that both Lethal Weapon and 48 Hrs were both co-produced by Joel Silver. Where as the other Lethal Weapon sequels we're light and much more comedic,LW1 is more gritty and dark because LW1 while an Action is also a great character study of Riggs and Murtaugh because the film shows that Riggs is depressed and on the verge of suicide while Murtaugh has to deal with getting older and his new partner Riggs. And while LW is a serious Action film there are moments of funny humor but the Humor is done in a cynical tone and the comedy is not as over the top as the sequels. LW in some way bridged a gap between the Action films of the 70s and 80s and the early 90s by being serious with a dark sense of Humor. That being said I love all of the LW films. The screenplay by Shane Black is brilliant and excellent,well-written and one of the best Action screenplays of all time with Black giving the main characters memorable dialog with some dark humor and giving the two main characters powerful depth. Black would continue writing brilliant Action scripts with Lethal Weapon 2,The Last Boy Scout,The Long Kiss Goodnight and Kiss,Kiss,Bang,Bang. Riggs and Murtaugh are classic characters of Action films and cinema in general. Like any great Action buddy film,Riggs and Murtaugh at first don't like each other and it's not only because the two don't want to work with one another it's also because of how opposite the two are. Riggs is more wild and filled with energy where as Murtaugh is more straight and narrow but as the film goes on Riggs and Murtaugh begin to understand and like each other. Riggs and Murtaugh feel like real characters who not stereotypes but real people that viewers can relate to. It is the difference between the characters that makes Riggs and Murtaugh so great and entertaining and the banter and dialog makes this film and the other LW films so amazing and watchable. I also love the villains in the film and despite the villains not having much screen time they are vicious and dark in the way they do things and leave a huge impression. The film moves at a great pace and never slows down once the Action kicks into high gear The Action scenes in the film are excellent and handled with intensity and white hot suspense and the Action scenes would get better and bigger as the LW films went on. The final 20-30 minutes are among the best endings that you will see in a Action film and it is so thrilling and Action packed that you will barely have time to catch your breath. It is an excellent ending that will stay in you after the film is over and will put a smile on viewers faces.The whole cast is great in their roles. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are excellent and at their best as Martin Riggs and Roger Murtaugh,with Gibson and Glover bringing depth,intensity and great chemistry to their roles. Gary Busey(Joshua) and Mitchell Ryan(The General)are great and menacing as the villains in the film. Tom Atkins is wonderful as Michael Hunsaker,Roger's old friend. Steve Kahan(Capt. Ed Murphy),Mary Ellen Trainor(Psychologist),Ed Ross(Mendez),Darlene Love(Trish Murtaugh),Traci Wolfe(Rianne Murtaugh),Damon Hines(Nick Murtaugh),Ebonie Smith(Carrie Murtaugh),Lycia Naff(Dixie)and Al Leong give good performances as well.The direction by Richard Donner is brilliant,with Donner always moving the camera and giving the film a great style and tone to the film and Donner also does a great job with the Action scenes. Amazing direction by Donner.The score by Eric Clapton and Michael Kamen is masterful,powerful and one of the best scores in an Action film. A great score by Clapton and Kamen. I also loved the use of the classic Christmas song Jingle Bell Rock by Bobby Helms.In final word if you love Action films,Thrillers or films in general I highly suggest you see Lethal Weapon,a masterful start to a great series and a unforgettable Action classic that you can watch again and again. Highly Recommended. 10/10.

Not the best, but close.  This is third in my mind.  Anyway, this movie, is known for its great opening sequence.  A naked chick jumps off a building, and splats on a car (a cheap tactic to keep the people in the theater! :P). After awhile, they found out this girl was drugged up, later, they find out she was poisoned by the drugs, and even later, they found a tape of her in the shower!!!!  This is Rated R if any of you still doubt. So two cops are on this case, and not your likely partner.  One is a 50 year old (Glover) and one is a crazy guy who is on the verge of killing himself (Mel Gibson, just back from those "Mad Max" films, and he is a little "mad" in this movie)  So the two of them are trying to find the drug dealers, led by some fruitcake and is loyal assistant only known as Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey), nice name.  This movie is pretty good, and features an awesome fight in the end between Mel and Busey.  This great action movie gets a 7/10, it has your action, suspense, and even a hint of comedy, but more comes in the sequels. Rated R for nudity, violence, and language.  Most likely appropriate for teens, but mature teens.  This movie does deserve to be watched.

Perhaps the greatest cop film of all time. A true legend and the best film of the 80's hands down, much better than raging bull and once upon a time in America.The returning buddy cop plot does not disappoint with Mel Gibosn in his standout role - same for Danny Glover.Also a great moment in film history - the return to form of the legend Gary Busey. he excellently plays the Brutal assassin Mr Joshua - a role which was made for him to play.The mega hit is an all time great.10/10.

reviews.review_title: Good action, but lets down at the end
reviews.content:
Don't get me wrong, Lethal Weapon set the standard for police buddy flicks, and is chock full of action and great one-liners.  But the film eventually begins to let down near the end, when the action gets a bit over the top (even for an action flick) and the dialog degrades to the use of "son" "b*tch" and "f*ck" mixed together in different orders more and more frequently.  Lethal Weapon starts off with an interesting plot, some hilarous moments and a good pairup for buddies found in Gibson and Glover; but ends hokey and gets a bit too dark during some points, when the movie was intended to be a funny buddy action flick...still gotta love Lethal Weapon for its good parts though, and the colorful sequels it brought on...
6.5/10

reviews.review_title: Action, good lookin' guys and funny writing...
reviews.content: So, there's nothing about this movie that you can't like. Excellent writing, directing and acting. Mel Gibson gives one of his best performances as Martin Riggs, and Danny Glover introduces himself in the first installation of the four 'Lethal Weapon'series as Sgt. Roger Murtaugh.For back in the late '80s, the action sequences are really quite good, and the acting is excellent. Although it's not my favorite of the four installments in the continuing story of Riggs and Murtaugh, it still has heart, and good direction for an action comedy such as this.It's not a cheap blow 'em up kinda flick. It's got all the right elements that you'd be looking for, in a man clan film, and it's well done. I enjoyed it, and will continue to enjoy it for many years to come.

I loved this film the first time I saw it back in 1987.  It's screenwriter Shane Black's best script, in fact, it's his only good one as long as you don't count his story credit on the almost as good Lethal 2.Gibson and Glover, Glover and Gibson.  Could there be a better on screen comedy-action duo?  Mel Gibson as psycho cop Martin Riggs became everybody's favorite action star when this came out.  The slick Los Angeles setting is also a perfect backdrop for the action to take place.  Lethal Weapon is an action classic with perfect scene after perfect scene.  Check it out or you can't truly call yourself an action movie fan!

What can I say other than this is indeed, one of the greatest action movies ever made? I'll take this over more than 95% of the crock that has come out since. Shane Black created one of the greatest characters with Martin Riggs. The scene where he threatens to blow his head off in after "talking" the jumper down is reason enough to own this film. And who better to play him than the tenacious Mel Gibson? If you haven't seen this movie, stop reading this and go rent it. Scratch that, go out and buy the movie. Danny Glover does an excellent job as his partner, playing it straight. Gary Busey makes for a fantastic bad guy. The music by Michael Kamen goes hand in hand with the series. Cool story. The action scenes are superb.... I'm wasting my time here. See this movie and see why it's one of the best ever!!! Rating: ****1/2 out of *****.

This is one of my favorites. It's about Riggs, a suicidal cop that can shoot, hit, and kill just about anything who is teamed up with an aged cop, Murtaugh, to take down some baddies.Mel Gibson is hilarious in his role as Riggs. Danny Glover is superb in playing the more-serious, less death-defying Murtaugh.The script by Shane Black is outstanding. There are so many memorable moments it is ridiculous. Probably my favorite scene is the gun range scene (don't worry, I won't reveal the gag), where Murtaugh tries to show off his shooting skills by placing a target about 30 feet away. He shoots it square in the head. Then, Riggs shows off his shooting skills by placing the target 100 feet away (Mel Gibson does a hilarious humming tune the whole time), and the result is hilarious.The action is great, the comedy is there, and just about everything is fantastic, really.I give this movie a 10 out of 10.

'Lethal Weapon' is another film franchise I've never had the chance to watch and so this review is based on my first viewing of this film. I will say right here that 'Lethal Weapon' is one of the best action films of the 80's, behind the obvious Die Hard and the obvious Terminator. The characters in the film are extremely great and this is one of the bigger positives from the film. The action in the film is great as was the cinematography until the final fight between Riggs and Joshua, which I say was a great fight but the camera movement was all over the place. It was sad, as the film duel would've looked brilliant. Apart from this, the film was brilliant and I liked the chemistry between Mel Gibson's Riggs and Danny Glover's Roger. That was my favorite part of the entire film. The script was great and the directing and acting were superbDefinite must see film for all die hard action fans!

Right from the start the Jingle bell and the theme/Environment it was amazing.the chemistry of both was iconic love the development of friendship,Danny was amazing as family man and Mel was insane and bad-ass.the story was amazing the investigation and the Mysteries,the ending was fast paced and awesome,the fight at last and whole cat and mouse game was engaging and exciting,Whole movie was phenomenal it was entertaining and its a classic Buddy-cop Flick!

reviews.review_title: Fierce, fast and frequently funny, Lethal Weapon fires off round after round.
reviews.content:
Lethal Weapon is another of Hollywood's movie classics. I enjoyed the different ends of the spectra the two main characters have, and how the audience are allowed to enter and pick their minds. Lethal Weapon has one of my favourite directors of all time as well, making this movie quite a treat.Martin Riggs is no ordinary cop. He's a Mad Max gone maniacal, a man whose killing expertise and suicidal recklessness make him a Lethal Weapon to anyone he works against. Or with. Roger Murtaugh is an easy going homicide detective with a loving family, a big house and a pension he doesn't want to lose. Imagine Murtaugh's shock when he learns his new partner is a guy with nothing left to lose: wild-eyed, burnt-out Martin Riggs. Lethal Weapon is the thrill-packed story of two Vietnam-vets-turned-cops who have just one thing in common: both hate to work with partners. But their partnership becomes the key to survival when a routine murder investigation leads to all-out, take-no-prisoners, martial-arts-and machine-guns war with an international heroin ring.  Well there are no queries from me about the cast of this film. Australian actor Mel Gibson shows his true talent in this action classic. He played Martin Riggs, the suicidal cop and borderline psychopath who's on the edge, perfectly. I love it how Riggs acts first and thinks second. Mel's career has been very illustrious, with films including Gallipoli, Mad Max, Maverick (alongside Jodie Foster), Braveheart, Payback and The Patriot. Then you take Rigg's partner Murtaugh played by veteran actor Danny Glover. His role would have been hard to find, and Glover filled the void beautifully. Glover has appeared in films like The colour purple and voiced characters in in cartoon movies like Antz and Prince of Egypt. Plus had a cameo role in the Maverick. The bad guy of credit in this movie is Gary Busey. He suited his role well. The boss's best tough man and I love the way his character shows no regard for anyone. Busey has some impressive films on the C.V., like Under Siege, Dropzone, and The Firm. This movie has some great scenes. The start is very powerful and keeps you enthralled to what is to come. Then there is some great action and a bit of fun. The scene with the most humour and then tension would have to be when Riggs approaches a man on the edge of a building. Then you have the explosions at the house of the prostitute who is the one person that can help our duo's investigation. But there is a point in this film where it ups the pace and never stops till virtually the end. I just loved the conclusion, with all the macho fighting which was great.
I want to praise the work of veteran director Richard Donner on Lethal Weapon. I love this movie for his touch of class. There is nothing in this movie that I can dispute and the direction he took the audience on was great. I praised Donner in my review of the original Superman movie and enjoyed his touch in the 1985 adventure, The Goonies. Like Superman, without Donner in the director's chair for Lethal Weapon, it would not have been as greater film as it is. Lastly, the onscreen chemistry between Glover and Gibson is one of the things that won me over to this movie, plus some of the quotes in this film are hilarious. If you are fan of this film you are in for a treat, considering there are sequels to follow. So if you are Hollywood movie fan, put this movie at the top of your list, coz I know I have it up there somewhere in mine.I will never be too old for this S#*T!Rating: 4 Stars or 9/10

reviews.review_title: Great funny first half followed by a terrible 80's B-action movie
reviews.content: After a lifetime of seeing this film in bits and pieces, whenever it happened to appear on TV, I finally saw it for the first time in its entirety, and the feelings are mixed.The basic premise of the movie is really bland. It should be enough to hear that that a movie was made in the 80s and that drugs and cops are involved to turn off a large number of people. Lethal Weapon has the markings of a typical 80s factory stamped action movie and it could have disappeared into obscurity, were it not for the two people at its centre: Mel Gibson and Danny Glover.Lethal Weapon is what has become known as a buddy-cop movie. The thing you need for a buddy cop movie is two good actors with a bit of chemistry and that is exactly what these two folks gave us. Nowadays, Mel's personal reputation almost squeezed him out of Hollywood, but do not forget, he is an actor with great charisma and Danny turned out to be just the right complement to his energy.The first part of the movie, when these two are first introduced and just work of each other, is the good part of the movie, but then the stupid starts. The cheesy 80s action stereotypes all come creeping in, complete with shooting rifles from the hip and unnecessary one on one fist fights. The dialogue turns to crap and the humour dies.This flick has a charm that keeps it a float, but it's a shame the story and the action is so poor.

Richard Donner's 'Lethal Weapon' (1987) is a buddy cop action film about two newly paired cops, who are complete opposites, having to put aside their differences in order to catch a gang of drug smugglers. That's the main gist of the film.
I am writing this review as someone who has just seen 'Lethal Weapon' for the first time in his life.This film has earned a great reputation over the decades from the film fan community due to one main reason, the chemistry between our two heroes!Mel Gibson as Martin Riggs and Danny Glover as Roger Murtaugh are both completely different characters, yet they share this undeniable charm that unites them beautifully! A good buddy cop action comedy always needs a great chemistry between the two protagonists! This film does have that!
Despite being constructed like a typical buddy cop action comedy, I still really appreciate the originality of the script. Is it the most amazing screenplay of all time? Of course not. It does have a few problems, mainly that it is too superficial at times and makes it a little too easy for itself when our characters are put into difficult situations. Therefore, at the end of the day, you can exactly see how the story will end and you won't be confronted with any shocking twists and turns.
Then again, the film definitely deserves credit for being so entertaining, fun to watch and pretty clever when it comes to the dialogue. There are some really funny one-liners coming from Mel Gibson and Danny Glover. Admittedly this film does have its silly moments too, especially right at the end!Let me talk a little bit about the impressive cinematography. I would specifically like to talk about one scene (without spoiling anything) where the cinematography stood out to me. There is a key scene in the film that takes place in a rather unusual/distant environment. In that whole sequence the cinematography is absolutely fantastic! You have long takes building up the tension and wide shots increasing the scope of the film even though a rather intimate and personal subject matter is the issue. Due to this wide shot technique the audience is presented with a much grander and richer experience.Despite the R-rating of the film, it is relatively light-hearted with the exception of a few gruesome scenes. The film's pacing is quite good. Unfortunately the second half of the film wasn't as compelling, focused and good as the first one. I feel like the quality had a bit of a dip.
The ending, like I said, is predictable without any twists and turns.Overall, 'Lethal Weapon' is a feel-good movie with some really entertaining and fun scenes. Obviously this film is a cult classic and an absolute must-see film for everybody! If you've never seen it before... what are you doing?! Go watch it! 6/10

Martin Riggs: "Well, what do you wanna hear, man? Do you wanna hear that sometimes I think about eatin' a bullet? Huh? Well, I do! I even got a special bullet for the occasion with a hollow point, look! Make sure it blows the back of my god damned head out and do the job right! Every single day I wake up and I think of a reason not to do it! Every single day! You know why I don't do it? This is gonna make you laugh! You know why I don't do it? The job! Doin' the job! Now that's the reason!" Los Angeles police sergeant Roger Murtaugh, who has just turned 50 years old, is assigned to investigate the death of Amanda Hunsaker, a prostitute who is one of the daughters of bank president Michael Hunsaker, a friend whom Roger has known since they were in the Vietnam War together, but Roger hasn't seen Michael in 12 years. Beginning with this investigation, Roger is assigned a new partner Sergeant Martin Riggs, who has been suicidal ever since his wife Victoria "Vicky" Lynn Riggs died in a car crash in 1984. Riggs and Murtaugh's investigation of Amanda's death reveals that she was murdered. Upon hearing of this, Michael tells Murtaugh that he would like for whoever is behind Amanda's murder to end up dead, like Amanda. Riggs and Murtaugh's investigation continues and it makes them the targets of Shadow Company, a group of former Vietnam War era mercenaries who now bring heroin into the Los Angeles County region. Shadow Company's leader, General Peter McAllister, and his right hand man, Mr. Joshua, want Riggs and Murtaugh dead, no matter what the cost.Just saw this last night as a part of my Lethal Weapon Saga movie nights and man, this one right here is the ultimate buddy cop film. This movie, in my opinion started the buddy cop genre which later spawned a whole lot of buddy cop films. From Tango & Cash, Bad Boys and Starsky & Hutch, it was all inspired by Lethal Weapon. What makes this film work incredibly is the chemistry between two leads: Mel Gibson as psychotic cop Martin Riggs and Danny Glover as "I'm too old fo' this sheet" Roger Murtaugh.I admit, I've never been really a fan of Mel Gibson as an actor, I like him better when he's behind the camera but this film changes it all. Tremendous acting by Gibson as well as Glover. Another reason why this film really clicked is the villainous Gary Busey as Mr. Joshua. A bad ass character portrayed by a bad ass actor. Mr. Joshua will go down as one of the greatest villains of all time.

reviews.review_title: A movie that goes back to a simpler time -- The 80's?
reviews.content: This movie earns a ten, not because it's profound; it isn't... It earns a ten because it's a movie that set the bar. It introduced humor and family, to over the top action ( for the times) movies; Arguably. The next 15 years in action movies were based in the formulas for hits like this and Die Hard which came out the following season.I wish they had just let it lay as is; and stayed away from the sequels. Each Sequel diluted this movie. Until it became a joke on Always Sunny. But, if you've never seen it; it's not a bad way to spend some leisure time... Most guys from the 80's have seen this movie 10 times at least...

I suggest that everyone go see the "Director's Cut," which includes some supplemental scenes. This is really the best buddy-cop duo movie, and the one that initiated a series of copy-cats that never quite matched up. This is almost cartoonish at times and over the top, but in a good way. I don't believe anyone will ever be able to match Gary Busey's authentic-brand of crazy!! What really stands out about this is the dialogue and the memorable quotes. Of all the Lethal Weapons, this is my favorite. People alive today might not get many of the Vietnam-era references, which are numerous. But this movie is so cleverly put together, and with such timeliness and finesse.

reviews.review_title: A Buddy Cop Comedy for the Ages
reviews.content: The character Riggs is sympathetic as hell, while also being funny as hell! Danny Glover is also a well-defined character who loves his family and hates drug dealers! One of my favorite action movies! Only 9 stars for attempted rape, though!

reviews.review_title: Quintessential action flick, Mel Gibson's breakout role...
reviews.content: One of the better 80s cop films, this was Mel Gibson's breakout role (I liked the Mad Max films, but he was *perfect* here). This is one of the few series where all of the films worked; each one had qualities that outshone the others. Gibson's Riggs is best in the first film, though; the facial expressions, the dialogue, the body language: this is Mel Gibson at his best.Danny Glover, on the other hand, really seemed to warm/wake up in 2. He wasn't as solid in the first one, he felt too wooden and too generic.The script is sharp, good use of foreshadow and well-written in terms of plot and pacing. The film doesn't get boring, and doesn't really get unrealistic eitheras far as any action film doesn't;) Gary Busey plays his typical evil villain character, one that he plays so well at all times (though each character tends to be a branch on the same tree, so to speak).Some of the action was a little too generic. The final fight scene was way over the top, could've been clipped a bit.Overall: not much to say except that this is a good, solid action film. One worth watching; in fact, the whole series is most definitely worth watching. Some things could have been better, but most was right on. 7/10.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest buddy films ever.
reviews.content: If you can get past Mel Gibson's haircut then you will love this film. Lethal Weapon is the best of the cop buddy films and one of the originators of the modern formula. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover make a great team and their chemistry onscreen is genuine. Gary Busey makes a great villian in the evil Mr. Joshua. Plenty of action and wisecracks keep this movie moving and keep it light-hearted and fun. The second best of the Lethal Weapon films, (I think 4 is the best) Lethal Weapon just gets better with age. Bottom Line: If you like action and comedy wrapped up in one film, Lethal Weapon is a pretty good choice.

reviews.review_title: the way action movies should be made again!
reviews.content: God, I miss these type of action movies... Two good Vietnam veteran cops cleaning up the streets of LA from drug dealing Vietnam vets and mercenaries. This movie was and still is one of the best action movies ever made. The chemistry between Danny Glover and Mel Gibson as Roger Murtaugh and Martin Riggs was the original (and still the best) template for many other buddy cop flicks to follow. I give major credit and would like to thank Richard Donner, Shane Black and Joel Silver for making this movie work on every level. I hope that one day these types of movies will return to the big screen again. I can only hope, since movies have become very unoriginal.

reviews.review_title: It will take a heck of an action movie to beat Lethal Weapon
reviews.content: Lethal Weapon shocked me at the same way as Die Hard did ( i'm sure you will find it's got practically the same Summary). There is NOTHING in the world that could beat this movie. Even though Die Hard was a relatively different movie than this it's about as good as this one. The story is in the same geniously spirit as Die Hard. I mean just the idea of pairing together two totally different kind of people and let them work together. I like the first one best because it really fits with the describing ''Lethal''. In Lethal 2 the humor was clearer with Joe Pesci and all. In Lethal 3 his role had got bigger. And in Lethal 4 the whole story is actually almost more funny than Lethal. So I like the original for one simple reason: It's tough! The fighting scenes have never been more violent then in this one ( OK OK OK the Lethal 4-end maybe ). But one things for sure: Mel Gibson is really a Lethal Weapon in this movie. The other parts are just more childish. Here it is a more grown-up story. Enough speaking. See Lethal Weapon. If you can buy the ''Lethal Weapon box'' with all three in directors cut. Don't ask  why just DO IT!

reviews.review_title: A perfect blend of humor and action. Strongly recommended.(Spoilers)
reviews.content: I watched Lethal Weapon in the theater when it first came out in 1987, it blew me away. I've never seen such a movie like that before, it had been copied for numerous times so it wouldn't be so appealing nowadays. I bought DVDs of the Lethal Weapon series. To me, this one still stands out as the best of the four. Its brilliance and luster retains even though I watch it in 2008. It certainly deserves to get at least one Oscar for the performance and some special effects but it was overlooked. One of the most eloquent evidence that proves the Academy Award is a joke.First, this movie starts with a aerial view of the city of Los Angeles. As the title "Lethal Weapon" appears, you get a feeling this is not only a cop movie but also an ultimate blockbuster. Later, the camera stops in the balcony. We see a half-naked woman lying on the bed, as if she is drowned or her high is coming up. However, she somehow climbs onto the balcony and takes a dive out of the building. Her death leads to an introduction of an middle-aged cop who is celebrating his birthday. His name is Murtaugh(played by Danny Glover), he is fifty years old when he takes this case. Later, he is informed he will be partnered with a cop named Riggs(played by Mel Gibson), only to find out the cop is suicidal because his wife was killed in a car accident a few years ago. First, the two cops detest each other very much. As time goes on, they become accustomed to each other and they stand together to fight against the bad guys of the movie. The bad guys are a bunch of veterans who become drug dealers by smuggling the heroin from Vietnam. Their leader is stern general and a macho guy named Joshua(played by Gary Busey), who is the top guy in the unit. All the actors were doing a great job and delivered believable, flesh-and-blood, and comical characters. Mel Gibson gave an outstanding performance as Riggs. His hardened exterior could not cover up the fragile interior of his. He was in a dilemma whether to kill himself or go on living. Danny Glover was also remarkable, he did everything "by the book", who could ever forget his characteristics: Shooting criminals in the leg and shooting people directly in the head. Gary Busey gave his best performance to date. This is one movie he ever immersed into his character. The action scenes were perfectly done. Almost two hours of non-stop action can satisfy action fans. Also, it can be considered a comedy to watch when you want to get rid of your burden. Also, some people have the tradition to watch it on Christmas. It can have different significance and interpretation reviewed by different people. Good story, good actors, crazy action, comical scenes, and significant masterpiece. This movie is a landmark of cop movies. 20 years and it still retains all these good elements. Strongly recommended for you to watch it.

These are a great series of films. Their just fun! The  others are good, but this one is  the best. The reason I liked this one is because it was a "big deal" when Riggs or Murtaugh killed someone, unlike the others where it was boom boom boom let's go get some dog biscuits (the whole doggy treat thing was funny though). This one was also superior because it was taken more serious than the other three, but other than that, I like them all. This is a very original film and should be considered a classic.  I still think they are the best series of action movies and it alone is one of the best action in itself. 9/10

reviews.review_title: The series that changed action films
reviews.content: In the 1980's, Chuck Norris and Charles Bronson were churning out action movies. Slyvester Stallone went from Rocky, to jumping on the action Bandwagon with the Rambo series. Even Arnold had established himself just fine in both the sci-fi and action worlds.Then everything changed. With a stellar cast and truly great director at the helm, Out comes Lethal Weapon.Suddenly, the body count became secondary to the plot, and not the other way around. The old Who dunit and the supercharged action film got merged together. Suddenly, Hollywood found a new way to make action films.The story is simple. When the daughter of an old Army buddy dies, Roger Murtuagh, nearing the end of his police career, is assigned to the case. The catch is he has to take a partner. MArtin Riggs, whom Murtaugh mistakes as a crazed gunman looking to take the police station hostage. That in my opinion sets up one of the best and most introductions of two characters ever filmed.Murtaugh see's Riggs Loose Cannon tactics, and including the well intended, but only adding to the troubles, advice from the police department's psychologist, Murtaugh thinks that his new partner may just be the end of him.However, the film steers from being overly dramatic min this aspect to allow for a little humor. Humor until now had been something that action films had been nearly devoid of. After an exchangement of war stories, soon the mis matched pair begin to have a trust in each other.Soon they are on the trail of drug runners, ironically funded by Roger's ex army buddy, who it turns out, who's daughter was murdered to keep him silent.However, he himself becomes expendable when the drug runners think he's going to spill his guts to his former army buddy, and quickly dispatch of him while he attempts to tell his side to Murtaugh.Gary Busey is at his evil zenith as Mr. Joshua, a skilled killer with little regard for human life. After Murtaugh's daughter is kidnapped, he and Riggs go it alone to get her back. That sets up a battle which goes from the desert, to down town LA, and ends with a karate battle right on Murtuagh's own front yard.The fight between Riggs and Joshua is suspenseful, and excellently shot, with the rain fall adding great effect. And by the time the movie's over, Murtaugh and Riggs are now the closest of friends, over coming the troubled start.I really do think this one film changed the way that action films are shot. No longer is a high body count the most important part. Now story development is paid attention to. The Lethal Weapon series is perhaps the most groundbreaking on that point alone.

reviews.review_title: Gibson and Glover both made this movie worth watching!
reviews.content: I don't have too much to say about this movie, but I'll do my best. So here it is: Lethal Weapon is basically a buddy cop movie about two mismatched cops working together on a case as they try to put a stop for a bunch of gangs for dealing with drugs on a Christmas holiday. What made this movie work is that both Mel Gibson and Danny Glover work so well together as we buy the chemistry between them; these two wonderful actors are the reason for making this movie worth watching. Gary Busey is a lot of fun as the villain as the rest of the cast all did for what they have to do. Richard Donner does a fine job directing the movie, but I mainly love his work on the first "Superman" movie as well as the sequel that he never completely finish as he only shot seventy-five percent of the movie if the producer didn't fired him so he can finish it for one hundred percent. The music by Michael Kamen is nothing special, but it is well done. The action in this movie is terrific, and the humor itself is alright. What didn't work is that the movie itself feels kind of slow, and which if they cut some things out so that I feel like I'm watching a fast paced buddy cop movie. That is just me, in my humble opinion. Also, I don't think its the greatest action movie of all time as it takes place around Christmas. So, I guess you can say that I like "Die Hard" more but I digress. Anyway, like I said, I don't have too much to say about "Lethal Weapon," but I do like to say that it is a fun movie, and both Gibson and Glover are wonderful together. I give it an 8 out of 10.

The eighties a time of big hair, bad clothes and worse music but the eighties also gave us Axel Foley, Arnie and of course Riggs and Murtagh. Lethal Weapon is an unashamed big, loud action movie but its more than this to with a smart plot and interesting characters. It's helped by having Gibson & Glover who are the best 'buddy' team since Redford & Newman, the action scenes are top quality but it's the interaction of these two that makes the movie. All the necessary ingredients for a great action blockbuster are present and correct chases, shootouts and a terrific final showdown. What is surprising is how little this film has dated it easily stands head and shoulders above recent efforts such as Bad Boys 2, XXX 2 etc. Top entertainment 8/10.Note - If possible see the directors cut which adds more depth to Riggs character with two quality scenes added.

reviews.review_title: An Action Packed Film That Can't Be Beaten
reviews.content: When the producers and stars made this film, I wonder if they knew how successful and memorable it was going to be. Mel Gibson stars as a suicidal cop, with co star Danny Glover as the straight, sensible cop.They are a great 'screen couple', who go on to entertain audiences all over the world for another three films. Although there were valiant efforts, the other Lethal Weapons didn't seem to do this one much justice. For a start, they didn't have excellent bad guy Mr Joshua(Gary Busey on top form).Lethal Weapon 2 was disappointing. The script writers were obviously on auto drive and depended heavily on Gibson's charm and Glover's talent!The action in number 1 is brilliantly done. The dialogue between the two stars has its moments and the bad guy is incredibly good. Rating=4/5

reviews.review_title: One of the great buddy movies!
reviews.content: Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) is a police officer who has just turned 50 years old and is assigned to investigate the death of Amanda Hunsaker, the daughter of Michael (Tom Atkins) one of Murtaugh's old Vietnam buddy's that he hasn't seen in around 12 years. At the same time the department has assigned Murtaugh with a new partner, Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) a man with a death wish who has been suffering with depression ever since his wife Victoria was killed in a car crash. Their investigations prove that Amanda Hunsaker was murdered and as they delve deeper they find themselves immersed in the world of organised drug trafficking and also find their original distrust and suspicion for each other grow into friendship.Perhaps not the greatest action movie ever, and in my opinion a little poorer than the first two sequels, Lethal Weapon' is an exceptional action/thriller and is definitely worth checking out. Lethal Weapon' is rather dark and gritty and deals with numerous interesting, and often emotional, scenes. Mel Gibson is great as the suicidal Martin Riggs and makes his character shine out in many scenes, including a school-yard sniper scene in the directors cut version. The audience can identify with Riggs and feel sympathy for him without being distracted from the main storyline. On top of this Danny Glover puts in a strong performance as the family man Murtaugh and adds a certain lightness to the movie without making it any less gritty. I personally feel that the pairing of Gibson and Glover is one of the all time greats in cinema, the characters of Riggs and Murtaugh go together exceptionally and the eventual trust and friendship that grows between the two is almost a beautiful thing to behold. A rather ingenious soundtrack really helps to add an air of humanity to certain scenes and compliments the Gibson/Glover partnership perfectly on many occasions. Credit must also go to Mitch Ryan who played Captain McAllister and Gary Busey who played Mr. Joshua as both portrayed their villainous characters magnificently and convincingly.The film moves at a steady pace and despite dragging on occasion is generally paced well enough to sustain the viewers interest. There is a lack of action early on in the movie but this does not hamper Lethal Weapon' in any way. The first half of the movie is almost more like a drama as we have to see if Riggs can keep his head together long enough for the duo to solve the crime. It's in the first half of the movie that the audience is treated to many emotional moments as the character of Riggs is fully investigated by director Richard Donner (this in my opinion is one of Donner's best films) and writer Shane Black. We learn so much about both characters in the first half that when the action portion of the movie gets going it's almost impossible not to feel for these characters who are putting their lives on the line. Donner's direction is exceptional though sometimes he lets himself down a little with some poor choices for camera angles or somewhat slow direction.There are few faults to this movie though people expecting gunfight after gunfight and explosion after explosion may be a little disappointed. Also the occasional dragging of the storyline makes some parts of the movie a little tedious, but overall the screenplay is very tight and there is a lot of useful and realistic dialogue. I would certainly recommend this to action movie fans and casual moviegoers. For fans of this I recommend the first two sequels as well. My rating for Lethal Weapon'  7.5/10

It took 30 years before I was able to watch this movie on the big screen.This classic has aged really well.Sure it's unrealistic and stuff but it is so well executed, well played by everyone and the action is really good.All in all a fantastic movie! I loved every second of it and although I have actually watched it several times before it was still a thrill ride!I wish more movies would look that good nowadays. Just stop wasting money on over the top CGI! Put it into proper storytelling, a good camera crew and proper cutters.

One of the movie genres which is the most popular in Hollywood is the action movie genre, movies like Star Wars (1977), Broken Arrow (1996), Independence Day (1996), The Fugitive (1993), and many more.  Personally, my favorite has always been Die Hard (1988) and considering some of the action movies we have been able to see quite recently, it always will be.  However, Lethal Weapon is another movie that I would consider as a good action movie. It isn't Die Hard, but it's pretty close and having been released one year before Die Hard, I give it credit for its styles which we can find in all of the Lethal Weapon movies.  These styles are a blend of action and comedy and a few emotional moments which keep the movie going and do not throw it off track.  Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) is a cop who is very suicidal and whom many think is crazy.  He lives alone in his broken down trailer with no other friend than his guard dog.  During the day, he works undercover busting drug dealers or as a normal cop but doing crazy things like jumping off a roof with a man who had intended to do that in the first place.  On the other side, we have detective Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover), an investigative cop who has just turned fifty.  Roger is married and father of three. 
  This is the set-up for the movie or as some people might call it, the excuse for allowing the movie to be.  The only thing is, these two men will have to meet one day if director Richard Donner wants his movie to be.  And this is where the emotional part of the movie comes in.  One night, in his trailer, Riggs brings his gun to his mouth and the only thing that keeps him from pulling the trigger is the picture of his wife who is deceased.  It seems to be the reason he wants to pull the trigger so that he may join her, but it also seems to keep him from shooting himself.  On the other side, detective Murtaugh is investigating the death of a prostitute who turns out to be the daughter of a friend with whom he served in Vietnam.  However, after the autopsy of the dead girl, the apparent suicide seems to be a murder case after all.  At this point, the two men have not met but they will quite soon.  Riggs is assigned to Murtaugh as his new partner.  The two of them quickly meet when Murtaugh assaults Riggs when he takes out his gun in the police precinct believing Riggs was about to attack the department.  Murtaugh soon realizes that his partner is a mad man and might get him killed while they work.  Riggs, on the other hand, sees nothing crazy whatsoever in what manners he uses to defend himself or his partner as long as he gets the job done.  For him, that is the only thing that counts considering the fact that Riggs realizes he is suicidal.  There is a very intense scene in which Murtaugh is trying to push Riggs over the edge telling him he should kill himself for he believes Riggs is not willing to do it.  But he realizes, just like the viewer, that Riggs is very willing and that he shouldn't tempt him.  The comedy sets in after the two of them meet and this is what makes this movie so unique.  In Die Hard, we saw Bruce Willis making wisecracks every now and then which allowed the movie to be more relaxing and all the more entertaining.  In Lethal Weapon however, the two actors make jokes and funny remarks about their age, Glover's family, and many other subjects all along the movie which gives it a cool rhythm and a nice flow.    Danny Glover seems to be one of the best actors they could have gotten for the job of Murtaugh as he delivers the goods and gives his now famous line "I'm too old for this s***" quite often.  But Gibson is the only man there was for the role of Riggs.  He steals the movie with his tough uncaring attitude of wether he dies on the job or not.  His attitude in the movie is comparable to Connery's in The Untouchables (1987) as he is ready to do anything as long as that gets the job done.  Fnally, the only thing missing to complete the cast is the bad guy.  I this case, Gary Busey plays an evil wacko named Mr. Joshua who has a disfunction in his nervous system as he can take pain with no reaction and still keep fighting back until he is taken down.  Busey is as good as Gibson and this might be one of the movie's flaws, Busey's lack of screen-time.  The script could have been somewhat stronger but you can't have everything now can you.  Overall, it is a very cool action movie and is definitely worth a watch.

I had high hopes for this film, but after having watched it, I'm a little disappointed. Sure, it has its moments, but the plot doesn't do much for me. It feels like a run-of-the-mill action movie with not a whole lot of creativity put into it. It has a plethora of shooting and car chase scenes. Because Lord knows you can never have enough of those.The movie, which takes place in LA during the 1980's, revolves around Sergeant Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover), an aging Black police officer. He comes into work the day after his 50th birthday to find out he has been assigned a new partner: Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson), a stereotypical disgruntled, suicidal, highly-skilled Vietnam War veteran, and the namesake of the movie.Roger and Riggs start off on a rocky start, but throughout the film develop a closer bond. The beginning of the duo's partnership coincides with a prostitute's murder. The prostitute was the daughter of an old colleague of Roger's, who had been trying to get in touch with him about something urgent shortly before her death. Roger and Riggs soon find out the murder is a part of something much bigger.This is not a bad movie. It's just not very original. Many of the scenes here are scenes I feel I've seen before in other action movies: the cop drug bust scene, the cops practicing at the firing range scene, the shooting at the club scene, etc. While I have nothing against him as an actor, Gary Busey seems almost like a too-obvious choice for a villain. His character is one-dimensional and his backstory is never explored. In fact, none of the characters are particularly interesting, especially Mel Gibson's portrayal of Martin Riggs, who is entertaining, perhaps, but not very original. However, I must admit Danny Glover's character makes for a likable and relatable protagonist.I would personally not recommend this movie. While it may have been sleek and "cutting edge" back in the 80s it simply has not aged well.

This is a wonderful movie. It has been praised for it action, comedy, acting. Practically every element ha received a favorable call out in at least one -- usually many -- of these comments. The truth (abolute and not subjective) is that it is all terrific. My favorite part is Gibson. He is beyond gorgeous and does a wonderful job here. One can easily believe that this led to his being cast as Hamlet.
